The [[Laas Geel]] complex on the outskirts of [[Hargeisa]] in northwestern  dates back approximately 5,000 years, and has [[rock art]] depicting both wild animals and decorated cows. Other [[cave painting]]s are found in the northern [[Dhambalin]] region, which feature one of the earliest known depictions of a hunter on horseback. The rock art is dated to 1,000 to 3,000 BC. Additionally, between the towns of [[Las Khorey]] and [[El Ayo]] in northern  lies [[Karinhegane]], the site of numerous cave paintings, which collectively have been estimated to be around 2,500 years old.

The [[camel]] is believed to have been domesticated in the Horn region sometime between the 2nd and 3rd millennium BC. From there, it spread to [[]] and the [[Maghreb]].

=== Antiquity and classical era ===
{{Main| architecture}}
[[File:Men from Punt Carrying Gifts, Tomb of Rekhmire MET 30.4.152 EGDP013029.jpg|thumb|Men from [[Land of Punt|Punt]] carrying Gifts, Tomb of [[Rekhmire]].]]
Ancient [[pyramid]]ical structures, [[mausoleum]]s, ruined cities and stone walls, such as the [[Wargaade Wall]], are evidence of an old civilisation that once thrived in the  peninsula. This civilisation enjoyed a trading relationship with [[ancient ]] and [[Mycenaean ]] since the second millennium BC, supporting the hypothesis that  or adjacent regions were the location of the ancient [[Land of Punt]]. The Puntites native to the region traded [[myrrh]], spices, gold, ebony, short-horned cattle, ivory and [[frankincense]] with the , Phoenicians, Babylonians, ,  and Romans through their commercial ports. An  expedition sent to Punt by the [[Eighteenth dynasty of |18th dynasty]] Queen [[Hatshepsut]] is recorded on the temple reliefs at [[Deir el-Bahari]], during the reign of the Puntite King Parahu and Queen Ati.

In the [[Classical antiquity|classical era]], the [[Macrobians]], who may have been ancestral to , established a powerful  kingdom that ruled large parts of modern . They were reputed for their longevity and wealth, and were said to be the "tallest and handsomest of all men". The Macrobians were warrior herders and seafarers. According to Herodotus' account, the [[Persian Emperor]] [[Cambyses II]], upon his [[History of Achaemenid |conquest of ]] in 525 BC, sent ambassadors to Macrobia, bringing luxury gifts for the Macrobian king to entice his submission. The Macrobian ruler, who was elected based on his stature and beauty, replied instead with a challenge for his Persian counterpart in the form of an unstrung bow: if the Persians could manage to draw it, they would have the right to invade his country; but until then, they should thank the gods that the Macrobians never decided to invade their empire. The Macrobians were a regional power reputed for their advanced architecture and [[gold]] wealth, which was so plentiful that they shackled their prisoners in golden chains.

During the classical period, the [[Barbaria (region)|Barbara]] city-states of [[Mosylon]], [[Opone]], [[Heis (town)|Mundus]], [[Bulhar|Isis]], [[Malao]], [[Zeila|Avalites]], [[Essina]], [[Nikon ()|Nikon]] and [[Sarapion]] developed a lucrative trade network, connecting with merchants from [[Ptolemaic Kingdom|Ptolemaic ]], [[Ancient ]], [[Phoenicia]], [[Parthian Empire|Parthian Persia]], [[Sabaeans|Saba]], the [[Nabataean Kingdom]], and the [[Roman Empire]]. They used the ancient  maritime vessel known as the ''[[beden]]'' to transport their cargo.
[[File:Beden.jpg|thumbnail|The [[Beden]] is a fast, ancient  single or double-masted maritime ship.]]
After the [[Nabatea#Roman annexation|Roman conquest of the Nabataean Empire]] and the Roman naval presence at [[Aden]] to curb piracy, Arab and  merchants agreed with the Romans to bar  ships from trading in the free port cities of the [[Arabian Peninsula|Arabian peninsula]] to protect the interests of  and Arab merchants in the lucrative commerce between the Red and Mediterranean Seas. However,  merchants continued to trade in the port cities of the  peninsula, which was free from Roman interference. For centuries,  merchants brought large quantities of cinnamon to  and Arabia from [[Ceylon]] and the [[Maluku Islands|Spice Islands]]. The source of the cinnamon and other spices is said to have been the best-kept secret of Arab and  merchants in their trade with the Roman and  world; the Romans and  believed the source to have been the  peninsula. The collusive agreement among  and Arab traders inflated the price of  and  cinnamon in North Africa, the Near East, and Europe, and made the cinnamon trade a very profitable revenue generator, especially for the  merchants.

=== Birth of Islam and the Middle Ages ===

{{Main| aristocratic and court titles|Ifat Sultanate|Walashma dynasty|Sultanate of Mogadishu|Adal Sultanate|Ajuran Sultanate|}}
[[File:Silk route.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35|The [[Silk Road]] extending from  to southern Europe, Arabia, , , Persia, , and Java]]
[[Islam]] was introduced to the area early on by the first Muslims of Mecca fleeing prosecution during the first [[Hegira|Hejira]] with [[Masjid al-Qiblatayn ()|Masjid al-Qiblatayn]] in [[Zeila]] being built before the [[Qibla]]h towards [[Mecca]]. It is one of the oldest [[mosque]]s in Africa. In the late 9th century, [[Al-Yaqubi]] wrote that Muslims were living along the northern  seaboard. He also mentioned that the [[Adal Sultanate|Adal Kingdom]] had its capital in the city. According to [[Leo Africanus]], the [[Adal Sultanate]] was governed by local [[ people|]] dynasties and its realm encompassed the geographical area between the Bab el Mandeb and Cape Guardafui. It was thus flanked to the south by the [[Ajuran Empire]] and to the west by the [[Abyssinian Empire]].

Throughout the Middle Ages, Arab immigrants arrived in Somaliland, a historical experience which would later lead to the legendary stories about Muslim [[sheikh]]s such as [[Abdirahman bin Isma'il al-Jabarti|Daarood]] and [[Ishaaq bin Ahmed]] (the purported ancestors of the [[Darod]] and [[Isaaq]] clans, respectively) travelling from [[Arabia]] to  and marrying into the local [[Dir (clan)|Dir]] clan.

In 1332, the Zeila-based King of Adal was slain in a military campaign aimed at halting Abyssinian emperor [[Amda Seyon I]]'s march toward the city. When the last Sultan of Ifat, [[Sa'ad ad-Din II]], was also killed by Emperor [[Dawit I of |Dawit I]] in Zeila in 1410, his children escaped to , before returning in 1415. In the early 15th century, Adal's capital was moved further inland to the town of [[Dakkar]], where [[Sabr ad-Din II]], the eldest son of Sa'ad ad-Din II, established a new base after his return from .
[[File:Imaam Ahmed Gurey.jpg|thumb|Statue of [[Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi|Ahmed ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi]], [[Imam]] of the [[Adal Sultanate|Adal Empire]]]]
Adal's headquarters were again relocated the following century, this time southward to [[Harar]]. From this new capital, Adal organised an effective army led by Imam [[Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi]], (Ahmad "Gurey" or "Gran"; both meaning "the left-handed") and his closest top general and brother in law [[Matan ibn Uthman Al |Garad Matan]]. Imam Ahmed clan is documented to be from the [[Geri Koombe]], a sub clan of Darod. This 16th-century campaign is historically known as the [[Abyssinian–Adal war|Conquest of Abyssinia]] (''Futuh al-Habash''). During the war, Imam Ahmad pioneered the use of cannons supplied by the Ottoman Empire, which he imported through Zeila and deployed against Abyssinian forces and their  allies led by [[Cristóvão da Gama]].

During the [[Ajuran Sultanate]] period, the city-states and republics of [[Merca]], [[Mogadishu]], [[Barawa]], [[Hobyo]] and their respective ports flourished and had a lucrative foreign commerce with ships sailing to and from Arabia, , [[Venetia (region)|Venetia]], Persia, , , and as far away as . [[Vasco da Gama]], who passed by Mogadishu in the 15th century, noted that it was a large city with houses several storeys high and large palaces in its centre, in addition to many mosques with cylindrical minarets. The [[Harla people|Harla]], an early [[Hamitic]] group of tall stature who inhabited parts of , Tchertcher and other areas in the Horn, also erected various [[tumulus|tumuli]]. These masons are believed to have been ancestral to ethnic .[[File:ShenDuGiraffePainting.jpg|thumb|The [[Ajuran Sultanate]] maintained commercial ties with the [[Ming dynasty]] and other kingdoms.|left|268x268px]]

In the 16th century, [[Duarte Barbosa]] noted that many ships from the [[Khambhat|Kingdom of Cambaya]] in modern-day  sailed to Mogadishu with cloth and spices, for which they in return received gold, wax and ivory. Barbosa also highlighted the abundance of meat, wheat, barley, horses, and fruit on the coastal markets, which generated enormous wealth for the merchants. Mogadishu, the centre of a thriving textile industry known as ''toob benadir'' (specialised for the markets in , among other places), together with Merca and Barawa, also served as a transit stop for [[Swahili people|Swahili]] merchants from [[Mombasa]] and [[Malindi]] and for the gold trade from [[Kilwa Sultanate|Kilwa]]. [[Jewish]] merchants from the [[Strait of Hormuz|Hormuz]] brought their  textile and fruit to the  coast in exchange for [[grain]] and wood.

Trading relations were established with [[Malacca]] in the 15th century, with cloth, ambergris and porcelain being the main commodities of the trade. Giraffes, zebras and incense were exported to the [[Ming Empire]] of , which established  merchants as leaders in the commerce between East Asia and the Horn. Hindu merchants from [[Surat]] and Southeast African merchants from [[Pate Island|Pate]], seeking to bypass both the [[ ]] blockade (and later the  interference), used the  ports of Merca and Barawa (which were out of the two powers' direct jurisdiction) to conduct their trade in safety and without interference.
{{clear}}

=== Early modern era and the scramble for Africa ===
{{Main|Geledi sultanate|Majeerteen Sultanate|Sultanate of Hobyo|l2 = Isaaq Sultanate|Dervish movement ()}}
{{see also| Somaliland| Somaliland}}
[[File:Mogadishu1936.jpg|thumb|[[Mogadishu under  rule|Mogadishu]], capital of [[ Somaliland]], with the [[Mogadiscio Cathedral|Catholic Cathedral]] at the center and the Arch monument in honour of [[Umberto I of |King Umberto I of ]]]]
[[File:Reception of Olal Dinle in .jpg|thumb|Sultan [[Olol Dinle]] (third from right) and his delegation, in [[Benito Mussolini]]'s , during the festivities of [[Adolf Hitler]]'s visit to [[Rome]], 1938|261x261px]]
In the [[early modern]] period, successor states to the Adal Sultanate and [[Ajuran Sultanate]] began to flourish in . These included the [[Hiraab Imamate]], the [[Isaaq Sultanate]] led by the [[Guled Dynasty|Guled dynasty]], the [[Habr Yunis Sultanate]] led by the [[Rer Ainanshe|Ainanshe dynasty]], the [[Sultanate of the Geledi]] (Gobroon dynasty), the [[Majeerteen Sultanate]] (Migiurtinia), and the [[Sultanate of Hobyo]] (Obbia). They continued the tradition of castle-building and seaborne trade established by previous  empires.

Sultan [[Yusuf Mahamud Ibrahim]], the third Sultan of the House of Gobroon, started the golden age of the Gobroon Dynasty. His army came out victorious during the Bardheere Jihad, which restored stability in the region and revitalised the East African [[ivory trade]]. He also had cordial relations and received gifts from the rulers of neighbouring and distant kingdoms such as the , [[Wituland|Witu]] and  Sultans.

Sultan Ibrahim's son [[Ahmed Yusuf (Gobroon)|Ahmed Yusuf]] succeeded him as one of the most important figures in 19th-century East Africa, receiving tribute from  governors and creating alliances with important Muslim families on the East African coast.

In [[Somaliland]], the Isaaq Sultanate was established in 1750. The Isaaq Sultanate was a  kingdom that ruled parts of the [[Horn of Africa]] during the 18th and 19th centuries. It spanned the territories of the [[Isaaq]] clan, descendants of the [[Banu Hashim]] clan, in modern-day Somaliland and . The sultanate was governed by the Rer Guled branch established by the first sultan, Sultan [[Guled Abdi (Sultan)|Guled Abdi]], of the [[Eidagale]] clan. According to oral tradition, prior to the Guled dynasty the [[Isaaq]] clan-family were ruled by a dynasty of the Tolje'lo branch starting from, descendants of Ahmed nicknamed Tol Je'lo, the eldest son of [[Ishaaq bin Ahmed|Sheikh Ishaaq]]'s [[Harari people|Harari]] wife. There were eight Tolje'lo rulers in total, starting with Boqor Harun ({{Langx|so|Boqor Haaruun}}) who ruled the Isaaq Sultanate for centuries starting from the 13th century. The last Tolje'lo ruler [[Garad]] Dhuh Barar ({{langx|so|Dhuux Baraar}}) was overthrown by a coalition of Isaaq clans. The once strong Tolje'lo clan were scattered and took refuge amongst the [[Habr Awal]] with whom they still mostly live.

In the late 19th century, after the [[Berlin Conference]] of 1884, European powers began the [[Scramble for Africa]]. In that year, a  protectorate was declared over part of , on the African coast opposite South . Initially, this region was under the control of the  Office, and so administered as part of the  Empire; in 1898 it was transferred to control by London. In 1889, the protectorate and later colony of [[ ]] was officially established by [[Kingdom of |]] through various treaties signed with a number of chiefs and sultans; Sultan [[Yusuf Ali Kenadid]] first sent a request to  in late December 1888 to make his [[Sultanate of Hobyo]] an  protectorate before later signing a treaty in 1889.
[[File:Hobyo Sultanate Cavalry And Fort.jpg|left|thumb|[[Sultanate of Hobyo|Hobyo Sultanate]] cavalry and fort]]
The Dervish movement successfully repulsed the  Empire four times and forced it to retreat to the coastal region. The [[Dervish movement ()|Darawiish]] defeated the , , Abyssinian colonial powers on numerous occasions, most notably, the 1903 victory at Cagaarweyne commanded by [[Suleiman Aden Galaydh]], forcing the [[ Empire]] to retreat to the coastal region in the early 1900s. The Dervishes were finally defeated in 1920 by  airpower.{{sfn|Samatar|1982|pages=[https://archive.org/details/oralpoetrysomali00sama/page/n144 131], 135}}

The dawn of [[fascism]] in the early 1920s heralded a change of strategy for , as the north-eastern sultanates were soon to be forced within the boundaries of ''La Grande '' ("''[[Greater ]]''") according to the plan of Fascist . With the arrival of Governor [[Cesare Maria De Vecchi]] on 15 December 1923, things began to change for that part of Somaliland known as [[ Somaliland]]. The last piece of land acquired by  in  was [[Oltre Giuba]], present-day [[Jubaland]] region, in 1925.[[File:Sayyid Mohammed Abdullah Hassan.jpeg|thumb|upright|Statue of [[Mohammed Abdullah Hassan|Muhammed Abdullah Hassan]], Leader of the [[Dervish movement ()|Dervishes]]]]The  began local infrastructure projects, including the construction of hospitals, farms and schools. [[Kingdom of #Fascist regime (1922–1943)|Fascist ]], under [[Benito Mussolini]], attacked Abyssinia () in 1935, with an aim to colonise it. The invasion was condemned by the [[League of Nations]], but little was done to stop it or to liberate occupied . In 1936,   was integrated into [[ East Africa]], alongside  and , as the [[ Governorate]]. On 3 August 1940,  troops, including  colonial units, crossed from  to [[ conquest of  Somaliland|invade  Somaliland]], and by 14 August, succeeded in taking [[Berbera]] from the .{{Citation needed|date=October 2021}}

A  force, including troops from several African countries, launched the [[East African Campaign (World War II)|campaign in January 1941]] from  to liberate  Somaliland and -occupied  and conquer  Somaliland. By February most of  Somaliland was captured and, in March,  Somaliland was retaken from the sea. The forces of the  Empire operating in Somaliland comprised the three divisions of , West African, and East African troops. They were assisted by  forces led by Abdulahi Hassan with  of the [[Isaaq]], [[Dhulbahante]], and [[Warsangali]] clans prominently participating. The number of [[ ]] began to decline after World War II, with fewer than 10,000 remaining in 1960.

=== Independence (1960–1969) ===
{{Main|Trust Territory of Somaliland|State of Somaliland| Republic|Greater | Youth League}}

Following World War II, Britain retained control of both [[ Somaliland]] and  Somaliland as protectorates. In 1945, during the [[Potsdam Conference]], the United Nations granted  trusteeship of  Somaliland as the [[Trust Territory of Somaliland]], on the condition first proposed by the  Youth League (SYL) and other nascent  political organisations, such as Hizbia Digil Mirifle  (HDMS) and the  National League (SNL)—that  achieve independence within ten years.  Somaliland remained a protectorate of Britain until 1960.
[[File:Isaaq Chiefs Hargeisa.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Leaders of the [[Isaaq]] clan photographed in [[Hargeisa]] in 1958 during the Duke & Duchess of Gloucester's visit to Somaliland]]

To the extent that [[]] held the territory by UN mandate, the trusteeship provisions gave the  the opportunity to gain experience in Western political education and self-government. These were advantages that  Somaliland, which was to be incorporated into the new  state, did not have. Although in the 1950s  colonial officials attempted, through various administrative development efforts, to make up for past neglect, the protectorate stagnated in political administrative development. The disparity between the two territories in economic development and political experience would later cause serious difficulties integrating the two parts.[[File:Mogadishu city centre - 1960s.jpg|thumb|upright|An avenue in downtown [[Mogadishu]] in 1963]]Meanwhile, in 1948, under pressure from their World War II allies and to the dismay of the , the  returned the [[Haud]] (an important  grazing area that was presumably protected by  treaties with the  in 1884 and 1886) and the [[ Region]] to , based on a treaty they signed in 1897 in which the  ceded  territory to the  Emperor [[Menelek II of |Menelik]] in exchange for his help against possible advances by the .

Britain included the conditional provision that the  residents would retain their autonomy, but  immediately claimed sovereignty over the area. This prompted an unsuccessful bid by Britain in 1956 to buy back the  lands it had turned over. Britain also granted administration of the almost exclusively -inhabited [[Northern Frontier District]] (NFD) to  nationalists. This was despite a [[plebiscite]] in which, according to a  colonial commission, almost all of the territory's ethnic  favoured joining the newly formed  Republic.

A [[ Somaliland overseas territory referendum, 1958|referendum]] was held in neighbouring [[]] (then known as [[ Somaliland]]) in 1958, on the eve of 's independence in 1960, to decide whether or not to join the  Republic or to remain with . The referendum turned out in favour of a continued association with , largely due to a combined yes vote by the sizeable [[Afar people|Afar]] ethnic group and resident Europeans. There was also widespread vote rigging, with the  expelling thousands of  before the referendum reached the polls.

The majority of those who voted 'no' were  who were strongly in favour of joining a united , as had been proposed by [[Mahmoud Harbi]], Vice President of the Government Council. Harbi was killed in a plane crash two years later.  finally gained independence from [[]] in 1977, and [[Hassan Gouled Aptidon]], a  who had campaigned for a 'yes' vote in the referendum of 1976, eventually became 's first president (1977–1999).
[[File:President Aden Adde alongside Prime minister Sharmarke.jpg|thumb|[[Aden Adde|President Aden Adde]] alongside [[Abdirashid Shermarke|Prime Minister Abdirashiid Ali Sharmarke]] praying [[Eid prayers|Eid]] in 1964 at [[Arba'a Rukun Mosque]]]]
The  Somaliland protectorate obtained independence as the [[State of Somaliland]] on 26 June 1960. On 1 July 1960 the Trust Territory of Somaliland gained independence and the two united to form the [[ Republic]], albeit within boundaries drawn up by  and Britain. A government was formed by [[Abdullahi Issa]] and [[Muhammad Haji Ibrahim Egal]] with other members of the trusteeship and protectorate governments, with [[Abdulcadir Muhammed Aden]] as President of the [[Parliament of | National Assembly]], [[Aden Abdullah Osman Daar]] as [[List of Presidents of |President]] of the  Republic, and [[Abdirashid Ali Shermarke]] as [[Prime Minister of |Prime Minister]] (later to become president from 1967 to 1969). On 20 July 1961 and through a [[ constitutional referendum, 1961|popular referendum]], was ratified popularly by the people of  under  trusteeship, Most of the people from the former Somaliland Protectorate did not participate in the referendum, although only a small number of Somalilanders who participated the referendum voted against the [[Constitution of |new constitution]], which was first drafted in 1960. In 1967, Muhammad Haji Ibrahim Egal became Prime Minister, a position to which he was appointed by Shermarke. Egal would later become the President of the autonomous [[Somaliland]] region in northwestern .

===  Democratic Republic (1969–1991) ===
{{Main| Democratic Republic|1969  coup d'état}}

=== Coup d'État ===
On 15 October, while president Abdirashid Ali Sharmarke was touring drought-stricken Las Anood, his personal bodyguard shot and killed him. Former US Secretary of State [[Henry Kissinger]] concluded that the bodyguard was acting of his own accord. Six days later, on 21 October, General [[Siad Barre]] led a military coup and successfully overthrew the parliamentary government. Modern political analysts assert that the coup was motivated by corruption in the parliamentary government.  The bodyguard was tried, tortured and executed by the [[Supreme Revolutionary Council ()|Supreme Revolutionary Council]] (SRC). He came from the same clan background as the president who he killed.
[[File:Mohamed_Ainanshe_and_Kim_Il_Sung_-1970.jpg|right|thumb|[[Mohamed Ainanshe Guled]] in [[]] meeting President [[Kim Il Sung]] 1970]]

Alongside Barre, the SRC that assumed power after President Sharmarke's assassination was led by Brigadier General [[Mohamed Ainanshe Guled]], Lieutenant Colonel [[Salaad Gabeyre Kediye]] and Chief of Police [[Jama Ali Korshel|Jama Korshel]]. Kediye officially held the title "Father of the Revolution", and Barre shortly afterwards became the head of the SRC. The SRC subsequently renamed the country the  Democratic Republic, dissolved the parliament and the Supreme Court, and suspended the constitution.

The revolutionary government established large-scale public works programs and successfully implemented an urban and rural [[literacy]] campaign, which helped dramatically increase the literacy rate. The  Democratic Republic achieved a literacy rate of 70%, one of the highest in Africa at the time.

In addition to a nationalisation program of industry and land, the new regime's foreign policy placed an emphasis on 's traditional and religious links with the [[Arab world]], eventually joining the [[Arab League]] in February 1974. That same year, Barre also served as chairman of the [[Organisation of African Unity]] (OAU), the predecessor of the [[African Union]] (AU).

In July 1976, Barre's SRC disbanded itself and established in its place the [[ Revolutionary Socialist Party]] (SRSP), a one-party government based on [[scientific socialism]] and Islamic tenets. The SRSP was an attempt to reconcile the official state ideology with the official state religion by [[Revisionism (Marxism)|adapting Marxist precepts]] to local circumstances. Emphasis was placed on the Muslim principles of social progress, equality and justice, which the government argued formed the core of scientific socialism and its own accent on self-sufficiency, public participation and popular control, as well as direct ownership of the means of production. While the SRSP encouraged private investment on a limited scale, the administration's overall direction was essentially [[Communism|communist]].

In July 1977, the [[Ogaden War]] broke out after Barre's government used a plea for national unity to justify an [[War of aggression|aggressive]] incorporation of the predominantly -inhabited [[Ogaden]] region of  into a Pan- [[Greater ]], along with the rich agricultural lands of south-eastern , infrastructure, and strategically important areas as far north as . In the first week of the conflict,  armed forces took southern and central Ogaden and for most of the war, the  army scored continuous victories on the  army and followed them as far as [[Sidamo Province|Sidamo]]. By September 1977,  controlled 90% of the Ogaden and captured strategic cities such as [[Jijiga]] and put heavy pressure on [[Dire Dawa]], threatening the train route from the latter city to . After the siege of Harar, a massive unprecedented Soviet intervention consisting of 20,000 [[]]n forces and several thousand Soviet experts came to the aid of 's communist [[Derg]] regime. By 1978, the  troops were ultimately pushed out of the Ogaden. This shift in support by the Soviet Union motivated the Barre government to seek allies elsewhere. It eventually settled on the Soviets' [[Cold War]] arch-rival, the [[]], which had been courting the  government for some time. 's initial friendship with the Soviet Union and later partnership with the  enabled it to build the largest army in Africa.[[File:Muhammad Siad Barre - 40866X9X9.jpg|thumb|Major General [[Mohamed Siad Barre]], Chairman of the [[Supreme Revolutionary Council ()|Supreme Revolutionary Council]], meeting with President of  [[Nicolae Ceauşescu]]]]A new constitution was promulgated in 1979 under which elections for a People's Assembly were held. However, Barre's  Revolutionary Socialist Party [[politburo]] continued to rule. In October 1980, the SRSP was disbanded, and the Supreme Revolutionary Council was reestablished in its place. By that time, Barre's government had become increasingly unpopular. Many  had become disillusioned with life under military dictatorship.

The regime was weakened further in the 1980s as the Cold War drew to a close and 's strategic importance was diminished. The government became increasingly [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]], and [[resistance movement]]s, encouraged by , sprang up across the country, eventually leading to the [[ Civil War]]. Among the militia groups were the [[ Salvation Democratic Front]] (SSDF), [[United  Congress]] (USC), [[ National Movement]] (SNM) and the [[ Patriotic Movement]] (SPM), together with the non-violent political oppositions of the [[ Democratic Movement]] (SDM), the [[Factions in the  Civil War# Democratic Alliance (SDA)| Democratic Alliance]] (SDA) and the  Manifesto Group (SMG).

===  Civil War ===
{{Main| Civil War|History of  (1991–2006)|War in  (2006–2009)| Civil War (2009–present)|Isaaq genocide|Somaliland War of Independence}}

[[File: Civil War (Google Live Map).svg|thumb|250px|

----'''{{flag|}}:'''
{{leftlegend|#ebc0b3|Under control of the [[Federal Government of ]], the [[African Union Support and Stabilization Mission in ]], and the [[]]}}
{{leftlegend|#f0bbf0|Under control of the [[Government of Puntland]]}}
{{leftlegend|#7bd67b|Under control of the [[Jubaland Dervish Force]] and the [[Raskamboni Movement]]}}
---- {{flagicon image|AQMI_Flag_asymmetric.svg}} '''[[Jihadist]] insurgent groups:'''
