 received the western third and subsequently named it -Domingue, the  equivalent of ''[[Captaincy General of Santo Domingo|Santo Domingo]]'', the  colony on [[Hispaniola]]. The  set about creating sugar and coffee plantations, worked by vast numbers of those enslaved imported from [[Africa]], and -Domingue grew to become their richest colonial possession, generating 40% of ’s foreign trade and doubling the wealth generation of all of England’s colonies, combined.

The  settlers were outnumbered by enslaved persons by almost 10 to 1. According to the 1788 Census, 's population consisted of nearly 25,000 Europeans, 22,000 free coloreds and 700,000 Africans in slavery. In contrast, by 1763 the white population of [[New | ]], a far larger territory, had numbered only 65,000. In the north of the island, those enslaved were able to retain many ties to African cultures, religion and language; these ties were continually being renewed by newly imported Africans. Some West Africans in slavery held on to their traditional [[ Vodou|Vodou]] beliefs by secretly syncretizing it with Catholicism.

The  enacted the ''[[Code Noir]]'' ("Black Code"), prepared by [[Jean-Baptiste Colbert]] and ratified by [[Louis XIV]], which established rules on slave treatment and permissible freedoms. -Domingue has been described as one of the most brutally efficient slave colonies; at the end of the eighteenth century it was supplying two-thirds of Europe's tropical produce while one-third of newly imported Africans died within a few years. Many enslaved persons died from diseases such as [[smallpox]] and [[typhoid fever]]. They had low [[birth rate]]s, and there is evidence that some women [[abortion|aborted]] fetuses rather than give birth to children within the bonds of [[slavery]]. The colony's environment also suffered, as forests were cleared to make way for plantations and the land was overworked so as to extract maximum profit for  plantation owners.

[[File:Fire in -Domingo 1791,  copper engraving.jpg|thumb|-Domingue [[Slave rebellion|slave revolt]] in 1791]]
As in its [[Louisiana (New )|Louisiana colony]], the [[New | colonial]] government allowed some rights to [[free people of color]] ({{Lang|fr|gens de couleur}}), the [[mixed-race]] descendants of European male colonists and African enslaved females (and later, mixed-race women). Over time, many were released from slavery and they established a separate [[social class]]. White  [[Creole peoples|Creole]] fathers frequently sent their mixed-race sons to [[]] for their education. Some men of color were admitted into the military. More of the free people of color lived in the south of the island, near [[Port-au-Prince]], and many intermarried within their community. They frequently worked as artisans and tradesmen, and began to own some property, including enslaved persons of their own. The free people of color petitioned the [[New |colonial]] government to expand their rights.

The brutality of slave life led many people in bondage to escape to mountainous regions, where they set up their own autonomous communities and became known as [[ Maroon|maroons]]. One maroon leader, [[François Mackandal]], led a rebellion in the 1750s; however, he was later captured and executed by the .

==== Revolution (1791–1804)====
{{Main| Revolution}}
[[File:Général Toussaint Louverture.jpg|thumb|upright|General Toussaint Louverture]]
Inspired by the [[ Revolution]] of 1789 and principles of the [[rights of man]], the  settlers and free people of color pressed for greater political freedom and more [[civil rights]]. Tensions between these two groups led to conflict, as a militia of free-coloreds was set up in 1790 by [[ Ogé]], resulting in his capture, torture and execution. Sensing an opportunity, in August 1791 the first slave armies were established in northern  under the leadership of [[Toussaint Louverture]] inspired by the Vodou ''houngan'' (priest) Boukman, and backed by the  in Santo Domingo – soon a full-blown slave rebellion had broken out across the entire colony.

In 1792, the [[ First Republic|]] government sent three commissioners with troops to re-establish control; to build an alliance with the ''[[gens de couleur]]'' and enslaved persons commissioners [[Léger-Félicité Sonthonax]] and [[Étienne Polverel]] abolished slavery in the colony. Six months later, the [[National Convention]], led by [[Maximilien de Robespierre]] and the [[Jacobin Club|Jacobins]], endorsed [[abolition of slavery timeline|abolition]] and extended it to all the  colonies.

The [[]], which was a new republic itself, oscillated between supporting or not supporting [[Toussaint Louverture]] and the emerging country of , depending on who was President of the US. Washington, who was a slave holder and isolationist, kept the  neutral, although private US citizens at times provided aid to  [[Planter (plantation owner)|planters]] trying to put down the revolt. [[John Adams]], a vocal opponent of slavery, fully supported the slave revolt by providing diplomatic recognition, financial support, munitions and warships (including the [[USS Constitution]]) beginning in 1798. This support ended in 1801 when Jefferson, another slave-holding president, took office and recalled the US Navy.

With slavery abolished, Toussaint Louverture pledged allegiance to , and he fought off the  and  forces who had taken advantage of the situation and invaded -Domingue. The  were later forced to cede their part of the island to  under the terms of the [[Peace of Basel]] in 1795, uniting the island under one government. However, an insurgency against  rule broke out in the east, and in the west there was fighting between Louverture's forces and the free people of color led by [[André Rigaud]] in the [[War of the Knives]] (1799–1800). The ' support for the blacks in the war contributed to their victory over the mulattoes. More than 25,000 whites and free blacks left the island as refugees.

[[File:Battle for Palm Tree Hill.jpg|thumb|Battle between [[ Legions (Napoleonic period)| troops]] in  service and the [[ Revolution| rebels]]. The majority of  soldiers eventually deserted the  army and fought alongside the .]]
After Louverture created a separatist constitution and proclaimed himself governor-general for life, [[Napoléon Bonaparte]] in 1802 sent an [[-Domingue expedition|expedition]] of 20,000 soldiers and as many sailors under the command of his brother-in-law, [[Charles Leclerc (general, born 1772)|Charles Leclerc]], to reassert  control. The  achieved some victories, but within a few months most of their [[ Army|army]] had died from [[yellow fever]]. Ultimately more than 50,000  troops died in an attempt to retake the colony, including 18 generals. The  managed to capture Louverture, transporting him to  for trial. He was imprisoned at [[Fort de Joux]], where he died in 1803 of exposure and possibly [[tuberculosis]].
[[File:Revenge taken by the Black Army for the Cruelties practised on them by the .png|thumb| hanging  soldiers]]
The enslaved persons, along with free {{Lang|fr|gens de couleur}} and allies, continued their fight for independence, led by generals [[Jean-Jacques Dessalines]], [[Alexandre Pétion]] and [[Henry Christophe]]. The rebels finally managed to decisively defeat the  troops at the [[Battle of Vertières]] on 18 November 1803, establishing the first state ever to successfully gain independence through a slave revolt. Under the overall command of Dessalines, the  armies avoided open battle, and instead conducted a successful guerrilla campaign against the Napoleonic forces, working with diseases such as yellow fever to reduce the numbers of  soldiers. Later that year  withdrew its remaining 7,000 troops from the island and Napoleon gave up his idea of re-establishing a North  empire, selling [[Louisiana (New )]] to the [[]], in the [[Louisiana Purchase]].

Throughout the revolution, an estimated 20,000  troops succumbed to yellow fever, while another 37,000 were [[killed in action]], exceeding the total  soldiers killed in action across various 19th-century colonial campaigns in , , Indochina, , and West Africa, which resulted in approximately 10,000  soldiers killed in action combined. The  sustained 45,000 dead. Additionally, 200,000  died. In the process, Dessalines became arguably the most successful military commander in the struggle against Napoleonic .

===Independent ===
====First Empire (1804–1806)====
{{main|First Empire of |1804  massacre}}
[[File:Le Serment des Ancêtres, 1823.jpg|thumb|Pétion and Dessalines swearing allegiance to each other before God; painting by [[Guillaume Guillon-Lethière|Guillon-Lethière]]]]

The independence of -Domingue was proclaimed under the native name '' by [[Jean-Jacques Dessalines]] on 1 January 1804 in [[Gonaïves]] and he was proclaimed "Emperor for Life" as Emperor Jacques I by his troops. Dessalines at first offered protection to the white planters and others. However, once in power, he ordered the [[1804  Massacre|genocide]] of nearly all the remaining whites; between January and April 1804, 3,000 to 5,000 whites were killed, including those who had been friendly and sympathetic to the black population. Only [[1804  massacre#Aftermath|three categories of white people]] were selected out as exceptions and spared: [[ |]] soldiers, some of whom had deserted from the  army and fought alongside the  rebels; the small group of [[ |]] colonists invited to the [[Nord-Ouest (department)|north-west region]]; and a group of [[Doctor of Medicine|medical doctors]] and professionals. Reportedly, people with connections to officers in the  army were also spared, as well as the women who agreed to marry non-white men.

Fearful of the potential impact the slave rebellion could have in the [[slave states]], U.S. President [[Thomas Jefferson]] refused to recognize the new republic. The Southern politicians who were a powerful voting bloc in the  Congress prevented U.S. recognition for decades until they withdrew in 1861 to form the [[Confederate States of America|Confederacy]].

The revolution led to a wave of emigration. In 1809, 9,000 refugees from -Domingue, both white planters and people of color, settled ''en masse'' in [[New Orleans]], doubling the city's population, having been expelled from their initial refuge in  by  authorities. In addition, the newly arrived enslaved persons added to the city's African population.

The plantation system was re-established in , albeit for wages; however, many  were marginalized and resented the heavy-handed manner in which this was enforced in the new nation's politics. The rebel movement splintered, and Dessalines was assassinated by rivals on 17 October 1806.{{Deep link needed|date=March 2023}}

====State of , Kingdom of  and the Republic (1806–1820)====
{{main|State of |Kingdom of }}
[[File:Citadelle Laferrière Aerial View.jpg|thumb|left|[[Citadelle Laferrière]], built 1805–1822, is the largest [[fortress]] in the Americas, and is considered locally to be an [[eighth wonder of the world]].]]
After Dessalines' death  became split into two, with the [[Kingdom of ]] in the north directed by Henri Christophe, later declaring himself [[Henri Christophe|Henri I]], and a republic in the south centered on [[Port-au-Prince]], directed by [[Alexandre Pétion]], an ''homme de couleur''. Pétion's republic was less absolutist, and he initiated a series of land reforms which benefited the peasant class. President Pétion also gave military and financial assistance to the revolutionary leader [[Simón Bolívar]], which were critical in enabling him to liberate the [[Viceroyalty of New Granada]]. Meanwhile, the , who had managed to maintain a precarious control of eastern Hispaniola, were [[ reconquest of Santo Domingo|defeated]] by insurgents led by [[Juan Sánchez Ramírez]], with the area returning to  rule in 1809 following the [[Battle of Palo Hincado]].

====Unification of Hispaniola (1821–1844)====
{{main|Republic of  (1820–1849)| occupation of Santo Domingo}}
[[File:President Jean-Pierre Boyer of  (Hispaniola Unification Regime) Portrait.jpg|thumb|Jean-Pierre Boyer, ruler of  1818–1843]]
Beginning in 1821, President [[Jean-Pierre Boyer]], also an ''homme de couleur'' and successor to Pétion, reunified the island following the suicide of Henry Christophe. After [[Republic of  |Santo Domingo]] declared its independence from  on 30 November 1821, Boyer invaded, seeking to [[Unification of Hispaniola|unite the entire island]] by force and ending slavery in Santo Domingo.

Struggling to revive the agricultural economy to produce [[commodity crops]], Boyer passed the Code Rural, which denied peasant laborers the right to leave the land, enter the towns, or start farms or shops of their own, causing much resentment as most peasants wished to have their own farms rather than work on plantations.

Starting in September 1824, more than 6,000 [[African ]] migrated to , with transportation paid by an  philanthropic group similar in function to the [[ Colonization Society]] and its efforts in [[]].{{Better source needed|reason=The current source is insufficiently reliable ([[WP:NOTRS]]).|date=August 2025}} Many found the conditions too harsh and returned to the .{{Citation needed|date=June 2024}}

In July 1825, [[Charles X of |King Charles X]] of [[]], during a period of restoration of the [[ monarchy]], sent a [[ Navy|fleet]] to reconquer . Under pressure, President Boyer agreed to a treaty by which  formally recognized the independence of the state in exchange for [[ indemnity controversy|a payment]] of 150 million [[francs]], or $560 million in today's dollars. By an order of 17 April 1826, the King of  renounced his rights of sovereignty and formally recognized the independence of . The enforced payments to  hampered 's economic growth for years, exacerbated by the fact that many [[Western world|Western]] states continued to refuse formal [[Diplomacy|diplomatic]] recognition to ; Britain recognized  independence in 1833, and the  not until 1862.  borrowed heavily from Western banks at extremely high interest rates to repay the debt, an amount estimated to be between $21 billion and $115 billion in lost economic growth over time, or as much as eight times the size of 's economy in 2020. Although the amount of the reparations was reduced to 90 million in 1838, by 1900 80% of 's government spending was debt repayment and the country did not finish repaying it until 1947.

====Loss of the eastern portion of the island====
{{main| War of Independence}}
After losing the support of 's elite, Boyer was ousted in 1843, with [[Charles Rivière-Hérard]] replacing him as president. Nationalist  forces in eastern Hispaniola led by [[Juan Pablo Duarte]] seized control of Santo Domingo on 27 February 1844. The  forces, unprepared for a significant uprising, capitulated to the rebels, effectively ending  rule of eastern Hispaniola. In March, Rivière-Hérard attempted to reimpose his authority, but the [[|]] inflicted heavy losses. Rivière-Hérard was removed from office by the mulatto hierarchy and replaced with the aged general [[Philippe Guerrier]], who assumed the presidency on 3 May 1844.

Guerrier died in April 1845, and was succeeded by General [[Jean-Louis Pierrot]]. Pierrot's most pressing duty as the new president was to check the incursions of the , who were harassing the  troops.  gunboats were also making depredations on 's coasts. President Pierrot decided to open a campaign against the , whom he considered merely as insurgents; however, the  offensive of 1845 was stopped on the frontier.

On 1 January 1846, Pierrot announced a fresh campaign to reimpose  suzerainty over eastern Hispaniola, but his officers and men greeted this fresh summons with contempt. Thus, a month later – February 1846 – when Pierrot ordered his troops to march against the , the  army mutinied, and its soldiers proclaimed his overthrow as president of the republic. With the war against the  having become very unpopular in , it was beyond the power of the new president, General [[Jean-Baptiste Riché]], to stage another invasion.

====Second Empire (1849–1859)====
{{main|Second Empire of }}
[[File:Faustin I.jpg|thumb|Faustin I, from ''[[The Illustrated London News]]'', 16 February 1856]]
On 27 February 1847, President Riché died after only a year in power and was replaced by an obscure officer, General [[Faustin Soulouque]]. During the first two years of Soulouque's administration the conspiracies and opposition he faced in retaining power were so manifold that the  were given a further breathing space in which to consolidate their independence. But, when in 1848  finally recognized the  as a free and independent state and provisionally signed a treaty of peace, friendship, commerce and navigation,  immediately protested, claiming the treaty was an attack upon their own security. Soulouque decided to invade the new Republic before the  Government could ratify the treaty.

On 21 March 1849,  soldiers attacked the  garrison at [[Las Matas de Farfán|Las Matas]]. The demoralized defenders offered almost no resistance before abandoning their weapons. Soulouque pressed on, capturing [[San Juan Province ()|San Juan]]. This left only the town of [[Azua, |Azua]] as the remaining  stronghold between the  army and the capital. On 6 April, Azua fell to the 18,000-strong  army, with a 5,000-man  counterattack failing to oust them. The way to [[Santo Domingo]] was now clear. But the news of discontent existing at Port-au-Prince, which reached Soulouque, arrested his further progress and caused him to return with the army to his capital.

Emboldened by the sudden retreat of the  army, the  counter-attacked. Their flotilla went as far as [[Dame-Marie, Grand'Anse|Dame-Marie]] on the west coast of , which they plundered and set on fire. After another  campaign in 1855, Britain and  intervened and obtained an armistice on behalf of the , who declared independence as the .

The sufferings endured by the soldiers during the campaign of 1855, and the losses and sacrifices inflicted on the country without yielding any compensation or any practical results provoked great discontent. In 1858 a revolution began, led by General [[Fabre Geffrard]], Duke of Tabara. In December of that year, Geffrard defeated the Imperial Army and seized control of most of the country. As a result, the Emperor abdicated his throne on 15 January 1859. Faustin was taken into exile and General Geffrard succeeded him as president.

====Late 19th century–early 20th century====
[[File:Luders Affair, , .jpg|thumb| Captain Thiele of the ''Charlotte'' handing over the  Ultimatum on 6 December 1897 during the Lüders Affair]]
The period following Soulouque's overthrow down to the turn of the century was a turbulent one for , with repeated bouts of political instability. President Geffrard was overthrown in a coup in 1867, as was his successor, [[Sylvain Salnave]], in 1869. Under the Presidency of [[Michel Domingue]] (1874–76) relations with the  were dramatically improved by the signing of a treaty, in which both parties acknowledged the independence of the other. Some modernisation of the economy and infrastructure also occurred in this period, especially under the Presidencies of [[Lysius Salomon]] (1879–1888) and [[Florvil Hyppolite]] (1889–1896).

's relations with outside powers were often strained. In 1889 the  attempted to [[Môle -Nicolas affair|force ]] to permit the building of a naval base at [[Môle -Nicolas]], which was firmly resisted by President Hyppolite. In 1892 the [[ Empire| government]] supported suppression of the reform movement of [[Anténor Firmin]], and in 1897, the  used [[gunboat diplomacy]] to intimidate and then humiliate the  government of President [[Tirésias Simon Sam]] (1896–1902) during the [[Lüders Affair]].

In the first decades of the 20th century,  experienced great political instability and was heavily in debt to ,  and the . A series of short lived presidencies came and went: President [[Pierre Nord Alexis]] was forced from power in 1908, as was his successor [[François C. Antoine Simon]] in 1911; President [[Cincinnatus Leconte]] (1911–12) was killed in a (possibly deliberate) explosion at the National Palace; [[Michel Oreste]] (1913–14) was ousted in a coup, as was his successor [[Oreste Zamor]] in 1914.

==== occupation (1915–1934)====
{{main| occupation of }}
[[File:U.S. Marines and guide in search of bandits. , circa 1919., 1927 - 1981 - NARA - 532584 (cropped).tif|thumb|left|U.S. Marines and guide in search of  [[Cacos (military group)|Cacos]] fighters against the [[ occupation of |U.S. occupation of ]], {{circa|1919}}]]

 increased its influence in  in this period, with a small community of  settlers wielding disproportionate influence in 's economy. The  influence prompted anxieties in the , who had also invested heavily in the country, and whose government defended their right to oppose foreign interference in the Americas under the [[Monroe Doctrine]]. In December 1914, the  removed $500,000 from the  National Bank, but rather than seize it to help pay the debt, it was removed for safe-keeping in New York, thus giving the  control of the bank and preventing other powers from doing so. This gave a stable financial base on which to build the economy, and to enable the debt to be repaid.

In 1915, 's new President [[Vilbrun Guillaume Sam]] sought to strengthen his tenuous rule by a mass execution of 167 political prisoners. Outrage at the killings led to riots, and Sam was captured and killed by a lynch mob. Fearing possible foreign intervention, or the emergence of a new government led by the anti-  politician [[Rosalvo Bobo]], President [[Woodrow Wilson]] sent U.S. Marines into  in July 1915. The {{USS|Washington|ACR-11|6}}, under Rear Admiral [[William Banks Caperton|Caperton]], arrived in Port-au-Prince in an attempt to restore order and protect U.S. interests. Within days, the Marines had taken control of the capital city and its banks and customs house. The Marines declared martial law and severely censored the press. Within weeks, a new pro-U.S.  president, [[Philippe Sudré Dartiguenave]], was installed and a new constitution written that was favorable to the interests of the . The constitution (written by future US President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]]) included a clause that allowed, for the first time, foreign ownership of land in , which was bitterly opposed by the  legislature and citizenry.

[[File:Corps de Charlemagne Péralte.jpg|thumb|right|175px|The body of caco leader Charlemagne Péralte on display after his execution by US forces; the image was counterproductive, with the resemblance to the [[Descent from the Cross|deposition of Jesus]] gaining Péralte the status of national martyr.]]
The occupation improved some of 's [[infrastructure]] and centralized power in Port-au-Prince. 1700&nbsp;km of roads were made usable, 189 bridges were built, many irrigation canals were rehabilitated, hospitals, schools, and public buildings were constructed, and drinking water was brought to the main cities.{{Citation needed|date=September 2019}} Agricultural education was organized, with a central school of agriculture and 69 farms in the country.{{sfn|Heinl|1996|pp=454–455}}{{incomplete short citation|date=February 2023}} However, many infrastructure projects were built using the [[corvée]] system that allowed the government/occupying forces to take people from their homes and farms, at gunpoint if necessary, to build roads, bridges etc. by force, a process that was deeply resented by ordinary . [[Sisal]] was also introduced to , and sugarcane and [[cotton]] became significant exports, boosting prosperity.  traditionalists, based in rural areas, were highly resistant to U.S.-backed changes, while the urban elites, typically mixed-race, welcomed the growing economy, but wanted more political control. Together they helped secure an end to the occupation in 1934, under the Presidency of [[Sténio ]] (1930–1941). The debts were still outstanding, though less due to increased prosperity, and the U.S. financial advisor-general receiver handled the budget until 1941.

The U.S. Marines were instilled with a special brand of paternalism towards  "expressed in the metaphor of a father's relationship with his children." Armed opposition to the US presence was led by the [[Cacos (military group)|cacos]] under the command of [[Charlemagne Péralte]]; his capture and execution in 1919 earned him the status of a national martyr. During Senate hearings in 1921, the commandant of the Marine Corps reported that, in the 20 months of active unrest, 2,250  had been killed. However, in a report to the Secretary of the Navy, he reported the death toll as being 3,250.  historians have claimed the true number was much higher, but this is not supported by most historians outside .

====Post-occupation era (1934–1957)====
After U.S. forces left in 1934,  dictator [[Rafael Trujillo]] used [[Antihaitianismo|anti-]] sentiment as a nationalist tool. In 1937, in an event that became known as the [[Parsley massacre|Parsley Massacre]], he ordered his army to kill  living on the  side of the border. Few bullets were used; instead, 20,000–30,000  were bludgeoned and bayoneted, then herded into the sea, where sharks finished what Trujillo had begun. The indiscriminate massacre occurred over a period of five days and involved hundreds of  troops.

 President [[Sténio |]], under U.S. pressure owing to his increasingly dictatorial actions, resigned in 1941 and was replaced by [[Élie Lescot]] (1941–46). In 1941, during the [[Second World War]], Lescot declared war on [[Empire of |]] (8 December), [[Nazi |]] (12 December), [[Kingdom of |]] (12 December), [[Kingdom of |]] (24 December), [[Kingdom of  (1920-46)|]] (24 December) and [[Kingdom of |]] (24 December). Out of these six [[Axis Powers|Axis]] countries, only  reciprocated, declaring war on  on the same day (24 December 1941). On 27 September 1945,  became a [[member states of the United Nations|founding member]] of the [[United Nations]] (the successor to the [[Member states of the League of Nations|League of Nations]], of which  was also a founding member).

In 1946, Lescot was overthrown by the military, with [[Dumarsais Estimé]] later becoming the new president (1946–50). Estimé sought to improve the economy and education, and to boost the role of black ; however, as he sought to consolidate his rule he too was overthrown in a coup led by [[Paul Magloire]], who replaced him as president (1950–56). Firmly anti-Communist, he was supported by the ; with greater political stability tourists started to visit . The waterfront area of Port-au-Prince was redeveloped to allow cruise ship passengers to walk to cultural attractions.

====Duvalier dynasty (1957–1986)====
{{main|Duvalier dynasty}}
[[File:Duvalier crop2.jpg|thumb|upright|"Papa Doc" [[François Duvalier|Duvalier]] in 1968]]
In 1956–57  underwent severe political turmoil; Magloire was forced to resign and leave the country in 1956 and he was followed by four short-lived presidencies. In the [[ presidential election, 1957|September 1957 election]] [[François Duvalier]] was elected President of . Known as 'Papa Doc' and initially popular, Duvalier remained President until his death in 1971. He advanced black interests in the public sector, where over time, people of color had predominated as the educated urban elite. Not trusting the army, despite his frequent purges of officers deemed disloyal, Duvalier created a private militia known as ''[[Tonton Macoute|Tontons Macoutes]]'' ("Bogeymen"), which maintained order by terrorizing the populace and political opponents. In 1964 Duvalier proclaimed himself 'President for Life'; [[Jérémie Vespers|an uprising]] against his rule that year in [[Jérémie]] was violently suppressed, with the ringleaders publicly executed and hundreds of mixed-raced citizens in the town killed. The bulk of the educated and professional class began leaving the country, and corruption became widespread. Duvalier sought to create a personality cult, identifying himself with [[Baron Samedi]], one of the [[loa]] (or ''lwa''), or spirits, of [[ Vodou]]. Despite the well-publicized abuses under his rule, Duvalier's firm anti-Communism earned him the support of the , who furnished the country with aid.

In 1971, Duvalier died, and he was succeeded by his son [[Jean-Claude Duvalier]], nicknamed 'Baby Doc', who ruled until 1986. He largely continued his father's policies, though curbed some of the worst excesses in order to court international respectability. Tourism, which had nosedived in Papa Doc's time, again became a growing industry. However, as the economy continued to decline, Baby Doc's grip on power began to weaken. 's pig population was slaughtered following an outbreak of swine fever in the late 1970s, causing hardship to rural communities who used them as an investment. The opposition became more vocal, bolstered by a visit to the country by [[Pope John Paul II]] in 1983, who publicly lambasted the president. Demonstrations occurred in Gonaïves in 1985 which then spread across the country; under pressure from the , Duvalier left the country in February 1986.

In total, roughly 40,000 to 60,000  are estimated to have been killed during the reign of the Duvaliers. Through the use of his intimidation tactics and executions, many intellectual  had fled, leaving the country with a massive brain-drain from which it has yet to recover.

====Post-Duvalier era (1986–2004)====
[[File:DD-SD-99-03743.jpg|thumb|[[Jean-Bertrand Aristide]] returns to  following the [[Operation Uphold Democracy|U.S.-led invasion]] in 1994 designed to remove the [[Raoul Cédras|regime]] installed by the [[1991  coup d'état]]]]
Following Duvalier's departure, army leader General [[Henri Namphy]] headed a new [[National Council of Government ()|National Governing Council]]. [[ presidential election, 1987|Elections]] scheduled for November 1987 were aborted after dozens of inhabitants were shot in the capital by soldiers and ''Tontons Macoutes''. Fraudulent [[ presidential election, 1988|elections followed]] in 1988, in which only 4% of the citizenry voted. The newly elected president, [[Leslie Manigat]], was then overthrown some months later in the [[June 1988  coup d'état]].

Another [[September 1988  coup d'état|coup followed]] in September 1988, after the [[St. Jean Bosco massacre]] in which approximately 13 to 50 people were killed while attending a mass led by prominent government critic and [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] priest [[Jean-Bertrand Aristide]]. General [[Prosper Avril]] subsequently led a military regime until March 1990.

Avril transferred power to the army chief of staff, General [[Hérard Abraham]], on 10 March 1990. Abraham gave up power three days later, becoming the only military leader in  during the twentieth century to voluntarily give up power. Abraham later helped to secure the [[1990–91  general election]].

In December 1990, Jean-Bertrand Aristide was elected president in the [[ general election, 1990–91| general election]]. However, his ambitious reformist agenda worried the elites, and in September of the following year he was overthrown by the military, led by [[Raoul Cédras]], in the [[1991  coup d'état]]. Amidst the continuing turmoil many  attempted to flee the country.

In September 1994, the  negotiated the departure of 's military leaders and the peaceful entry of 20,000 US troops under [[Operation Uphold Democracy]]. This enabled the restoration of the democratically elected Jean-Bertrand Aristide as president, who returned to  in October to complete his term. As part of the deal Aristide had to implement free market reforms in an attempt to improve the  economy, with mixed results. In November 1994, [[Hurricane Gordon (1994)|Hurricane Gordon]] brushed , dumping heavy rain and creating [[flash flood]]ing that triggered mudslides. Gordon killed an estimated 1,122 people, although some estimates go as high as 2,200.

[[1995  general election|Elections]] were held in 1995 which were won by [[René Préval]], gaining 88% of the popular vote, albeit on a low turnout. Aristide subsequently formed his own party, [[Fanmi Lavalas]], and political deadlock ensued; the [[ presidential election, 2000|November 2000 election]] returned Aristide to the presidency with 92% of the vote. The election had been boycotted by the opposition, then organized into the [[Convergence Démocratique]], over a dispute in the [[ legislative election, 2000|May legislative elections]]. In subsequent years, there was increasing violence between rival political factions and [[human rights abuse]]s. Aristide spent years negotiating with the Convergence Démocratique on new elections, but the Convergence's inability to develop a sufficient electoral base made elections unattractive.{{citation needed|date=September 2019}}

In 2004, [[2004  coup d'état|an anti-Aristide revolt began]] in northern . The rebellion eventually reached the capital, and Aristide was forced into exile. The precise nature of the events are disputed; some, including Aristide and his bodyguard, Franz Gabriel, stated that he was the victim of a "new [[coup d'état]] or modern kidnapping" by U.S. forces. These charges were denied by the US government. As political violence and crime continued to grow, a [[United Nations Stabilisation Mission in |United Nations Stabilisation Mission (MINUSTAH)]] was brought in to maintain order. However, MINUSTAH proved controversial, since their periodically heavy-handed approach to maintaining law and order and several instances of abuses, including the alleged sexual abuse of civilians, provoked resentment and distrust among ordinary .

[[Boniface Alexandre]] assumed interim authority until 2006, when René Préval was re-elected President following [[ general election, 2006|elections]] with 55% voter turnout.

====Post-Aristide era (2004–present)====
{{See also| crisis (2018–present)}}
Amidst the continuing political chaos, a series of natural disasters hit . In 2004, [[Hurricane Jeanne#|Tropical Storm Jeanne]] skimmed the north coast, leaving 3,006 people dead in flooding and [[mudslide]]s, mostly in the city of [[Gonaïves]]. In 2008,  was again struck by tropical storms; [[Tropical Storm Fay (2008)|Tropical Storm Fay]], [[Hurricane Gustav]], [[Hurricane Hanna (2008)|Hurricane Hanna]] and [[Hurricane Ike]] all produced heavy winds and rain, resulting in 331 deaths and about 800,000 in need of humanitarian aid. The state of affairs produced by these storms was intensified by already high food and fuel prices that had caused a food crisis and political unrest in April 2008.

[[File: national palace earthquake.jpg|thumb|upright=1.6|The [[National Palace ()| National Palace]], located in Port-au-Prince, , heavily damaged after the [[2010  earthquake|earthquake of 2010]]. This was originally a two-story structure; the second story completely collapsed.]]

On 12 January 2010, at 4:53pm local time,  was struck by a [[moment magnitude scale|magnitude]]-7.0 [[2010  earthquake|earthquake]]. This was the country's most severe earthquake in over 200 years. The earthquake was reported to have left between 160,000 and 300,000 people dead and up to 1.6 million homeless, making it one of the [[List of natural disasters by death toll|deadliest natural disasters ever recorded]]. An estimated 80% of schools, more than half of 's hospitals were destroyed or damaged. It is also one of the deadliest earthquakes ever recorded. The situation was exacerbated by a subsequent massive [[ cholera outbreak|cholera outbreak]] that was triggered when cholera-infected waste from a [[United Nations]] peacekeeping station contaminated the country's main river, the [[Artibonite River|Artibonite]]. In 2017, it was reported that roughly 10,000  had died and nearly a million had been made ill. After years of denial, the United Nations apologized in 2016, but {{as of|2017|lc=y}}, they have refused to acknowledge fault, thus avoiding financial responsibility.

General elections had been planned for January 2010 but were postponed due to the earthquake. [[2010–11  general election|Elections were held on 28 November 2010]] for the senate, the parliament and the first round of the presidential elections. The run-off between [[Michel Martelly]] and [[Mirlande Manigat]] took place on 20 March 2011, and preliminary results, released on 4 April, named Michel Martelly the winner. In 2011, both former dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier and Jean-Bertrand Aristide returned to ; attempts to try Duvalier for crimes committed under his rule were shelved following his death in 2014. In 2013, the  government called for European governments to pay [[reparations for slavery]] and establish an official commission for the settlement of past wrongdoings. Meanwhile, after continuing political wrangling with the opposition and allegations of electoral fraud, Martelly agreed to step down in 2016 without a successor in place. After numerous postponements, partly owing to the effects of devastating [[Hurricane Matthew]], [[November 2016  presidential election|elections]] were held in November 2016 with a record low voter turnout of just 17%. The victor, [[Jovenel Moïse]] of the [[ Tèt Kale Party]], was sworn in as president in 2017. [[ crisis (2018–present)|Protests began]] on 7 July 2018, in response to increased fuel prices. Over time these protests evolved into demands for the resignation of president Moïse.

On 7 July 2021, President Moïse was [[Assassination of Jovenel Moïse|assassinated]] in an attack on his private residence, and First Lady [[Martine Moïse]] was hospitalized. Amid the political crisis, the government of  installed [[Ariel Henry]] as the acting prime minister on 20 July 2021. On 14 August 2021,  suffered [[2021  earthquake|another huge earthquake]], with many casualties. The earthquake also damaged 's economic conditions and led to a rise in [[Gang|gang violence]] which, by September 2021, had escalated to a long-lasting full-blown [[Gang war in |gang war]] and other violent crimes within the country. As of March 2022,  still had no president, no parliamentary quorum, and a dysfunctional high court due to a lack of judges. In 2022, [[2022  crisis|protests]] against the government and [[Global energy crisis (2021–present)|rising fuel prices]] intensified.

By the end of 2023, gangs and armed groups controlled an estimated 80% of the capital, Port-au-Prince. During 2023, gangs killed 4,789 people, kidnapped 2,490 more and displaced an estimated 362,000 from their homes (mostly in Port-au-Prince). Doctors, lawyers, and other wealthy members of society were kidnapped and held for ransom. Many victims were killed when ransom demands were not met, leading those with the means to do so to flee the country, further hampering efforts to pull the country out of the crisis. It is estimated that amidst the crisis up to 20% of qualified medical staff had left  by the end of 2023.

In March 2024, Ariel Henry was prevented by gangs from returning to , following a visit to [[]]. Henry agreed to resign once a transitional government had been formed. As of that month, nearly half of 's population was living under [[Hunger|acute food insecurity]], according to the [[World Food Programme]]. On 25 April 2024, the [[Transitional Presidential Council]] took over the Governance of  and is scheduled to stay in power until 2026.  [[Michel Patrick Boisvert]] was named interim prime minister. On 3 June 2024, the council swore in [[Garry Conille]] as acting prime minister. On 10 November 2024, [[Alix Didier Fils-Aimé]] replaced Conille as acting prime minister.
==History==
{{Main|History of |Timeline of  history}}
[[File:Choirokoitia.jpg|thumb|Archaeological site of [[Khirokitia]] with early remains of human habitation during the Aceramic Neolithic period (reconstruction)]]

===Prehistoric and ancient period===
{{Main|Prehistoric |Ancient history of }}

Hunter-gatherers first arrived on  around 13–12,000 years ago (11,000 to 10,000 BC), based on dating of sites like [[Aetokremnos]] on the south coast and the inland site of Vretsia Roudias. The arrival of the first humans coincides with the extinction of the {{Convert|75|cm|ft|abbr=on}} high [[ pygmy hippopotamus]] and {{Convert|1|m}} tall [[ Dwarf Elephant| dwarf elephant]], the only large mammals native to the island. [[Neolithic]] farming communities emerged on the island by around 10,500 years ago (8500 BC).

Remains of an eight-month-old cat were discovered buried with a human body at a separate [[Neolithic]] site in . The grave is estimated to be 9,500 years old (7500&nbsp;BC), predating [[ancient ]]ian civilisation and pushing back the [[Domestication of the cat|earliest known feline-human association]] significantly. The remarkably well-preserved Neolithic village of [[Khirokitia]] is a UNESCO [[World Heritage Site]], dating to approximately 6800&nbsp;BC.

During the Late [[Bronze Age]], from around 1650 BC  (identified in whole or part as [[Alashiya]] in contemporary texts) became more connected to the wider Mediterranean world driven by the trade in [[copper]] extracted from the Troodos Mountains, which stimulated the development of urbanised settlements across the island, with records suggesting that  at this time was ruled by "kings" who corresponded with the leaders of other Mediterranean states (like the [[pharaoh]]s of the [[New Kingdom of ]], as documented in the [[Amarna letters]]). The first recorded name of a  king is ''Kushmeshusha'', as appears on letters sent to [[Ugarit]] in the 13th&nbsp;century&nbsp;BC.

At the end of the Bronze Age, the island experienced two waves of  settlement. The first wave consisted of [[Mycenaean |Mycenaean ]] traders, who started visiting  around 1400&nbsp;BC. A major wave of  settlement is believed to have taken place following the [[Late Bronze Age collapse]] of Mycenaean  from 1100 to 1050&nbsp;BC, with the island's predominantly  character dating from this period.   occupies an important role in [[ mythology]], being the birthplace of [[Aphrodite]] and [[Adonis]], and home to [[Cinyras|King Cinyras]], [[Teucer]] and [[Pygmalion (mythology)|Pygmalion]]. Literary evidence suggests an early Phoenician presence at [[Kition]], which was under [[Tyre, |Tyrian]] rule at the beginning of the 10th century BC. Some [[Phoenicia]]n merchants who were believed to come from [[Tyre, |Tyre]] [[colony|colonised]] the area and expanded the political influence of Kition. After c.&nbsp;850&nbsp;BC, the Phoenicians rebuilt and reused the sanctuaries [at the Kathari site].[[File:Kition, Zeus Keraunios.jpg|thumb|upright|Zeus Keraunios, 500–480 BC, Nicosia museum]]

 is at a strategic location in the Eastern Mediterranean. It was ruled by the [[Neo-Assyrian Empire]] for a century starting in 708&nbsp;BC, before a brief spell under  rule and eventually [[Achaemenid Empire|Achaemenid]] rule in 545&nbsp;BC. The , led by [[Onesilus]], king of Salamis, joined their fellow  in the [[Ionia]]n cities during the unsuccessful [[Ionian Revolt]] in 499&nbsp;BC against the Achaemenids. The revolt was suppressed, but  managed to maintain a high degree of autonomy and remained inclined towards the  world. 
During the whole period of the Persian rule, there is a continuity in the reign of the  kings and during their rebellions they were crushed by Persian rulers from Asia Minor, which is an indication that the  were ruling the island with directly regulated relations with the Great King and there was not a Persian [[satrap]]. The Kingdoms of  enjoyed special privileges and a semi-autonomous status, but they were still considered vassal subjects of the Great King.

The island was conquered by [[Alexander the Great]] in 333&nbsp;BC and  navy helped Alexander during the [[siege of Tyre (332 BC)]]. The  fleet was also sent to help [[Amphoterus (admiral)|Amphoterus]]. In addition, Alexander had two  generals [[Stasander]] and [[Stasanor]] both from the [[Soli, |Soli]] and later both became satraps in Alexander's empire.
Following Alexander's death, the [[Partition of Babylon|division of his empire]], and the subsequent [[Wars of the Diadochi]],  became part of the [[Hellenistic civilization|Hellenistic empire]] of [[Ptolemaic Kingdom|Ptolemaic ]]. It was during this period that the island was fully [[Hellenization|Hellenised]]. In 58&nbsp;BC  was acquired by the [[Roman Republic]] and became [[Roman ]] in 22 BC.

===Middle Ages===
{{Main| in the Middle Ages|Kingdom of }}
[[File:Nicosia by Giacomo Franco.jpg|thumb|The [[Walls of Nicosia]] were built by the Venetians to defend the city in case of an Ottoman attack.]]
[[File:Kyrenia 01-2017 img11 Castle exterior.jpg|thumb|[[Kyrenia Castle]] was originally built by the Byzantines and enlarged by the Venetians.]]
When the [[Roman Empire]] was divided into Eastern and Western parts in 286,  became part of the East Roman Empire (also called the [[Byzantine Empire]]); the island would remain part of the empire for some 900 years. Under Byzantine rule, the  orientation that had been prominent since antiquity developed the strong Hellenistic-Christian character that continues to be a hallmark of the   community.

Beginning in 649,  endured repeated attacks and raids launched by [[Umayyad Caliphate]]. Many were quick raids, but others were large-scale attacks in which many  were killed and great wealth carried off or destroyed. The city of [[Salamis, |Salamis]] was destroyed and never rebuilt. Byzantine control remained stronger in the northern coast, the Arabs exerted more influence in the south. In 688, Emperor [[Justinian II|Justinian&nbsp;II]] and Caliph [[Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan|Abd al-Malik]] signed a treaty whereby  would be paying an equal amount of tribute to the Caliphate and tax to the Empire, but would remain politically neutral to both while being retained as a province administered by the Empire. There are no Byzantine churches which survive from this period, and the island entered a period of impoverishment. Full Byzantine rule was restored in 965, when Emperor [[Nikephoros II Phokas|Nikephoros&nbsp;II Phokas]] scored decisive victories on land and sea.

In 1156 [[Raynald of Châtillon]] and [[Thoros II|Thoros II of ]] brutally sacked  over a period of three weeks, stealing so much plunder and capturing so many of the leading citizens and their families for ransom, that the island took generations to recover. Several  priests were mutilated and sent away to Constantinople.

In 1185 [[Isaac Komnenos of |Isaac Komnenos]], a member of the Byzantine imperial family, took over  and declared it independent of the Empire. In 1191, during the [[Third Crusade]], [[Richard I of England]] captured the island from Isaac. He used it as a major supply base that was relatively safe from the [[Saracen]]s. A year later Richard sold the island to the [[Knights Templar]], who, following a bloody revolt, in turn sold it to [[Guy of Lusignan]]. His brother and successor [[Aimery of |Aimery]] was recognised as [[Kingdom of |King of ]] by [[Henry VI, Holy Roman Emperor]].

Following the death in 1473 of [[James II of |James&nbsp;II]], the last Lusignan king, the [[Republic of Venice]] assumed control of the island, while the late king's Venetian widow, Queen [[Catherine Cornaro]], reigned as figurehead. Venice formally annexed the [[Kingdom of ]] in 1489, following the abdication of Catherine. The Venetians fortified [[Nicosia]] by building the [[Walls of Nicosia]], and used it as an important commercial hub. Throughout Venetian rule, the [[Ottoman Empire]] frequently raided . In 1539 the Ottomans destroyed [[Limassol]] and so fearing the worst, the Venetians also fortified [[Famagusta]] and [[Kyrenia]].

Although the Lusignan  aristocracy remained the dominant social class in  throughout the medieval period, the former assumption that  were treated only as serfs on the island is no longer considered by academics to be accurate. It is now accepted that the medieval period saw increasing numbers of   elevated to the upper classes, a growing  [[middle class|middle ranks]], and the Lusignan royal household even marrying . This included King [[John II of |John&nbsp;II of ]] who married [[Helena Palaiologina]].

===Ottoman ===
{{Main|Ottoman }}
[[File:Atlas Ortelius KB PPN369376781-073av-073br.jpg|thumb|left|''Cypri insvlae nova descript. 1573'', Ioannes à Deutecum f[ecit]. "Map of the island of , newly drawn by Johannes van Deutecom in 1573."]]
In 1570, a full-scale Ottoman assault with 60,000 troops brought the island under Ottoman control, despite stiff resistance by the inhabitants of Nicosia and Famagusta. Ottoman forces capturing  [[ massacre|massacred]] many  and  Christian inhabitants. The previous Latin elite were destroyed and the first significant demographic change since antiquity took place with the formation of a Muslim community. Soldiers who fought in the conquest settled on the island and  peasants and craftsmen were brought to the island from [[]]. This new community also included banished Anatolian tribes, "undesirable" persons and members of various "troublesome" Muslim sects, as well as a number of new converts on the island.
[[File:Buyuk Han, Nicosia - panoramio.jpg|thumb|[[Büyük Han]], a [[caravanserai]] in Nicosia, is an example of the surviving Ottoman architecture in .]]
The Ottomans abolished the [[feudal]] system previously in place and applied the [[Millet (Ottoman Empire)|millet system]] to , under which non-Muslim peoples were governed by their own religious authorities. In a reversal from the days of Latin rule, the head of the [[Church of ]] was invested as leader of the   population and acted as mediator between Christian   and the Ottoman authorities. This status ensured that the Church of  was in a position to end the [[Catholic Church]]'s constant expansion efforts on the island. Ottoman rule of  was at times indifferent, at times oppressive, depending on the temperaments of the sultans and local officials.

The ratio of Muslims to Christians fluctuated throughout the period of Ottoman domination. In 1777–78, 47,000 Muslims constituted a majority over the island's 37,000 Christians. By 1872, the population of the island had risen to 144,000, comprising 44,000 Muslims and 100,000 Christians. The Muslim population included numerous [[crypto-Christians]], including the [[Linobambaki]], a crypto-Catholic community that arose due to religious persecution of the Catholic community by the Ottoman authorities; this community would assimilate into the   community during  rule.

As soon as the [[ War of Independence]] broke out in 1821, several   left for  to join the  forces. In response, the Ottoman governor of  arrested and executed 486 prominent  , including the Archbishop of , [[Kyprianos of |Kyprianos]], and four other bishops. In 1828, modern 's first president [[Ioannis Kapodistrias]] called for union of  with , and numerous minor uprisings took place. Reaction to Ottoman misrule led to uprisings by both  and  , although none were successful. After centuries of neglect by the Ottoman Empire, the poverty of most of the people and the ever-present tax collectors fuelled  nationalism, and by the 20th century the idea of ''[[enosis|union]]'' with newly independent  was firmly rooted among  .

Under Ottoman rule, numeracy, school enrolment and literacy rates were all low. They persisted some time after Ottoman rule ended, and then increased rapidly during the twentieth century.

=== ===
{{Main| |Modern history of | Emergency}}
[[File:Hosting the  flag at Nicosia.jpg|thumb|upright|Hoisting the  flag at Nicosia]]

In the aftermath of the [[Russo- War (1877–1878)]] and the [[Congress of Berlin]],  was [[ Convention|leased]] to the [[ Empire]] which de facto took over its administration in 1878 (though, in terms of sovereignty,  remained a ''[[de jure]]'' Ottoman territory until 5 November 1914, together with [[Khedivate of | and ]]) in exchange for guarantees that Britain would use the island as a base to protect the Ottoman Empire against possible  aggression.

[[File: demonstration 1930.jpg|thumb|[[ | ]] demonstrations for [[Enosis]] (union with ) in 1930]]
The island would serve Britain as a key military base for its colonial routes. By 1906, when the Famagusta harbour was completed,  was a strategic naval outpost overlooking the [[Suez Canal]], the crucial main route to  which was then Britain's most important overseas possession. Following the outbreak of the [[First World War]] and the decision of the Ottoman Empire to join the war on the side of the [[Central Powers]], on 5 November 1914 the  Empire formally annexed  and declared the Ottoman ''[[Khedive|Khedivate]]'' of [[Khedivate of | and ]] a [[Sultanate of |''Sultanate'' and  protectorate]].

In October 1915, Britain offered  to , ruled by King [[Constantine I of ]], on the condition that  join the war on the side of the  and went to [[Kingdom of |]]’s assistance, in order to fulfill her Treaty obligations under the [[– Alliance of 1913|Serbo- pact]] of May 1913. It gave  a golden 
“opportunity” in achieving ''[[enosis]]'' with . Alternatively it was a
“lost opportunity” when the [[Alexandros Zaimis|Zaimis]] administration declined the  proposal.

In 1923, under the [[Treaty of Lausanne (1923)|Treaty of Lausanne]], the nascent  republic relinquished any claim to , and in 1925 it was declared a  [[crown colony]]. During the [[Second World War]], many  and   enlisted in the [[ Regiment]].

The   population, meanwhile, had become hopeful that the  administration would lead to ''enosis''. The idea of ''enosis'' was historically part of the ''[[Megali Idea]]'', a greater political ambition of a  state encompassing the territories with large  populations in the former Ottoman Empire, including  and [[Asia Minor]] with a capital in [[Constantinople]], and was actively pursued by the [[ Orthodox Church]], which had its members educated in . These religious officials, together with  military officers and professionals, some of whom still pursued the ''Megali Idea'', would later found the guerrilla organisation [[EOKA]] ''(Ethniki Organosis Kyprion Agoniston'' or National Organisation of  Fighters). The   viewed the island as historically  and believed that union with  was a natural right. In the 1950s, the pursuit of ''enosis'' became a part of the  national policy.

[[File:Street riot in Nicosia 1956.jpg|thumb|A  soldier facing a crowd of   demonstrators in Nicosia (1956)]]

Initially, the   favoured the continuation of the  rule. However, they were alarmed by the   calls for ''enosis'', as they saw the union of [[Cretan State|Crete]] with , which led to the exodus of [[Cretan Turks]], as a precedent to be avoided, and they took a pro-partition stance in response to the militant activity of EOKA. The   also viewed themselves as a distinct ethnic group of the island and believed in their having a separate right to [[self-determination]] from  . Meanwhile, in the 1950s,  leader [[Adnan Menderes|Menderes]] considered  an "extension of ", rejected the partition of  along ethnic lines and favoured the annexation of the whole island to . Nationalistic slogans centred on the idea that " is " and the ruling party declared  to be a part of the  homeland that was vital to its security. Upon realising that the fact that the   population was only 20% of the islanders made annexation unfeasible, the national policy was changed to favour partition. The slogan "Partition or Death" was frequently used in   and  protests starting in the late 1950s and continuing throughout the 1960s. Although after the Zürich and London conferences  seemed to accept the existence of the  state and to distance itself from its policy of favouring the partition of the island, the goal of the  and   leaders remained that of creating an independent  state in the northern part of the island.

In January 1950, the Church of  organised a [[ enosis referendum, 1950|referendum]] under the supervision of clerics and with no   participation, where 96% of the participating   voted in favour of ''enosis''.{{rp|9}} The  were 80.2% of the total island's population at the time ([[Demographics of |census 1946]]). Restricted autonomy under a constitution was proposed by the  administration but eventually rejected. In 1955 the EOKA organisation was founded, seeking union with  through armed struggle. At the same time the [[ Resistance Organisation]] (TMT), calling for Taksim, or partition, was established by the   as a counterweight.  officials also tolerated the creation of the  underground organisation TMT The Secretary of State for the Colonies in a letter dated 15 July 1958 had advised the Governor of  not to act against TMT despite its illegal actions so as not to harm  relations with the  government.

===Independence and inter-communal violence===
{{Main| crisis of 1963–64}}
{{multiple image
| align             = right
| direction         = horizontal
| image1            = Makarios III and Robert F. Wagner NYWTS cropped.jpg
| width1            = 135
| image2            = Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-F014934-0068, Fazil Kutschuk.jpg
| width2            = 127
| footer            = The first president of , [[Makarios III]] (left), and the first vice-president of , [[Fazıl Küçük]] (right)
}}

During  rule, the future of the island became a matter of disagreement between the two prominent ethnic communities, [[ ]], who made up 77% of the population in 1960, and [[ ]], who made up 18% of the population. From the 19th century onwards, the   population pursued ''[[enosis]]'', union with [[]], which became a  national policy in the 1950s. The   population initially advocated the continuation of the  rule, then demanded the annexation of the island to , and in the 1950s, together with , established a policy of ''[[Taksim (politics)|taksim]]'', the partition of  and the creation of a  polity in the north.[[File:Ethnographic distribution in  1960.jpg|thumb|Ethnic map of  according to the 1960 census]]
 was [[London and Zürich Agreements|granted independence]] in 1960, following an armed campaign spearheaded by EOKA. As per the [[Zürich and London Agreement]],  officially attained independence on 16 August 1960, and at the time had a total population of 573,566; of whom 442,138 (77.1%) were , 104,320 (18.2%) Turks, and 27,108 (4.7%) others. The UK retained the two [[Sovereign Base Areas]] of [[Akrotiri and Dhekelia]], while government posts and public offices were allocated by ethnic quotas, giving the minority   a permanent veto, 30% in parliament and administration, and granting the three mother-states guarantor rights.

However, the division of power as foreseen by the constitution soon resulted in legal impasses and discontent on both sides, and nationalist militants started training again, with the military support of  and  respectively. The   leadership believed that the rights given to   under the 1960 constitution were too extensive and designed the [[Akritas plan]], which was aimed at reforming the constitution in favour of  , persuading the international community about the correctness of the changes and violently subjugating   in a few days should they not accept the plan. Tensions were heightened when  President Archbishop [[Makarios&nbsp;III]] called for [[Zürich and London Agreement#13 Amendments proposed by Makarios III|constitutional changes]], which were rejected by {{rp|17–20}} and opposed by  .

Intercommunal violence [[Bloody Christmas (1963)|erupted]] on 21 December 1963, when two   were killed at an incident involving the   police. The violence resulted in the death of 364&nbsp; and 174&nbsp; , destruction of 109   or mixed villages and displacement of 25,000–30,000  . The crisis resulted in the end of the   involvement in the administration and their claiming that it had lost its legitimacy;{{rp|56–59}} the nature of this event is still controversial. In some areas,   prevented   from travelling and entering government buildings, while some   willingly withdrew due to the calls of the   administration.   started living in [[  enclaves|enclaves]]. The republic's structure was changed, unilaterally, by Makarios, and Nicosia was divided by the [[Green Line ()|Green Line]], with the deployment of [[UNFICYP]] troops.{{rp|56–59}}

In 1964,  threatened to invade  in response to the continuing [[ intercommunal violence]], but this was stopped by a strongly worded telegram from the US President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] on 5 June, warning that the US would not stand beside  in case of a consequential Soviet invasion of  territory. Meanwhile, by 1964, ''enosis'' was a  policy and would not be abandoned; Makarios and the  prime minister [[Georgios Papandreou]] agreed that ''enosis'' should be the ultimate aim and King [[Constantine II of |Constantine]] wished  "a speedy union with the mother country".  dispatched 10,000 troops to  to counter a possible  invasion.

The [[Bloody Christmas (1963)|crisis of 1963–64]] had brought further [[ intercommunal violence|intercommunal violence]] between the two communities, displaced more than 25,000   into [[  enclaves|enclaves]]{{rp|56–59}} and brought the end of   representation in the republic.

===1974 coup d'état, invasion, and division===
{{Main|1974  coup d'état| invasion of }}
[[File:Famagusta-Varosha 2007.JPG|thumb|[[Varosha, Famagusta|Varosha (Maraş)]], a suburb of Famagusta, was abandoned when its inhabitants fled in 1974 and remains under  military control.]]
On 15 July 1974, the [[ military junta of 1967–1974| military junta]] under [[Dimitrios Ioannides]] carried out a [[1974  coup d'état|coup d'état]] in , to [[Enosis|unite the island with ]]. The coup ousted president [[Makarios&nbsp;III]] and replaced him with pro-[[enosis]] nationalist [[Nikos Sampson]]. In response to the coup,{{efn|See:}} five days later, on 20 July 1974, the [[ invasion of | army invaded]] the island, citing a right to intervene to restore the constitutional order from the 1960 [[Treaty of Guarantee (1960)|Treaty of Guarantee]]. This justification has been rejected by the [[United Nations]] and the international community.

The  air force began bombing  positions in , and hundreds of [[paratroopers]] were dropped in the area between Nicosia and Kyrenia, where well-armed   enclaves had been long-established; while off the Kyrenia coast,  troop ships landed 6,000 men as well as tanks, trucks and armoured vehicles.

Three days later, when a ceasefire had been agreed,  had landed 30,000 troops on the island and captured Kyrenia, the corridor linking Kyrenia to Nicosia, and the   quarter of Nicosia itself. The junta in [[Athens]], and then the Sampson regime in  fell from power. In Nicosia, [[Glafkos Clerides]] temporarily assumed the presidency. But after the peace negotiations in [[Geneva]], the  government reinforced their Kyrenia bridgehead and started a second invasion on 14 August. The invasion resulted in [[Morphou]], [[Karpass Peninsula|Karpass]], Famagusta and the [[Mesaoria]] coming under  control.

International pressure led to a ceasefire, and by then 36% of the island had been taken over by the Turks and 180,000   had been evicted from their homes in the north. At the same time, around 50,000   were displaced to the north and settled in the properties of the displaced  . Among a variety of sanctions against , in mid-1975 the US Congress imposed an arms embargo on  for using US-supplied equipment during the [[ invasion of ]] in 1974. There were 1,534   and 502   missing as a result of the fighting from 1963 to 1974.

The Republic of  has ''[[de jure]]'' [[sovereignty]] over the entire island, including its [[territorial waters]] and [[exclusive economic zone]], with the exception of the Sovereign Base Areas of [[Akrotiri and Dhekelia]], which remain under the UK's control according to the [[London-Zürich Agreements|London and Zürich Agreements]]. However, the island is ''[[de facto]]'' partitioned into two main parts: the area under the effective control of the Republic of , in the south and west and comprising about 59% of the island's area, and the north, administered by the self-declared  Republic of Northern , covering about 36% of the island's area. Another nearly 4% of the island's area is covered by the [[United Nations Buffer Zone in |UN buffer zone]]. The international community considers the northern part of the island to be territory of the Republic of  occupied by  forces.{{efn|See:}} The occupation is viewed as illegal under international law and amounting to illegal occupation of EU territory since  became a member of the [[European Union]].

===Post-division===
[[File:Cy-map.png|thumb|upright=1.6|A map showing the division of ]]

After the restoration of constitutional order and the return of Archbishop [[Makarios&nbsp;III]] to  in December 1974,  troops remained, occupying the northeastern portion of the island. In 1983, the [[Assembly of the Republic (Northern )|  parliament]], led by the   leader [[Rauf Denktaş]], [[Declaration of Independence of the  Republic of Northern |proclaimed]] the  Republic of Northern  (TRNC), which is recognised only by .

The events of the summer of 1974 dominate the [[ dispute|politics]] on the island, as well as [[Greco- relations]]. [[ settlers in Northern | settlers]] have been settled in the north with the encouragement of the  and   states. The Republic of  considers their presence a violation of the [[Geneva Convention]],{{rp|56–59}} whilst many  settlers have since severed their ties to  and their second generation considers  to be their homeland.
[[File:EU Foreign Ministers Gymnich Meeting in . 7.-8. September 2012 (7954502290).jpg|thumb|Foreign Ministers of the European Union countries in Limassol during  Presidency of the EU in 2012]]
The  invasion, the ensuing occupation and the declaration of independence by the TRNC have been condemned by United Nations resolutions, which are reaffirmed by the Security Council every year.

===21st century===
[[File:Close to the buffer zone - panoramio.jpg|thumb|Street in the divided capital of Nicosia]]
Attempts to resolve the  dispute have continued. In 2004, the [[Annan Plan]], drafted by then UN Secretary General [[Kofi Annan]], was put to a [[ Annan Plan referendums, 2004|referendum]] in both  administrations. 65% of   voted in support of the plan and 74%   voted against the plan, saying that it disproportionately favoured   and gave unreasonable influence over the nation to . In total, 66.7% of the voters [[ Annan Plan referendum, 2004|rejected the Annan Plan]].

On 1 May 2004  joined the [[European Union]], together with nine other countries.  was accepted into the EU as a whole, although the EU legislation is suspended in Northern  until a final settlement of the  problem.

Efforts have been made to enhance freedom of movement between the two sides. In April 2003, Northern  unilaterally eased checkpoint restrictions, permitting  to cross between the two sides for the first time in 30 years. In March 2008, a wall that had stood for decades at the boundary between the Republic of  and the [[United Nations Buffer Zone in |UN buffer zone]] was demolished. The wall had cut across [[Ledra Street]] in the heart of Nicosia and was seen as a strong symbol of the island's 32-year division. On 3 April 2008, Ledra Street was reopened in the presence of  and   officials. The two sides relaunched reunification talks in 2015, but these collapsed in 2017.

The [[European Union]] warned in February 2019 that  was selling [[Passports of the European Union|EU passports]] to [[ oligarch]]s, and thus would allow [[organized crime|organised crime]] syndicates to infiltrate the EU. In 2020, leaked documents revealed a wider range of former and current officials from , , Dubai, , the  Federation, ,  and  who bought a  citizenship prior to a change of the law in July 2019. Since 2020  and  have been [[– maritime zones dispute|engaged in a dispute]] over the extent of their [[exclusive economic zone]]s, ostensibly sparked by oil and gas exploration in the area.

In November 2023, the [[ Confidential]] data leak published by the [[International Consortium of Investigative Journalists]] showed the country's financial network entertaining strong links with  oligarchs and high-up figures in the Kremlin, supporting the regime of [[Vladimir Putin]].

In July 2024, on the 50th anniversary of the  invasion of Northern ,  President Erdoğan rejected a United Nations-endorsed plan for a federal government and supported the idea of having two separate states within .   immediately rejected Erdoğan's two-state proposal, calling it a "non-starter".
== History==
{{Main|History of the }}

===Prehistory===
[[File:Sailing Canoe brailed on starboard tack, Jaliut Lagoon,  (1899-1900).jpg|thumb|Marshall Islanders sailing, with sails [[brail]]ed ([[reefing|reefed]]), c. 1899–1900]]

Linguistic and anthropological studies have suggested that the first [[Austronesian peoples|Austronesian]] settlers of the  arrived from the [[ (archipelago)|]]. [[Radiocarbon dating]] suggests that [[Bikini Atoll]] may have been inhabited as early as 1200 BCE, though samples may not have been collected from secure [[Stratigraphy|stratigraphic]] contexts and older driftwood samples may have affected results. Archaeological digs on other atolls have found evidence of human habitation dating around the 1st century CE at the village of [[Laura, |Laura]] on [[Majuro]] and on [[Kwajalein Atoll]].

The Austronesian settlers [[Domesticated plants and animals of Austronesia|introduced Southeast Asian crops]], including [[coconut]]s, [[Cyrtosperma merkusii|giant swamp taro]], and [[breadfruit]], as well as domesticated chickens throughout the . They possibly seeded the islands by leaving coconuts at seasonal fishing camps before permanently settling years later. The southern islands receive heavier rainfall than the north, so communities in the wet south subsisted on prevalent taro and breadfruit, while northerners were more likely to subsist on [[pandanus]] and coconuts. Southern atolls probably supported larger, more dense populations.

[[File:Stick chart-BHM 1920.530.0032-P8260228.JPG|thumb|A  [[ stick chart|stick chart]]. Most were made from a grid of coconut frond midribs with small shells representing the relative location of islands.]]

The  sailed between islands on [[walap]]s made from breadfruit-tree wood and coconut-fiber rope. They navigated by using the stars for orientation and initial course setting, but also developed a [[piloting]] technique of interpreting disruptions in [[Swell (ocean)|ocean swells]] to determine the location of low coral atolls below the horizon. They noticed that swells refracted around the undersea slope of atolls. When refracted swells from different directions met, they created noticeable disruption patterns, which  pilots could read to determine the direction of an island. When interviewed by anthropologists, some  sailors noted that they piloted their canoes by both sight and feeling changes in the motion of the boat. Sailors also invented [[ stick chart|stick charts]] to map the swell patterns, but unlike western navigational charts, the  stick charts were tools for teaching students and for consultation before embarking on a voyage; navigators did not take charts with them when they set sail.

When  explorer [[Otto von Kotzebue]] visited the Marshalls in 1817, the islanders still showed few signs of western influence. He observed that the  lived in thatched-roof huts, but their villages did not include the large ornate meeting houses found in other parts of . They did not have furniture, except for woven mats, which they used for both floor coverings and clothing. The  had pierced ears and [[tattoo]]s. He learned that  families practiced [[infanticide]] after the birth of a third child as a form of population planning due to frequent [[famine]]s. He also noted that  [[Iroijlaplap|iroij]] held considerable authority and rights to all property, though he had a more favorable view of the condition of  commoners than of that of [[Polynesians|Polynesian]] commoners. The Marshalls' two island groups, the [[Ratak]] and [[Ralik]] chains, were each ruled by a paramount chief, or iroijlaplap, who held authority over the individual island iroij.

===European exploration===
[[File:Reception of the Manila Galleon by the Chamorro in the Ladrones Islands, ca. 1590.jpg|thumb|upright=1.25|[[Manila galleon|Manila Galleon]] in the [[Mariana Islands|Marianas]] and [[Caroline Islands|Carolines]], c. 1590 [[Boxer Codex]]]]

On August 21, 1526,  explorer [[Alonso de Salazar]] was the first European to sight the . While commanding the ''[[Loaísa Expedition|Santa Maria de la Victoria]]'', he sighted an atoll with a green lagoon, which may have been [[Bokak Atoll|Taongi]]. The crew could not land, because of strong currents and water too deep for the ship's anchor, so the ship sailed for [[Guam]] two days later.

On January 2, 1528, the expedition of [[Álvaro de Saavedra Cerón]] landed on an uninhabited island, possibly in [[Ailinginae Atoll]], where they resupplied and stayed for six days. Natives from a neighboring island briefly met the . This expedition named the islands 'Los Pintados' or "the Painted Ones" for the natives who wore tattoos. Later  explorers of the Marshalls included [[Ruy López de Villalobos]], [[Miguel López de Legazpi]], [[Alonso de Arellano]], and [[Álvaro de Mendaña de Neira]], though coordinates and geographic descriptions in 16th century  logs are sometimes imprecise, leaving uncertainty about the specific islands they sighted and visited.

On July 6, 1565, the  ship ''San Jeronimo'' nearly wrecked at [[Ujelang Atoll]] after the ship's pilot [[Lope Martín]] led a mutiny. While the mutineers were resupplying at Ujelang, several crew members took back control of the ship and marooned Martín and twenty-six other mutineers in the Marshalls. By the late 16th century,  galleons sailing between the Americas and the  kept to a sea lane at 13°N and provisioned at Guam, avoiding the Marshalls, which  sailors saw as unprofitable islands amid hazardous waters.

The  sea captains [[John Marshall (Royal Navy officer, born 1748)|John Marshall]] and [[Thomas Gilbert (sea captain)|Thomas Gilbert]] visited the islands in 1788. Their vessels had been part of the [[First Fleet]] taking convicts from England to [[Botany Bay]] in [[New South Wales]], and were en route to [[Guangzhou]] when they passed through the [[Gilbert Islands]] and . On June 25, 1788, the  ships had peaceful interactions and traded with islanders at [[Mili Atoll]]; their meeting may have been the first contact between Europeans and  since the Mendaña expedition of 1568. Subsequent navigational charts and maps named the islands for John Marshall.

From the 1820s through the 1850s, the Marshall Islanders became increasingly hostile to western vessels, possibly because of violent punishments that sea captains exacted for theft as well as the [[Blackbirding|abduction]] of  people for sale into slavery on Pacific plantations. One of the earliest violent encounters occurred in February 1824, when the inhabitants of Mili Atoll massacred marooned sailors from the  [[whaler]] ''[[Globe (1815 whaleship)|Globe]]''. Similar encounters occurred as late as 1851 and 1852, when three separate  attacks on ships occurred at [[Ebon Atoll|Ebon]], [[Jaluit Atoll|Jaluit]], and [[Namdrik Atoll]]s.

===Colonial period===
[[File: colonial album 1880s img26.jpg|thumb|Offices of the Pacific Navigation Co. at Jaluit Atoll in the late 1880s]]

In 1857, [[ Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions]] sent two families to establish a mission church and school at [[Ebon Atoll|Ebon]]. By 1875, the missionaries had established churches on five atolls and had baptized more than 200 islanders, and one traveler noted that most women on Ebon wore western clothes and many men wore trousers by the mid-1870s.

In 1859, Adolph Capelle and another merchant arrived at Ebon and set up a trading post for the  company Hoffschlaeger & Stapenhorst. When the firm went bankrupt in 1863, Capelle partnered with  ex-whaler Anton Jose DeBrum to establish a [[copra]] trading firm: Capelle & Co. In 1873, the company moved its headquarters to [[Jaluit Atoll|Jaluit]], the home of [[Kabua the Great|Kabua]], a powerful [[iroijlaplap|iroij]] and disputed successor for the [[paramount chief]]tainship of the southern [[Ralik|Ralik Chain]]. In the 1870s, various other companies from , Hawaii, , and the  engaged in the copra trade in the . By 1885, the  firms [[Hernsheim & Co]]. and Deutsche Handels- und Plantagen-Gesellschaft Der Südsee Inseln zu Hamburg controlled two-thirds of the trade.

Contact between the  and westerners led to sometimes lethal outbreaks of western diseases, including [[influenza]], [[measles]], [[syphilis]], and [[typhoid fever]]. Increased access to alcohol led to social problems in some  communities, and on several atolls conflicts erupted between rival iroij with access to firearms.

==== protectorate====
[[File: colonial album 1880s img12.jpg|thumb| colonial administration building at Jaluit Atoll in 1886]]

In 1875, the  and  governments conducted a series of secret negotiations to divide the Western Pacific into [[Sphere of influence|spheres of influence]]. The  sphere included the . On November 26, 1878, the  warship [[SMS Ariadne (1871)|SMS ''Ariadne'']] anchored at Jaluit to begin treaty negotiations with the chiefs to grant the [[ Empire]] "[[Most favoured nation|most favored nation]]" status in the Ralik Chain. During the second day of negotiations, Captain {{ill|Bartholomäus von Werner|de}} ordered his men to give military demonstrations which he later said were intended to "show the islanders, who have not seen anything like it before, the power of the Europeans." On November 29, Werner signed a treaty with Kabua and several other Ralik Chain iroij which secured a  [[fuelling station]] at Jaluit and free use of the atoll's harbor.

On August 29, 1885, [[Chancellor of | Chancellor]] [[Otto von Bismarck]] authorized the annexation of the  as a [[protectorate]] following repeated petitions by  business interests. The  gunboat {{SMS|Nautilus|1871|2}} docked at Jaluit on October 13 to take control. On October 15, iroij Kabua, Loeak, Nelu, Lagajime, and Launa signed a protection treaty in  and  at the  consulate. While the  text made no distinction of rank among the five chiefs, the  text recognized Kabua as the King of the , despite an ongoing dispute between Kabua and Loeak over the [[iroijlaplap|paramount chief]]tainship. A company of  marines hoisted the [[flag of the  Empire]] over Jaluit, and performed similar ceremonies at seven other atolls in the Marshalls, though several pro- iroij refused to recognize the  protectorate until threatened with  naval force in mid-1886. [[]] was incorporated into the  Protectorate of the  in 1888, following the [[Anglo- Declarations about the Western Pacific Ocean|Anglo- Declarations]] of April 1886.

The  commercial interests formed the [[Joint-stock company|joint-stock]] [[Jaluit Company]], which was responsible for financing the colony's administration. In addition to controlling two-thirds of the  copra trade, the company had the authority to collect commercial license fees and an annual [[poll tax]]. The company also had the right to be consulted on all new laws and ordinances and nominated all colonial administrative staff. The company's licensing fees and legal advantages pushed out  and  competition, creating a monopoly in the  Pacific colonies. The  government protested the regulations benefiting the Jaluit Company as a violation of the Anglo- Declarations' free-trade provision.
