In 2021,  signed and ratified the [[Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons]], making it a nuclear-weapon-free state. and in 2023,  was invited as a non-member guest to the G7 summit in [[Hiroshima]]. On 18 February 2023 the  assumed the presidency of the [[African Union]].

In January 2024, President Azali Assoumani was re-elected with 63% of the vote in the disputed presidential [[2024  presidential election|election]]. In January 2025, the ruling party of president Azali Assoumani won parliamentary [[2025  parliamentary election|election]], taking 28 out of 33 parliamentary seats. The opposition parties rejected the results.
==History==
{{Main|History of }}
{{further| historiography}}

=== Prehistory ===
{{Contains special characters|Ethiopic}}{{Main|Prehistoric }}

[[File:Homo Sapiens Idaltu.JPG|thumb|A ''[[Herto Man|Homo sapiens idaltu]]'' hominid skull]]

Several important finds have propelled  and the surrounding region to the forefront of&nbsp;[[Paleontology|palaeontology]]. The oldest [[Hominidae|hominid]] discovered to date in  is the 4.2&nbsp;million-year-old ''[[Ardipithecus|Ardipithecus ramidus]]'' ([[Ardi]]) found by [[Tim D. White]] in 1994. The most well-known hominid discovery is ''[[Australopithecus afarensis]]'' ([[Lucy (Australopithecus)|Lucy]]). Known locally as ''Dinkinesh'', the specimen was found in the [[Awash Valley]] of [[Afar Region]] in 1974 by [[Donald Johanson]], and is one of the most complete and best-preserved adult [[Australopithecus|Australopithecine]] fossils ever uncovered. Lucy's taxonomic name refers to the region where the discovery was made. This hominid is estimated to have lived 3.2&nbsp;million years ago.

 is also considered one of the earliest sites of the emergence of [[Early modern human|anatomically modern humans]], ''[[Human|Homo sapiens]]''. The oldest of these local fossil finds, the [[Omo remains]], were excavated in the southwestern [[Omo Kibish Formation|Omo Kibish]] area and have been dated to the [[Middle Paleolithic]], around 200,000 years ago. Additionally, skeletons of ''[[Herto Man|Homo sapiens idaltu]]'' were found at a site in the [[Middle Awash]] valley. Dated to approximately 160,000 years ago, they may represent an extinct subspecies of ''Homo sapiens'', or the immediate ancestors of anatomically modern humans. Archaic ''Homo sapiens'' fossils excavated at the [[Jebel Irhoud]] site in  have since been dated to an earlier period, about 300,000 years ago, while Omo-Kibish I (Omo I) from southern  is the oldest anatomically modern ''Homo sapiens'' skeleton currently known (196 ± 5 kya).

According to some anthropologists, the first [[Afroasiatic languages|Afroasiatic]]-speaking populations arrived in the region during the ensuing [[Neolithic]] era from the family's proposed [[Afroasiatic homeland|urheimat]] ("original homeland") in the [[Nile|Nile Valley]], or the [[Near East]]. The majority of scholars today propose that the Afroasiatic family developed in northeast Africa because of the higher diversity of lineages in that region, a telltale sign of linguistic origin.

In 2019, archaeologists discovered a 30,000-year-old [[Middle Stone Age]] rock shelter at the [[Fincha Habera, |Fincha Habera]] site in [[Bale Mountains]] at an elevation of {{convert|3469|m|abbr=off}} above sea level. At this high altitude, humans are susceptible both to [[Hypoxemia#Environmental oxygen|hypoxia]] and to extreme weather. According to a study published in the journal ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'', this dwelling is proof of the earliest permanent human occupation at high altitude yet discovered. Thousands of animal bones, hundreds of stone tools, and ancient fireplaces were discovered, revealing a diet that featured giant [[Spalacidae|mole rat]]s.

Evidence of some of the earliest known stone-tipped projectile weapons (a characteristic tool of ''Homo sapiens''), the stone tips of javelins or throwing spears, were discovered in 2013 at the  site of [[Gademotta]], which date to around 279,000 years ago. In 2019, additional Middle Stone Age projectile weapons were found at Aduma, dated 100,000–80,000 years ago, in the form of points considered likely to belong to darts delivered by spear throwers.

===Antiquity===
{{Main|Dʿmt|Kingdom of Aksum}}
[[File:KingEndybisEthiopia227-235CE.jpg|thumb|[[Aksumite currency]] of the [[Axumite kings|Aksumite king]] [[Endybis]], 227–35, at the [[ Museum]]{{Efn|The inscriptions in [[Ancient ]] read {{lang|grc|ΑΞΩΜΙΤΩ ΒΑϹΙΛΕΥϹ}} ("King of Axum") and {{lang|grc|ΕΝΔΥΒΙϹ ΒΑϹΙΛΕΥϹ}} ("King Endybis");  was the ''[[lingua franca]]'' by that time, so its use in coins simplified foreign trade.}}]]

In 980 BC, [[Dʿmt]] was established in present-day [[]] and the northern part of  in the Tigray region, and is widely believed to be the successor state to [[Land of Punt|Punt]]. This polity's capital was located at [[Yeha]] in what is now northern . Most modern historians consider this civilization to be a native  one, although in earlier times many suggested it was [[Sabaeans|Sabaean]]-influenced because of the latter's hegemony of the [[Red Sea]].

Other scholars regard Dʿmt as the result of a union of Afroasiatic-speaking cultures of the Cushitic and Semitic branches; namely, local [[Agaw people]]s and Sabaeans from Southern Arabia. However, [[Geʽez|Ge'ez]], the ancient Semitic language of , is thought to have developed independently from the [[Sabaean language]]. As early as 2000 BC, other Semitic speakers were living in  and  where Ge'ez developed. Sabaean influence is now thought to have been minor, limited to a few localities, and disappearing after a few decades or a century. It may have been a trading or military colony in alliance with the  civilization of Dʿmt or some other proto-Axumite state.
[[File:The Kingdom of Aksum.png|thumb|The [[Kingdom of Aksum|Empire of Axum]] at its peak in the 6th century]]
After the fall of Dʿmt during the 4th century BC, the  plateau came to be dominated by smaller successor kingdoms. In the 1st century AD, the [[Kingdom of Aksum]] emerged in what is now Tigray Region and . According to the medieval ''[[Book of Axum]]'', the kingdom's first capital, Mazaber, was built by Itiyopis, son of Cush. Aksum would later at times extend its rule into  on the other side of the Red Sea. The Persian prophet [[Mani (prophet)|Mani]] listed Axum with Rome, Persia, and  as one of the four great powers of his era, during the 3rd century. It is also believed that there was a connection between  and  churches. There is faint evidence that the Aksumites were associated with the [[Queen of Sheba]], via their royal inscription.

Around 316 AD, [[Frumentius]] and his brother Edesius from [[Tyre, |Tyre]] accompanied their uncle on a voyage to . When the vessel stopped at a Red Sea port, the natives killed all the travellers except the two brothers, who were taken to the court as [[Slavery in |slaves]]. They were given positions of trust by the monarch, and they converted members of the royal court to Christianity. Frumentius became the first bishop of Aksum. A coin dated to 324 shows that  was the second country to officially adopt Christianity (after  did so in 301), although the religion may have been at first confined to court circles; it was the first major power to do so. The Aksumites were accustomed to the Greco-Roman sphere of influence, but they embarked on significant cultural ties and trade connections between the [[ subcontinent]] and the Roman Empire via the [[Silk Road]], primarily exporting [[Ivory trade|ivory]], tortoise shell, gold and emeralds, and importing silk and spices. The country's gold production in 2015 is 9 metric tons.

===Middle Ages===
{{Main| in the Middle Ages}}

The kingdom adopted the name "" during the reign of [[Ezana of Axum|Ezana]] in the 4th century. After the conquest of [[Kingdom of Kush]] in 330, the Aksumite territory reached its peak between the 5th and 6th centuries. This period was interrupted by several incursions into the South Arabian protectorate, including [[Jews|Jewish]] [[Dhu Nuwas]] of the [[Himyarite Kingdom]] and the [[Aksumite–Persian wars]]. In 575, the Aksumites [[Sasanian reconquest of |besieged and retook Sana'a]] following the assassination of its governor [[Sayf ibn Dhi Yazan|Sayf ibn Dhī Yazan]]. The Red Sea was left to the [[Rashidun Caliphate]] in 646, and the port city of [[Adulis]] was plundered by Arab Muslims in the 8th century; along with irrevocable [[land degradation]], claimed [[climate change (general concept)|climate change]] and sporadic rainfall precipitation from 730 to 760, these factors likely caused the kingdom to decline in power as part of an important trade route. Aksum came to an end in 960 when [[Gudit|Queen Gudit]] defeated the last king of Aksum. In response, the remnant of the Aksumite population to shift into the southern region and establish the [[Zagwe dynasty]], changing its capital to [[Lalibela]]. Zagwe's rule ended when an [[Amhara people|Amhara]] noble man [[Yekuno Amlak]] revolted against King [[Yetbarak]] and established the [[ Empire]] (known by exonym "Abyssinia").
[[File:Bete Medhane Alem in Lalibela.JPG|thumb|201x201px|[[Biete Medhane Alem]], built during [[Zagwe dynasty]] in the Middle Ages ]]
The  Empire initiated territorial expansion under the leadership of [[Amda Seyon I]]. He launched campaigns against his Muslim adversaries to the east, resulting in a significant shift in the balance of power in favor of the Christians for the next two centuries. After Amda Seyon's successful eastern campaigns, most of the Muslim principalities in the [[Horn of Africa]] came under the suzerainty of the  Empire. Stretching from [[Gojjam]] to the  Coast in [[Zeila|Zelia]]. Among these Muslim entities was the [[Sultanate of Ifat]]. During the reign of Emperor [[Zara Yaqob]], the  Empire reached its pinnacle. His rule was marked by the consolidation of territorial acquisitions from earlier rulers, the oversight of the construction of numerous churches and monasteries, the active promotion of literature and art, and the strengthening of central imperial authority.{{sfn|Connel|Killion|2011|p=160}} Ifat's successor, the [[Adal Sultanate]], tried to conquer  during the [[–Adal War]], but was ultimately defeated at the 1543 [[Battle of Wayna Daga]].

By the 16th century, an influx of migration by ethnic [[Oromo people|Oromo]] into northern parts of the region fragmented the empire's power. Embarking from present-day [[Guji Zone|Guji]] and [[Borena Zone]], the Oromos were largely motivated by several folkloric conceptions—beginning with ''Moggaasaa'' and ''Liqimssa''—many of whom related to their raids. This persisted until ''gada'' of Meslé.{{sfn|Pankhurst|1997|p=301}} According to [[Bahrey|Abba Bahrey]], the earliest expansion occurred under Emperor [[Dawit II]] ([[Luba Melbah|''luba'' Melbah]]), when they encroached to [[Bale Province, |Bale]] before invading Adal Sultanate.

 saw major diplomatic contact with  from the 17th century, mainly related to religion. Beginning in 1555,  Jesuits attempted to develop Roman Catholicism as the state religion. After several failures, they sent several missionaries in 1603, including the most influential,  Jesuit [[Pedro Páez|Pedro Paez]]. Under Emperor [[Susenyos I]], Roman Catholicism became the state religion of the  Empire in 1622. This decision caused an uprising by the Orthodox populace.

===Early Modern Period (1632–1855)===
{{Main|Gondarine period|Zemene Mesafint}}
[[File:Fasil Ghebbi IV (23869587160).jpg|thumb|Fasil Ghebbi, one of the key castles of the [[Gondarine period]]]]
In 1632, Emperor [[Fasilides]] halted Roman Catholic state administration, restoring [[Orthodox Tewahedo]] as the state religion. Fasilides' reign solidified imperial power, relocating the capital to [[Gondar]] in 1636, marking the beginning of the "[[Gondarine period]]". He reclaimed lands, and exiled [[Jesuits]] to [[Fremona]]. During his rule, Fasilides constructed the iconic royal fortress, [[Fasil Ghebbi]], built forty-four churches, and revived [[ art]]. He is also credited with building seven stone bridges over the [[Blue Nile River]].

Gondar's power declined after the death of [[Iyasu I]] in 1706. Following [[Iyasu II]]'s death in 1755, Empress [[Mentewab]] brought her brother, [[Ras (title)|Ras]] Wolde Leul, to Gondar, making him Ras Bitwaded. This led to regnal conflict between Mentewab's ''Quaregnoch'' and the Wollo group led by Wubit. In 1767, Ras [[Mikael Sehul]], a regent in [[Tigray Province]], seized Gondar, killing the child [[Iyoas I]] in 1769, the reigning emperor, and installed 70-year-old [[Yohannes II]].

Between 1769 and 1855,  witnessed the [[Zemene Mesafint]] or "Age of Princes," a period of isolation. Emperors became figureheads, controlled by regional lords and noblemen like ''Ras'' Mikael Sehul, Ras [[Wolde Selassie]] of Tigray, and by the [[Yejju]] Oromo dynasty of the [[Zemene Mesafint#Wara Sheh rulers (Yejju) (1784–1855)|Wara Sheh]], including Ras [[Gugsa of Yejju]]. Before the Zemene Mesafint, Emperor Iyoas I had introduced the Oromo language (''Afaan Oromo'') at court, replacing Amharic.

=== Age of Imperialism (1855–1916) ===
{{Multiple image
| direction         = horizontal
| image1            = Téwodros II - 2.jpg
| caption1          = Emperor [[Tewodros II]] (r. 1855–1868) brought an end to Zemene Mesafint.
| image2            = Menelik - Adoua-2 (cropped).jpg
| caption2          = Emperor [[Menelik II]] defended 's sovereignty during the age of imperialism.
| total_width       = 320
}}
{{main| expedition to Abyssinia|Menelik's Invasions|– War|First Italo- War|Mahdist War}} isolationism ended following a  mission that concluded with an alliance between the two nations, but it was not until 1855 that the Amhara kingdoms of northern  (Gondar, [[Gojjam]], and [[Shewa]]) were briefly united after the power of the emperor was restored beginning with the reign of [[Tewodros II]]. Tewodros II began a process of consolidation, centralisation, and state-building that would be continued by succeeding emperors. This process reduced the power of regional rulers, restructured the empire's administration, and created a professional army. These changes created the basis for establishing the effective sovereignty and territorial integrity of the  state. In 1875 and 1876, Ottoman and  forces, accompanied by many European and  advisors, twice [[– War|invaded Abyssinia]] but were initially defeated. From 1885 to 1889 (under [[Yohannes IV]]),  joined the [[Mahdist War]] allied to Britain, the Ottomans, and  against the  Mahdist State. In 1887, [[Menelik II]], king of [[Shewa]], invaded the [[Emirate of Harar]] after his victory at the [[Battle of Chelenqo]]. On 10 March 1889, Yohannes IV was killed by the  Khalifah Abdullah's army whilst leading his army in the [[Battle of Gallabat]].

, in roughly its current form, began under the reign of Menelik II, who was Emperor from 1889 until his death in 1913. From his base in the central province of Shewa, Menelik set out to annex territories to the south, east, and west — areas inhabited by the Oromo, [[Sidama people|Sidama]], Gurage, [[Welayta people|Welayta]], and other peoples. He achieved this with the help of ''Ras'' [[Gobana Dacche]]'s Shewan Oromo militia, which occupied lands that had not been held since [[Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi]]'s war, as well as other areas that had never been under  rule.

For his leadership, despite opposition from more traditional elements of society, Menelik II was heralded as a national hero. He had signed the [[Treaty of Wuchale]] with  in May 1889, by which  would recognize 's sovereignty so long as  could control an area north of  (now part of modern ). In return,  was to provide Menelik with weapons and support him as emperor. The  used the time between the signing of the treaty and its ratification by the  government to expand their territorial claims. This [[First Italo- War]] culminated in the [[Battle of Adwa]] on 1 March 1896, in which 's colonial forces were defeated by the . During this time, about a third of the population died in the [[Famines in |Great  Famine]] (1888 to 1892), and the [[1890s African rinderpest epizootic|rinderpest]] swept through the area, destroying much of the herd economy. On 11 October 1897,  adopted the [[Pan-African colours|colours of the pan-African flag]] with green, yellow and red stripes in representation of [[pan-Africanist]] ideology.

===Haile Selassie I era (1916–1974)===
{{main|Second Italo- War| | East Africa|Federation of  and | War of Independence}}
[[File: Soldiers  War.jpg|thumb| troops sent by the government under the [[Haile Selassie|Emperor Haile Selassie I]] during the [[ War]] fighting for South  independence]]
[[File:Emperor Haile Selassie I with President FDR.jpg|thumb|[[Haile Selassie|Emperor Haile Selassie I]] with U.S. president [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] during the end of World War II]]
The early 20th century was marked by the reign of Emperor [[Haile Selassie]] (''Ras Tafari''). He came to power after [[Lij Iyasu]] was deposed, and undertook [[Modernization under Haile Selassie|a nationwide modernization campaign]] from 1916 when he was made a ''Ras'' and Regent (''Inderase'') for the [[Queen regnant|Empress Regnant]] [[Zewditu]], and became the ''de facto'' ruler of the  Empire. Following Zewditu's death, on 2 November 1930, he succeeded her as emperor. In 1931, Haile Selassie endowed  with [[1931 Constitution of |its first constitution]] in emulation of Imperial 's [[Meiji Constitution|1890 Constitution]].
The independence of  was interrupted by the [[Second Italo- War]], beginning when it was invaded by [[Kingdom of #Fascist regime (1922–1943)|]] in early October 1935, and by subsequent  rule of the country (1936–1941) after  victory in the war. , however, never managed to secure the country in its totality, due to resistance from the [[Arbegnoch]]; this made , along with [[]], the only African countries to never be fully colonized. Following the entry of  into [[World War II]], [[ Empire]] forces, together with the Arbegnoch, liberated  in the course of the [[East African campaign (World War II)|East African campaign]] in 1941. The country was placed under [[Occupied Enemy Territory Administration ()| military administration]], and then 's full [[sovereignty]] was restored with the signing of the [[Anglo- Agreement]] in December 1944.

On 24 October 1945,  became a founding member of the [[United Nations]]. In 1952, Haile Selassie orchestrated a [[Federation of  and |federation with ]]. He dissolved this in 1962 and annexed , resulting in the [[ War of Independence]]. Haile Selassie also played a leading role in the formation of the [[Organisation of African Unity]] (OAU). Opinion within  turned against Haile Selassie, owing to the worldwide [[1973 oil crisis]] causing a sharp increase in gasoline prices starting on 13 February 1974, leading to student and worker protests. The feudal oligarchical cabinet of [[Aklilu Habte-Wold]] was toppled, and a new government was formed with [[Endelkachew Makonnen]] serving as Prime Minister.

===Derg era (1974–1991)===
{{see also| Revolution|Derg|People's Democratic Republic of | Civil War|Red Terror (){{!}}Red Terror|1983–1985 famine in }}
[[File:Mengistu Haile Mariam 3.jpg|thumb|[[Mengistu Haile Mariam]] was sentenced to death [[Trial in absentia|''in absentia'']] for committing [[Red Terror ()|crimes during his rule]].|164x164px]]

Haile Selassie's rule ended on 12 September 1974, when he was [[1974  coup d'état|deposed]] by the [[Derg]], a committee made up of military and police officers. After the execution of [[Massacre of the Sixty|60 former government and military officials]], the new [[Provisional Military Administrative Council]] abolished the monarchy in March 1975 and established  as a [[Marxist-Leninist state]]. The abolition of [[feudalism]], increased [[literacy]], [[nationalization]], and sweeping [[land reform]] including the [[Resettlement and villagization in |resettlement and villagization]] from the [[ Highlands]] became priorities.

After a power struggle in 1977, [[Mengistu Haile Mariam]] gained undisputed leadership of the Derg. In 1977, , which had previously been receiving assistance and arms from the [[USSR]], invaded  in the [[Ogaden War]], capturing part of the [[Ogaden]] region.  recovered it after it began receiving massive military aid from the Soviet bloc countries. By the end of the seventies, Mengistu presided over the second-largest army in all of [[sub-Saharan Africa]], as well as a formidable [[ Air Force|air force]] and navy.

In 1976–78, up to 500,000 were killed as a result of the [[Red Terror ()|Red Terror]], a violent [[political repression]] campaign by the Derg against various opposition groups. In 1987, the Derg dissolved itself and established the [[People's Democratic Republic of ]] (PDRE) upon the adoption of the [[1987 Constitution of ]]. A [[1983–1985 famine in |1983–85 famine]] affected around 8 million people, resulting in 1 million dead. Insurrections against [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] rule sprang up, particularly in the northern regions of  and Tigray. The [[Tigray People's Liberation Front]] (TPLF) merged with other ethnically based opposition movements in 1989, to form the [[ People's Revolutionary Democratic Front]] (EPRDF).

The collapse of [[Marxism–Leninism]] during the [[revolutions of 1989]] coincided with the Soviet Union stopping aid to  altogether in 1990. EPRDF forces advanced on Addis Ababa in May 1991, and Mengistu fled the country and was granted asylum in .

===<span id="AnchorFederal">Federal Democratic Republic (1991–present)</span>===
{{main|History of the Federal Democratic Republic of }}
{{Further|– border conflict| civil conflict (2018–present)|Tigray war}}{{See also|1993  independence referendum}}
[[File: Civil War (2020-present).svg|thumb|[[ civil conflict (2018–present)| civil conflict]]: territorial control as of September 2023{{efn|
* '''Pro-federal government troops'''
** {{leftlegend|#fcadad|[[Government of | federal government]] and regional allies}}
** {{leftlegend|#8b98f0ff|[[ Defence Forces]]}}
** {{leftlegend|#cbc6d9|[[Government of | federal government]] and [[ Defence Forces]]}}
* '''Anti-federal government rebels'''
** {{leftlegend|#ffff44|[[Oromo Liberation Army]]}}
** {{leftlegend|#b4b2ae|[[Fano (militia)|Fano]] (Amhara militia)}}
}}]]
In July 1991, the EPRDF convened a National Conference to establish the [[Transitional Government of ]] composed of an 87-member [[Council of Representatives of |Council of Representatives]] and guided by a national charter that functioned as a transitional constitution.{{sfn|Lyons|1996|pp=121–23}} In 1994, a new constitution was written that established a parliamentary republic with a bicameral legislature and a judicial system.

In April 1993, [[]] gained independence from  after a [[1993  independence referendum|national referendum]]. In May 1998, a border dispute with  led to the [[– War]], which lasted until June 2000 and cost both countries an estimated $1&nbsp;million a day. This had a negative effect on 's economy, and a [[– border conflict|border conflict]] between the two countries would continue [[2018 – summit|until 2018]]. As of 2018, further [[ civil conflict (2018–present)|civil war in ]] continues, mainly due to destabilization of the country.

[[Human rights in #Ethnic violence|Ethnic violence rose]] during the late 2010s and early 2020s, with various clashes and conflicts leading to millions of  being displaced.

The federal government decided that elections for 2020 (later being [[2021  general election|rescheduled to 2021]]) be cancelled, due to health and safety concerns about [[COVID-19 pandemic in |COVID-19]]. The [[Tigray Region]]'s TPLF opposed this, and [[2020 Tigray regional election|proceeded to hold elections]] anyway on 9 September 2020. Relations between the federal government and Tigray deteriorated rapidly, and in November 2020,  began a military offensive in Tigray in response to [[Northern Command attacks ()|attacks on army units stationed]] there, marking the beginning of the [[Tigray war]]. By March 2022, as many as 500,000 people had died as a result of [[War crimes in the Tigray war|violence]] and [[Famine in northern  (2020–present)|famine]]. After a number of [[Tigrayan peace process|peace and mediation proposals]] in the intervening years,  and the Tigrayan rebel forces agreed to a [[–Tigray peace agreement|cessation of hostilities on 2 November 2022]]. Coupled with [[OLA insurgency]], the federal government relations with Fano militias, who previously allied to the government in the Tigray War, deteriorated in mid-2023, resulting in a [[War in Amhara|war in the Amhara Region]]. According to reports conducted by the [[ Human Rights Commission]] (EHRC), mass human rights violations carried out by ENDF troops including door-to-door searches, extrajudicial killings, massacres and detentions. Notable incident includes the [[Merawi massacre]] in early 2024, which left 50 to 100 residents dead in [[Merawi, |Merawi]] town in Amhara.
==History==
{{Main|History of }}

===Early history===
{{further|Early Slavs}}
From 5000 to 2000 BC, the [[Bandkeramik]] predominated in what now constitutes , and the [[Cimmerians]] as well as other pastoralists roamed through the area by 1,000 BC. The [[Zarubintsy culture]] later became widespread at the beginning of the [[1st millennium]]. In addition, remains from the [[Dnieper–Donets culture]] were found in  and parts of . The region was first permanently settled by [[Baltic peoples|Baltic]] tribes in the 3rd century. Around the 5th century, the area was taken over by the Slavs. The takeover was partially due to the lack of military coordination of the Balts, but their gradual assimilation into Slavic culture was peaceful. Invaders from [[Asia]], among whom were the [[Huns]] and [[Avars (Carpathians)|Avars]], swept through c. 400–600 AD, but were unable to dislodge the Slavic presence.

===Kievan Rus'===
{{further|Kievan Rus'}}
[[File:001 Kievan Rus' Kyivan Rus'  map 1220 1240.jpg|thumb|upright|[[List of early East Slavic states|Principalities]] in Eastern Europe before the Mongol and  invasions]]
In the 9th century, the territory of modern  became part of [[Kievan Rus']], a vast East Slavic state ruled by the [[Rurikids]]. Upon the death of its ruler [[Yaroslav the Wise]] in 1054, the state split into independent principalities. The [[Battle on the Nemiga River]] in 1067 was one of the more notable events of the period, the date of which is considered the founding date of [[Minsk]].

Many early principalities were virtually razed or severely affected by a major [[Mongol invasion of Kievan Rus'|Mongol invasion]] in the 13th century, but the lands of modern-day  avoided the brunt of the invasion and eventually joined the [[Grand Duchy of ]]. There are no sources of military seizure, but the annals affirm the alliance and united foreign policy of [[Principality of Polotsk|Polotsk]] and  for decades.

Incorporation into the Grand Duchy of  resulted in an economic, political, and ethno-cultural unification of  lands. Of the principalities held by the duchy, nine of them were settled by a population that would eventually become the . During this time, the duchy was involved in several military campaigns, including fighting on the side of [[Kingdom of  (1025–1385)|]] against the [[Teutonic Knights]] at the [[Battle of Grunwald]] in 1410; the joint victory allowed the duchy to control the northwestern borderlands of [[Eastern Europe]].

The [[Grand Duchy of Moscow|Muscovites]], led by [[Ivan III of ]], began military campaigns in 1486 in an attempt to incorporate the former lands of [[Kievan Rus']], including the territories of modern-day  and .

===– Commonwealth===
{{Further|– Commonwealth}}
[[File:GDL Map, 15cent.png|thumb|A map of the [[Grand Duchy of ]] in the 15th century prior to its union with the [[Crown of the Kingdom of |Kingdom of ]].  was fully within its borders.]]

On 2 February 1386, the Grand Duchy of  and the [[Kingdom of  (1025–1385)|Kingdom of ]] were joined in a [[personal union]] through a [[Union of Krewo|marriage of their rulers]]. This union set in motion the developments that eventually resulted in the formation of the [[– Commonwealth]], created in 1569 by the [[Union of Lublin]].

In the years following the union, the process of gradual [[Polonization]] of both  and Ruthenians gained steady momentum. In culture and social life, both the [[ language]] and [[Catholicism]] became dominant, and in 1696,  replaced Ruthenian as the official language, with Ruthenian being banned from administrative use. However, the Ruthenian peasants continued to speak their native language. Also, the [[ Byzantine Catholic Church]] was formed by the Poles to bring Orthodox Christians into the [[Holy See|See of Rome]]. The  church entered into a full [[Koinonia|communion]] with the [[Latin Church]] through the [[Union of Brest]] in 1595, while keeping its Byzantine [[liturgy]] in the [[Church Slavonic]] language.

=== Empire===
{{main| history in the  Empire}}

{{Further|Kościuszko Uprising|November Uprising|January Uprising}}
[[File:Berezyna.jpg|thumb|Napoleon's ''Grande Armée'' retreating after [[Napoleon's invasion of |his invasion of ]] and crossing the [[Berezina river]] (near [[Barysaw]], )]]
The union between  and  ended in 1795 with the [[Third Partition of ]] by Imperial , [[Prussia]], and [[Habsburg monarchy|]]. The  territories acquired by the  Empire under the reign of [[Catherine II of |Catherine&nbsp;II]] were included into the [[ Governorate]] ({{langx|ru|Белорусское генерал-губернаторство}}) in 1796 and held until their occupation by the [[ Empire]] during [[World War I]].

Under [[Nicholas I of |Nicholas I]] and [[Alexander III of |Alexander III]] the national cultures were repressed with policies of [[Polonization]] replaced by [[Russification]] which included the return to [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox Christianity]] of  [[Union of Brest|Uniates]].  language was banned in schools while in nearby [[Samogitia]] primary school education with [[Samogitian dialect|Samogitian]] literacy was allowed.

In a [[Russification]] drive in the 1840s, [[Nicholas I of |Nicholas I]] prohibited the use of the  language in public schools, campaigned against  publications, and tried to pressure those who had converted to Catholicism under the Poles to reconvert to the Orthodox faith. In 1863, economic and cultural pressure exploded in a [[January Uprising|revolt]], led by [[Konstanty Kalinowski]] (also known as Kastus). After the failed revolt, the  government reintroduced the use of [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] to  in 1864 and no documents in  were permitted by the  government until 1905.

During the negotiations of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk (–Central Powers)|Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]],  first declared independence under  occupation on 25 March 1918, forming the [[ People's Republic]]. Immediately afterwards, the [[–Soviet War]] ignited, and the territory of  was divided between  and Soviet . The Rada of the  Democratic Republic exists as a [[government in exile]] ever since then; in fact, it is currently the world's longest serving government in exile.

===Early states and interwar period===
[[File:Dziejačy BNR.jpg|thumb|right|The first government ("activists") of the  People's Republic (BNR, Беларуская Народная Рэспубліка), 1918.<br />Sitting, left to right:<br />[[Aliaksandar Burbis]], [[Jan Sierada]], [[Jazep Varonka]], [[Vasil Zacharka]].<br />Standing, left to right:<br />[[Arkadź Smolič]], [[Pyotra Krecheuski]], [[Kastuś Jezavitaŭ]], Anton Ausianik, Liavon Zayats.]]
The [[ People's Republic]] was the first attempt to create an independent  state under the name "". Despite significant efforts, the state ceased to exist, primarily because the territory was continually dominated by the [[Imperial  Army]] and the [[Imperial  Army]] in [[World War I]], and then the [[Bolshevik]] [[Red Army]]. It existed from only 1918 to 1919 but created prerequisites for the formation of a  state. The choice of name was probably based on the fact that core members of the newly formed government were educated in tsarist universities, with corresponding emphasis on the ideology of West-Russianism.

The [[Republic of Central ]] was a short-lived political entity, which was the last attempt to restore  to the historical confederacy state (it was also supposed to create  Upper and  Lower). The republic was created in 1920 following [[Żeligowski's Mutiny|the staged rebellion]] of soldiers of the [[1st – Division]] of the [[ Army]] under [[Lucjan Żeligowski]]. Centered on the historical capital of the [[Grand Duchy of ]], [[Vilna]] ({{langx|lt|Vilnius}}, {{langx|pl|Wilno}}), for 18 months the entity served as a [[buffer state]] between [[]], upon which it depended, and , which claimed the area. After a variety of delays, [[1922 Republic of Central  general election|a disputed election]] took place on 8 January 1922, and the territory was annexed to . Żeligowski later in his memoir which was published in London in 1943 condemned the annexation of the Republic by , as well as the policy of closing  schools and general disregard of Marshal [[Józef Piłsudski]]'s confederation plans by  ally.

[[File:Kurapaty 1989 meeting.jpg|thumb|Meeting in the [[Kurapaty]] woods, 1989, where between 1937 and 1941 from 30,000 to 250,000 people, including  [[intelligentsia]] members, were [[Soviet repressions in |murdered]] by the [[NKVD]] during the [[Great Purge]]]]

In January 1919, a part of  under Bolshevik  control was declared the [[Socialist Soviet Republic of Byelorussia]] (SSRB) for just two months, but then merged with the [[ Soviet Socialist Republic]] (LSSR) to form the [[Socialist Soviet Republic of  and Belorussia]] (SSR LiB), which lost control of its territories by August.

The [[Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic]] (BSSR) was created in July 1920.

The contested lands were divided between  and the [[Soviet Union]] after the war ended in 1921, and the Byelorussian SSR became a founding member of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in 1922. In the 1920s and 1930s, Soviet agricultural and economic policies, including [[collectivization]] and [[Five-year plans of the Soviet Union|five-year plans for the national economy]], led to famine and political repression.

The [[Western Belorussia|western part of modern ]] remained part of the [[Second  Republic]]. After an early period of liberalization, tensions between increasingly nationalistic  government and various increasingly separatist ethnic minorities started to grow, and the [[ minority in | minority]] was no exception. The [[polonization]] drive was inspired and influenced by the  [[National Democracy ()|National Democracy]], led by [[Roman Dmowski]], who advocated refusing  and  the right for a free national development. A  organization, the ''[[ Peasants' and Workers' Union]]'', was banned in 1927, and opposition to  government was met with state repressions. Nonetheless, compared to the (larger) [[ minority in | minority]],  were much less politically aware and active, and thus suffered fewer repressions than the . In 1935, after the death of Piłsudski, a new wave of repressions was released upon the minorities, with many [[ Orthodox Church|Orthodox churches]] and  schools being closed. Use of the [[ language]] was discouraged.  leadership was sent to [[Bereza Kartuska prison]].

===World War II===
{{main|Byelorussia in World War II| occupation of Byelorussia during World War II}}

[[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 101I-137-1010-37A, Minsk, deutsche Truppen vor modernen Gebäuden.jpg|thumb|upright| soldiers in [[Minsk]], August 1941]]
[[File:Hatiny1.jpg|thumb|upright=1|[[Khatyn]] Memorial; during World War II the  Nazis murdered civilians in 5,295 different localities in [[Occupation of  by Nazi |occupied Soviet ]].]]
In September 1939, the Soviet Union invaded and occupied eastern , following the  [[invasion of ]] two weeks earlier which marked the beginning of [[World War II]]. The territories of [[Western Belorussia]] were [[Soviet annexation of Western Belorussia|annexed]] and incorporated into the Byelorussian SSR. The Soviet-controlled Byelorussian People's Council officially took control of the territories, whose populations consisted of a mixture of Poles, ,  and Jews, on {{nowrap|28 October}} 1939 in [[Białystok]]. Nazi  [[Operation Barbarossa|invaded the Soviet Union]] in 1941. The [[Defense of Brest Fortress|defense]] of [[Brest Fortress]] was the first major battle of [[Operation Barbarossa]].

The Byelorussian SSR was the hardest-hit Soviet republic in World War II; it remained under [[ occupation of Byelorussia during World War II| occupation]] until 1944. The  {{lang|de|[[Generalplan Ost]]}} called for the extermination, expulsion, or enslavement of most or all  to provide more [[Lebensraum|living space]] in the [[Drang nach Osten|East]] for . Most of Western  became part of the ''[[Reichskommissariat Ostland]]'' in 1941, but in 1943 the  authorities allowed local [[Byelorussian collaboration with Nazi |collaborators]] to set up a client state, the [[ Central Council]].

During World War II,  was home to a variety of [[ resistance during World War II|guerrilla movements]], including Jewish, , and Soviet partisans.  partisan formations formed a large part of the [[Soviet partisans]], and in the modern day these partisans have formed a core part of the  national identity, with  continuing to refer to itself as the "partisan republic" since the 1970s. Following the war, many former Soviet partisans entered positions of government, among them [[Pyotr Masherov]] and [[Kirill Mazurov]], both of whom were First Secretary of the Communist Party of Byelorussia. Until the late 1970s, the  government was almost entirely composed of former partisans. Numerous pieces of media have been made about the  partisans, including the 1985 film ''[[Come and See]]'' and the works of authors [[Ales Adamovich]] and [[Vasil Bykaŭ]].

The  occupation in 1941–1944 and war on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] devastated . During that time, 209 out of 290 towns and cities were destroyed, 85% of the republic's industry, and more than one million buildings. After the war, it was estimated that 2.2 million local inhabitants had died, and of those some 810,000 were combatants—some foreign. This figure represented [[World War II casualties of the Soviet Union|a staggering quarter of the prewar population]]. In the 1990s some raised the estimate even higher, to 2.7 million. The [[History of the Jews in |Jewish population of ]] was devastated during [[the Holocaust]] and never recovered. The population of  did not regain its pre-war level until 1971.  was also hit hard economically, losing around half of its economic resources.

===Post-war===
[[File:М. І. Гусеў. Плакат, выпушчаны да выбараў у Вярхоўныя Саветы БССР і СССР ад заходніх абласцей Беларусі.jpg|thumb|upright| poster where the text reads "Long live the Stalinist constitution of victorious socialism and true democracy!" (issued in 1940)]]
The borders of the Byelorussian SSR and  were redrawn, in accord with the 1919-proposed [[Curzon Line]].  Byelorus gained territory to the west: the formerly  [[Kresy]].

[[Joseph Stalin]] implemented a policy of [[Sovietization]] to isolate the Byelorussian SSR from [[Western world|Western influences]]. This policy involved sending  from various parts of the Soviet Union and placing them in key positions in the Byelorussian SSR government. After Stalin died in 1953, [[Nikita Khrushchev]] continued his predecessor's [[cultural hegemony]] program, stating, "The sooner we all start speaking , the faster we shall build communism."

Between Stalin's death in 1953 and 1980,  politics was dominated by former members of the Soviet partisans, including First Secretaries Kirill Mazurov and Pyotr Masherov. Mazurov and Masherov oversaw 's [[ economic miracle|rapid industrialisation]] and transformation from one of the Soviet Union's poorest republics into one of its richest. In 1986, the Byelorussian SSR was contaminated with most (70%) of the [[nuclear fallout]] from the explosion at the [[Chernobyl disaster|Chernobyl]] power plant located 16&nbsp;km beyond the border in the neighboring [[ Soviet Socialist Republic| SSR]].

By the late 1980s, political liberalization led to a national revival, with the [[ Popular Front]] becoming a major pro-independence force.

===Independence===
[[File:RIAN archive 848095 Signing the Agreement to eliminate the USSR and establish the Commonwealth of Independent States.jpg|thumb|upright=1|Leaders of ,  and  signed the [[Belavezha Accords]], [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union|dissolving the Soviet Union]], 8 December 1991]]
In March 1990, [[12th  Supreme Council|elections]] for seats in the [[Supreme Soviet]] of the Byelorussian SSR took place. Though the opposition candidates, mostly associated with the pro-independence [[ Popular Front]], took only 10% of the seats,  declared itself sovereign on 27 July 1990 by issuing the [[Declaration of State Sovereignty of the  Soviet Socialist Republic]].

[[1991  strikes|Wide-scale strikes]] erupted in April 1991. With the support of the [[Communist Party of Byelorussia]], the country's name was changed to the Republic of  on 25 August 1991. [[Stanislav Shushkevich]], the chairman of the Supreme Soviet of , met with [[Boris Yeltsin]] of  and [[Leonid Kravchuk]] of  on 8 December 1991 in [[Białowieża Forest]] to formally declare the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the formation of the [[Commonwealth of Independent States]].

In January 1992, the [[ Popular Front]] campaigned for early elections later in the year, two years before they were scheduled. By May of that year, about 383,000 signatures had been collected for a petition to hold the referendum, which was 23,000 more than legally required to be put to a referendum at the time. Despite this, the meeting of the [[Supreme Council of the Republic of ]] to ultimately decide the date for the referendum was delayed by six months. However, with no evidence to suggest such, the Supreme Council rejected the petition on the grounds of massive irregularities. Elections for the Supreme Council were set for March 1994. A new law on parliamentary elections failed to pass by 1993. Disputes over the referendum were accredited to the largely conservative [[Party of  Communists]], which controlled the Supreme Council at the time and was largely opposed to political and economic reform, with allegations that some of the deputies opposed  independence.

===Lukashenko era===
[[File: 1997 CIA map.jpg|thumb|1997 map of ]]
A national constitution was adopted in March 1994 in which the functions of prime minister were given to the [[President of ]]. A two-round [[1994  presidential election|election for the presidency on 24 June 1994 and 10 July 1994]] catapulted the formerly unknown Alexander Lukashenko into national prominence. He garnered 45% of the vote in the first round and 80% in the second, defeating [[Vyacheslav Kebich]] who received 14% of the vote. The elections were the first and only free elections in  after independence.

The 2000s saw some economic disputes between  and its primary economic partner, . The first one was the [[2004 – energy dispute]] when  energy giant [[Gazprom]] ceased the import of gas into  because of price disagreements. The [[2007 – energy dispute]] centered on accusations by Gazprom that  was siphoning oil from the [[Druzhba pipeline]] that runs through . Two years later the so-called [[Milk War]], a trade dispute, started when  wanted  to recognize the independence of [[Abkhazia]] and [[South Ossetia]] and through a series of events ended up banning the import of dairy products from .

In 2011,  suffered [[Economy of #Crisis of 2011|a severe economic crisis]] attributed to Lukashenko's government's centralized control of the economy, with inflation reaching 108.7%. Around the same time the [[2011 Minsk Metro bombing]] occurred in which 15 people were killed and 204 were injured. Two suspects, who were arrested within two days, confessed to being the perpetrators and were executed by shooting in 2012. The official version of events as publicised by the  government was questioned in the unprecedented wording of the [[UN Security Council]] statement condemning "the apparent terrorist attack" intimating the possibility that the  government itself was behind the bombing.

[[File:Alexander Lukashenko, opening of Slavianski Bazar 2014.jpg|thumb|[[Alexander Lukashenko]] has ruled  since 1994.]]
[[2020–2021  protests|Mass protests]] erupted across the country following the disputed [[2020  presidential election]], in which Lukashenko sought a sixth term in office.<!--  and EU leaders warned of any external interference in 's internal affairs.--> Neighbouring countries  and  do not recognize Lukashenko as the legitimate president of  and the  government has allotted a residence for main opposition candidate [[Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya]] and other members of the  opposition in [[Vilnius]]. Neither is Lukashenko recognized as the legitimate president of  by the European Union, , the  or the . The European Union, , the , and the  have all imposed sanctions against  because of the rigged election and political oppression during the ongoing protests in the country. [[International sanctions during the  invasion of |Further sanctions]] were imposed in 2022 following the [[ involvement in the  invasion of |country's role and complicity]] in the  invasion of ;  troops were allowed to stage part of the invasion from  territory. Sanctions were targeted towards not only corporate offices and individual officers of government, but also private individuals who work in the [[state-owned enterprise]] industrial sector. [[]] and [[]] have joined the sanctions regime which aims to isolate  from the international supply chain. Most major  banks are also under restrictions.
== History ==
{{Main|History of }}
{{For timeline|Timeline of  history}}

=== Prehistory and early history ===
Archaeological excavations have revealed the existence of humans in what is now  as early as the [[Paleolithic]] age. Stone artefacts excavated in [[Gia Lai province]] have been claimed to date to 780,000 years ago, based on associated find of [[tektite]]s, however this claim has been challenged because tektites are often found in archaeological sites of various ages in .  ''[[Homo erectus]]'' fossils dating to around 500,000 BC have been found in caves in [[Lạng Sơn province|Lạng Sơn]] and [[Nghệ An province|Nghệ An]] provinces in northern .{{sfn|McKinney|2009}} The oldest ''[[Homo sapiens]]'' fossils from mainland Southeast Asia are of [[Middle Pleistocene]] provenance, and include isolated tooth fragments from Tham Om and Hang Hum.{{sfn|Akazawa|Aoki|Kimura|1992|p=321}}{{sfn|Rabett|2012|p=109}}{{sfn|Dennell|Porr|2014|p=41}} Teeth attributed to ''Homo sapiens'' from the [[Late Pleistocene]] have been found at Dong Can,{{sfn|Matsumura|Yoneda|Yukio|Oxenham|2008|p=12}} and from the Early [[Holocene]] at Mai Da Dieu,{{sfn|Matsumura|Lan Cuong|Kim Thuy|Anezaki|2001}}{{sfn|Oxenham|Tayles|2006|p=36}} Lang Gao{{sfn|Nguyen|1985|p=16}}{{sfn|Karlstrom|Kallen|2002|p=83}} and Lang Cuom.{{sfn|Oxenham|Buckley|2015|p=329}} Areas comprising what is now  participated in the Maritime Jade Road, as ascertained by archaeological research.

By about 1,000 BC, the development of wet-[[rice]] cultivation in the [[Ma River]] and [[Red River (Asia)|Red River]] floodplains led to the flourishing of [[Đông Sơn culture]],{{sfn|Higham|1984}}{{sfn|Nang Chung|Giang Hai|2017|p=31}} notable for its [[bronze]] casting used to make elaborate bronze [[Đông Sơn drums]].{{sfn|de Laet|Herrmann|1996|p=408}}{{sfn|Calo|2009|p=51}}{{sfn|Kiernan|2017|p=31}} This culture spread to the rest of [[Southeast Asia]], including [[Maritime Southeast Asia]], throughout the first millennium BC.{{sfn|Calo|2009|p=51}}{{sfn|Cooke|Li|Anderson|2011|p=46}}

=== Dynastic  ===
{{For timeline|Timeline of  under  rule}}
[[File:Southeast Asian history - 13th century.png|thumb|[[Đại Việt]], [[Champa]], [[Khmer Empire|Angkor Empire]] and their neighbours, late 13th century]]
[[File:Nguyen Dynasty, administrative divisions map (1838).svg|thumb|'s territories around 1838, during the [[ invasions of | occupation of ]]]]
According to  legends, the [[Hồng Bàng dynasty]] of the [[Hùng kings]], first established in 2879 BC, is considered the first state established in  (then known as Xích Quỷ and later [[Văn Lang]]).{{sfn|Pelley|2002|p=151}} Văn Lang was established by [[Lạc Việt]] tribes,{{sfn|Kiernan|2017|p=53}} who were likely a confederacy of multilingual [[Austroasiatic languages|Austroasiatic]] and [[Kra-Dai languages|Kra-Dai]] speakers who occupied the [[Red River Delta]] in northern .{{sfn|Kiernan|2017|p=42}}

In 257 BC, the last Hùng king was defeated by Thục Phán. He consolidated the [[Lạc Việt]] and [[Âu Việt]] tribes, who came from southern , to form the [[Âu Lạc]], proclaiming himself [[An Dương Vương]].{{sfn|Duc Tran|Thu Ha|2000|p=8}}

In 179 BC, a  general named [[Zhao Tuo]] ("Triệu Đà") defeated An Dương Vương and consolidated Âu Lạc into [[Nanyue]].{{sfn|Nang Chung|Giang Hai|2017|p=31}} However, Nanyue was itself [[Southward expansion of the Han dynasty|incorporated into the empire]] of the  [[Han dynasty]] in 111 BC after the [[Han–Nanyue War]].{{sfn|Ooi|2004|p=932}}{{sfn|Yao|2016|p=62}} Before the Han dynasty's invasion,  was marked by a vibrant mix of religion, culture, and social norms. For the next thousand years, what is now northern  remained mostly under [[ domination of | rule]].{{sfn|Holmgren|1980}}{{sfn|Taylor|1983|p=30}}{{sfn|Buttinger|1968|p=18, Ch.2}} Early independence movements, such as those of the [[Trưng Sisters]] and [[Lady Triệu]],{{sfn|Pelley|2002|p=177}} were temporarily successful,{{sfn|Cottrell|2009|p=15}} though the region gained a longer period of independence as Vạn Xuân under the [[Anterior Lý dynasty]] between AD 544 and 602.{{sfn| Nguyen|Mung Nguyen|1958|p=33}}{{sfn|Chesneaux|1966|p=20}}{{sfn|University of California|1972|p=24}}{{verify source|date=December 2024}} By the early 10th century, northern  had gained autonomy, but not sovereignty, under the [[Khúc family]].{{sfn|Tuyet Tran|Reid|2006|p=32}}

In AD 938, the  lord [[Ngô Quyền]] defeated the forces of the  [[Southern Han]] state at [[Battle of Bạch Đằng (938)|Bạch Đằng River]] and achieved full independence for  in 939 after a millennium of  domination.{{sfn|Hien Le|2003|p=65}}{{sfn|Hong Lien|Sharrock|2014|p=55}}{{sfn|Kiernan|2017|p=226}} By the 960s, the dynastic [[Đại Việt]] (''Great Viet'') kingdom was established, and  society enjoyed a golden era under the Lý and [[Trần dynasty|Trần]] dynasties. During the rule of the Trần dynasty, Đại Việt repelled three [[Mongol invasions of |Mongol invasions]].{{sfn|Cottrell|2009|p=16}}{{sfn|Hong Lien|Sharrock|2014|p=95}} Meanwhile, the [[Mahāyāna]] branch of [[Buddhism in |Buddhism]] flourished and became the state religion.{{sfn|Kiernan|2017|p=226}}{{sfn|Keyes|1995|p=183}} Following the 1406–7 [[Ming–Hồ War]], which overthrew the [[Hồ dynasty]],  independence was [[Fourth  domination of |interrupted briefly]] by the  [[Ming dynasty]], but was restored by [[Lê Lợi]], the founder of the [[Lê dynasty]].{{sfn|Hong Lien|Sharrock|2014|p=111}} The  polity reached their zenith in the Lê dynasty of the 15th century, especially during the reign of emperor [[Lê Thánh Tông]] (1460–1497).{{sfn|Hong Lien|Sharrock|2014|p=120}}{{sfn|Kiernan|2017|p=265}} Between the 11th and 18th centuries, the  polity expanded southward in a gradual process known as {{lang|vi|[[Nam tiến]]}} ("Southward expansion"),{{sfn|Anderson|Whitmore|2014|p=158}} eventually conquering the kingdom of [[Champa]] and part of the [[Post-Angkor Period|Khmer Kingdom]].{{sfn|Vo|2011|p=13}}{{sfn|Ooi|Anh Tuan|2015|p=212}}{{sfn|Phuong Linh|2016|p=39}}

From the 16th century onward, civil strife and frequent political infighting engulfed much of Đại Việt. First, the -supported [[Mạc dynasty]] challenged the Lê dynasty's power.{{sfn|Anderson|Whitmore|2014|p=174}} After the Mạc dynasty was defeated, the Lê dynasty was nominally reinstalled. Actual power, however, was divided between the northern [[Trịnh lords]] and the southern [[Nguyễn lords]], who engaged in a [[Trịnh–Nguyễn War|civil war]] for more than four decades before a truce was called in the 1670s.{{sfn|Leonard|1984|p=131}}  was divided into North (Trịnh) and South (Nguyễn) from 1600 to 1777. During this period, the Nguyễn expanded into the [[Mekong Delta]], annexing the [[Central Highlands ()|Central Highlands]] and the Khmer lands in the Mekong Delta.{{sfn|Vo|2011|p=13}}{{sfn|Phuong Linh|2016|p=39}}{{sfn|Ooi|2004|p=356}} The division of the country ended a century later when the [[Tây Sơn]] brothers helped Trịnh to end Nguyễn; they also established a new dynasty and ended Trịnh. However, their rule did not last long, and they were defeated by the remnants of the Nguyễn lords, led by [[Gia Long|Nguyễn Ánh]]. Nguyễn Ánh unified , and established the [[Nguyễn dynasty]], ruling under the name [[Gia Long]].{{sfn|Ooi|2004|p=356}}

===  Indochina ===
{{Further|Cochinchina campaign|Tonkin campaign|Sino- War| Indochina}}

In the 1500s, the [[ Empire|]] explored the  coast and reportedly erected a [[stele]] on the [[Chàm Islands]] to mark their presence.{{sfn|Hoang|2007|p=50}} By 1533, they began landing in the  delta but were forced to leave because of local turmoil and fighting. They also had less interest in the territory than they did in  and .{{sfn|Hoang|2007|p=50}} After they had settled in [[ Macau|Macau]] and [[ Nagasaki|Nagasaki]] to begin the profitable Macau– trade route, the  began to involve themselves in trade with [[Hội An]].{{sfn|Hoang|2007|p=50}}  traders and [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]] missionaries under the ''[[Padroado]]'' system were active in both  realms of ''[[Đàng Trong]]'' ([[Cochinchina]] or Quinan) and ''[[Đàng Ngoài]]'' ([[Tonkin]]) in the 17th century.{{sfn|Tran|2018}} The [[ Empire|]] also tried to establish contact with Quinan in 1601 but failed to sustain a presence there after several violent encounters with the locals. The [[ East  Company]] (VOC) only managed to establish official relations with Tonkin in the spring of 1637 after leaving [[Dejima]] in  to establish trade for [[silk]].{{sfn|Hoang|2007|p=52}} Meanwhile, in 1613, the first [[Kingdom of England|]] attempt to establish contact with Hội An failed following a violent incident involving the [[East  Company]]. By 1672, the  did establish relations with Tonkin and were allowed to reside in [[Hưng Yên|Phố Hiến]].{{sfn|Hoang|2007|p=53}}
[[File:Prise de Saigon 18 Fevrier 1859 Antoine Morel-Fatio.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|[[Siege of Saigon|Capture of Saigon]] by [[Charles Rigault de Genouilly]] on 18 February 1859]]
Between 1615 and 1753,  traders also engaged in trade in .{{sfn|Li|1998|p=89}}{{sfn|Lockard|2010|p=479}} The first  missionaries<!--Joseph Francis Tissanier and Pierre Jacques Albier, SJ--> arrived in 1658, under the  ''Padroado''. From its foundation, the [[Paris Foreign Missions Society]] under [[Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples|''Propaganda Fide'']] actively sent missionaries to , entering Cochinchina first<!--Louis Chevreuil--> in 1664 and Tonkin first<!--François Deydier--> in 1666.{{sfn|Tran|2017|p=27}}  [[ Order|]] joined the Tonkin mission in 1676, and [[Franciscans]] were in Cochinchina from 1719 to 1834. The  authorities began{{when|date=October 2020}} to feel threatened by continuous [[Christianisation]] activities.{{sfn|McLeod|1991|p=22}} After several Catholic missionaries were detained, the [[ Navy]] intervened in 1843 to free them, as the kingdom was perceived as [[xenophobic]].{{sfn|Woods|2002|p=42}} In a series of conquests from 1859 to 1885, [[ colonial empire| eroded]] 's sovereignty.{{sfn|Cortada|1994|p=29}} At the [[siege of Tourane]] in 1858,  was aided by [[ Empire|]] (with , [[Latin  Asian|Latin ]], and  troops from the [[]]) and perhaps some Tonkinese Catholics.{{sfn|Keith|2012|p=46}} After the [[Treaty of Saigon (1862)|1862 Treaty]], and especially after  completely conquered [[Southern |Lower Cochinchina]] in 1867, the [[Văn Thân movement]] of scholar-gentry class arose and committed violence against [[Catholic Church|Catholics]] across central and northern .{{sfn|Keith|2012|pp=49–50}}

Between 1862 and 1867, the southern third of the country became the [[ Cochinchina| colony of Cochinchina]].{{sfn|McLeod|1991|p=61}} By 1884, the entire country was under  rule, with the central and northern parts of  separated into the two protectorates of [[Annam ( protectorate)|Annam]] and [[Tonkin ( protectorate)|Tonkin]]. The three entities were formally integrated into the union of [[ Indochina]] in 1887.{{sfn|Ooi|2004|p=520}}{{sfn|Cook|2001|p=396}} The  administration imposed significant political and cultural changes on  society.{{sfn|Frankum|2011|p=172}} A Western-style system of modern education introduced new [[humanism|humanist]] values.{{sfn|Nhu Nguyen|2016|p=37}} Most  settlers in Indochina were concentrated in Cochinchina, particularly in [[Saigon]], and in [[Hanoi]], the colony's capital.{{sfn|Richardson|1876|p=269}}

During the early colonial period, guerrillas of the royalist [[Cần Vương movement]] rebelled against  rule and massacred around a third of [[Christianity in |'s Christian]] population.{{sfn|Keith|2012|p=53}} Anti-Catholic violence persisted in Nam Định, Quảng Trị, and Bình Định during the 1880s.{{sfn|Ramsay|2008|p=171}} The  strategy for pacification in  relied more on alliances with local notables than on Christian missions to establish control and manage resistance.{{sfn|Quach-Langlet|1991|p=361}} The  developed a [[plantation economy]] to promote export of [[tobacco]], [[indigo dye|indigo]], [[tea]] and [[coffee]].{{sfn|Lim|2014|p=33}} However, they largely ignored the increasing demands for civil rights and [[self-government]]. An increasing dissatisfaction even led to half-hearted, badly coordinated, and still worse executed plots to oust the , like the infamous [[Hanoi Poison Plot]] of 1908. Another large-scale rebellion, the [[Thái Nguyên uprising]] in 1917, was also suppressed heavily.{{sfn|Zinoman|2000}} 
[[File:ExpositionHanoi1902 GrandPalais (1).jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|alt=Photograph of the Grand Palais building in Hanoi|The [[Grand Palais (Hanoi)|Grand Palais]] built for the [[Hanoi exhibition|1902–1903 world's fair]], when [[Hanoi]] became  Indochina's capital]]
A nationalist political movement soon emerged, with leaders like [[Phan Bội Châu]], [[Phan Châu Trinh]], [[Phan Đình Phùng]], Emperor [[Hàm Nghi]], and [[Ho Chi Minh]] fighting or calling for independence.{{sfn|Largo|2002|p=112}} This resulted in the 1930 [[Yên Bái mutiny]] by the [[Việt Nam Quốc Dân Đảng| Nationalist Party]] (VNQDĐ), which the  quashed. The mutiny split the independence movement, as many leading members converted to [[communism]].{{sfn|Khanh Huynh|1986|p=98}}{{sfn|Odell|Castillo|2008|p=82}}{{sfn|Thomas|2012}}

The  maintained full control of their colonies until World War II, when the [[Pacific War|war in the Pacific]] led to the [[ invasion of  Indochina]] in 1940. Afterwards, the [[Empire of | Empire]] was allowed to station its troops in  while the pro-[[Vichy |Vichy ]] colonial administration continued.{{sfn|Miller|1990|p=293}}{{sfn|Gettleman|Franklin|Young|Franklin|1995|p=4}}  exploited 's natural resources to support its military campaigns, culminating in a [[ coup d'état in  Indochina|full-scale takeover of the country]] in March 1945. This led to the [[ famine of 1944–1945]], which killed up to two million people.{{sfn|Thanh Nien|2015}}{{sfn|'' Net''|2015}}

=== First Indochina War ===
{{Further|Civil conflicts in  (1945–1949)|First Indochina War|1954 Geneva Conference}}
In 1941, the [[Viet Minh|Việt Minh]], a communist-led national liberation movement, emerged under [[Ho Chi Minh]]'s leadership.{{sfn|Joes|1992|p=95}}{{sfn|Pike|2011|p=192}} Mass political mobilization intensified during the [[ Indochina in World War II| military occupation of Indochina]], and nationalist parties fostered a stronger sense of national identity. After 's defeat in World War II, the Việt Minh seized Hanoi and Huế in August 1945, dissolved the [[Empire of ]], and established a provisional government that declared national independence on 2 September.{{sfn|Pike|2011|p=192}} In the south, Saigon's administrative services collapsed, and chaos, riots, and murder were widespread.{{sfn|Gunn|2014|p=270}} 

In August 1945, the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] had decided to divide Indochina at the [[16th parallel north|16th parallel]] to allow [[Chiang Kai-shek]] of the [[Republic of  (1912–1949)|Republic of ]] to [[ occupation of northern , 1945–1946|receive the  surrender in the north]] while Britain's [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of |Lord Louis Mountbatten]] received their surrender in the south. The Allies agreed that Indochina still belonged to .{{sfn|Neville|2007|p=175}}{{sfn|Smith|2007|p=6}}

[[File: Indochina post partition.png|thumb|left|alt=Map showing the partition of  Indochina following the 1954 Geneva Conference | [[Partition (politics)|Partition]] of  Indochina after the [[1954 Geneva Conference]]]]
But as the  were weakened by the [[ military administration in occupied  during World War II| occupation]], [[ Raj|-]] forces and the remaining  [[Southern Expeditionary Army Group]] were used to maintain order and help  reestablish control through the [[War in  (1945–1946)|1945–1946 War in ]], south of the 16th parallel.{{sfn|Neville|2007|p=124}} The Viet Minh sought to consolidate power by terrorizing and purging rival  [[ nationalism|nationalist groups]] and [[Trotskyism in |Trotskyist leaders]].{{sfn|Guillemot|2004}}{{sfn|Kort|2017|pages=62–63, 81–85}}{{sfn|Tran|2022|pages=24–30}}{{sfn|Marr|2013|pages=383–441}} In 1946, the Franco- and [[Ho–Sainteny Agreement]]s enabled  forces to replace the  north of the 16th parallel and facilitated a coexistence between the DRV and the  that strengthened the Viet Minh while undermining the nationalists.{{sfn|Goscha|2016|pages=204–208}}{{sfn|Holcombe |2020|pages=35, 38–44}} That summer, the Viet Minh, in collaboration with  forces, eliminated rival nationalist parties.{{sfn|Kort|2017|pages=83–84}}{{sfn|Reilly|2018|pages=175–177}}{{sfn|Guillemot|2004|pages=205–207}}{{sfn|Tran|2023|pages=699–700}} Hồ chose to take a compromising stance to avoid military conflict with , asking the  to withdraw their colonial administrators and for  professors and engineers to help build a modern independent .{{sfn|Pike|2011|p=192}} But [[Provisional Government of the  Republic|]] did not act on these requests, including the idea of independence, and dispatched the [[ Far East Expeditionary Corps]] to restore colonial rule. With negotiations having broken down,{{sfn|Asselin|2024|pages=73–81}} tensions between the Viet Minh and  authorities erupted into the full-scale [[First Indochina War]] in December 1946.{{sfn|Joes|1992|p=95}}{{sfn|Pike|2011|p=192}}{{sfn|Tonnesson|2011|p=66}} Surviving nationalist partisans and politico-religious groups rallied behind the exiled [[Bảo Đại]] to reopen negotiations with [[ Fourth Republic|]], ultimately establishing the [[State of ]] in opposition to communist domination.{{sfn|Goscha|2016|pages=238–247}} The defeat of [[ Union]] forces in the 1954 [[Battle of Điện Biên Phủ]] allowed Hồ to negotiate a ceasefire from a favourable position at the subsequent [[1954 Geneva Conference|Geneva Conference]].{{sfn|Pike|2011|p=192}}{{sfn|Waite|2012|p=89}}

The colonial administration was thereby ended and  Indochina was dissolved under the Geneva Accords of 21 July 1954 into three countries—, and the kingdoms of [[Kingdom of  (1953–1970)|]] and [[Kingdom of |]].  was further divided into North and South administrative regions at the [[ Demilitarised Zone|Demilitarised Zone]], roughly along the [[17th parallel north]] (pending elections scheduled for July 1956{{efn|Neither the  government nor Ngô Đình Diệm's State of  signed anything at the 1954 Geneva Conference. The non-communist  delegation objected strenuously to any division of ; however, the  accepted the Việt Minh proposal{{sfn|Gravel|1971|p=134}} that  be united by elections under the supervision of "local commissions".{{sfn|Gravel|1971|p=119}} The , with the support of [[South ]] and the , countered with the " Plan",{{sfn|Gravel|1971|p=140}} which provided for [[United Nations]]-supervised unification elections. The plan, however, was rejected by [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] and other communist delegations.{{sfn|Kort|2017|p=96}}}}). 300 days of free movement were permitted, during which almost a million northerners, including at least 500,000 Catholics and approximately 200,000 Buddhists, moved south,{{sfn|Goscha|2016|pages=280}} fearing persecution by the communists. This migration was in large part aided by the  military through [[Operation Passage to Freedom]].{{sfn|Olson|2012|p=43}}{{sfn|DK|2017|p=39}} The [[partition of ]] by the Geneva Accords was not intended to be permanent, and stipulated that  would be reunited after the elections.{{sfn|van Dijk|Gray|Savranskaya|Suri|2013|p=68}} In July 1955, the State of 's prime minister [[Ngo Dinh Diem|Ngô Đình Diệm]] announced in a broadcast that South  would not participate in the elections, as they had not signed the accords and therefore were not bound by them. In October 1955, Ngô Đình Diệm toppled [[Bảo Đại]] in a fraudulent [[1955 State of  referendum|referendum]] organised by his brother [[Ngô Đình Nhu]], and proclaimed himself president of the [[Republic of ]].{{sfn|van Dijk|Gray|Savranskaya|Suri|2013|p=68}}

===  War ===
{{Main| War}}
From 1953 to 1956, the [[North ]]ese government instituted [[Agrarianism|agrarian]] reforms including "[[Rent regulation|rent reduction]]" and "[[Land reform in |land reform]]", which resulted in significant [[political repression]].{{sfn|Moise|2017|p=56}} This included 13,500 to as many as 100,000 executions.{{sfn|Vu|2007}}{{sfn|Turner|1975|p=143}} In the South, Diệm countered North  subversion (including the assassination of over 450 South  officials in 1956) by detaining tens of thousands of suspected communists in "political reeducation centres".{{sfn|Heneghan|1969|p=160}}{{sfn|Turner|1975|p=177}} This programme incarcerated many non-communists, but was successful at curtailing [[communism|communist]] activity in the country, if only for a time.{{sfn|Crozier|1955}} The North  government claimed that 2,148 people were killed in the process by November 1957.{{sfn|Turner|1975|pp=174–178}} The pro-Hanoi [[Viet Cong]] began a guerrilla campaign in [[South ]] in the late 1950s to overthrow Diệm's government.{{sfn|Gilbert|2013|p=292}} From 1960, the Soviet Union and North  signed treaties providing for further Soviet military support.{{sfn|Jukes|1973|p=209}}{{sfn|Olsen|2007|p=92}}{{sfn|Khoo|2011|p=27}} The [[South |Republic of ]] in the south was supported by the [[]], [[]], [[]], [[]], and [[Kingdom of |]] while the [[North |Democratic Republic of ]] in the north was supported by the [[Soviet Union]], [[|People's Republic of ]],{{sfn|van Dijk|Gray|Savranskaya|Suri|2013|p=68}} [[Khmer Rouge]], and later, [[]].

[[File:Agent Orange Cropdusting.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Three US Fairchild UC-123B aircraft pictured spraying Agent Orange  | Three US [[Fairchild C-123 Provider|Fairchild UC-123B]] aircraft spraying [[Agent Orange]] during the [[Operation Ranch Hand]] as part of a [[herbicidal warfare]] operation depriving the food and vegetation cover of the [[Việt Cộng]], {{circa|1962–1971}}]]
In 1963, Buddhist discontent with Diệm's perceived pro-Catholic bias erupted into [[Buddhist crisis|mass demonstrations]], leading to a violent government crackdown.{{sfn|Muehlenbeck|Muehlenbeck|2012|p=221}} This led to the [[Cable 243|collapse of Diệm's relationship with the ]], and ultimately to a [[1963 South  coup|1963 coup]] in which [[Arrest and assassination of Ngô Đình Diệm|he and Nhu were assassinated]].{{sfn|Willbanks|2013|p=53}} The Diệm era was followed by more than a dozen successive military governments, before the pairing of Air Marshal [[Nguyễn Cao Kỳ]] and General [[Nguyễn Văn Thiệu]] took control in mid-1965.{{sfn|Duy Hinh|Dinh Tho|2015|p=238}} Thiệu gradually outmaneuvered Kỳ and cemented his grip on power in fraudulent elections in 1967 and 1971.{{sfn|Isserman|Bowman|2009|p=46}} During this political instability, the communists began to gain ground. To support South 's struggle against the communist insurgency, the  used the 1964 [[Gulf of Tonkin incident]] as a pretext for increasing its contribution of military advisers.{{sfn|Alterman|2005|p=213}} US forces became involved in ground combat operations by 1965, and at their peak several years later, numbered more than 500,000.{{sfn|Lewy|1980}}{{sfn|Gibbons|2014|p=166}} The US also engaged in [[Operation Rolling Thunder|sustained aerial bombing]]. Meanwhile,  and the Soviet Union provided North  with significant material aid and 15,000 combat advisers.{{sfn|Jukes|1973|p=209}}{{sfn|Olsen|2007|p=92}}{{sfn|Li|2012|p=67}} Communist forces supplying the Việt Cộng carried supplies along the [[Ho Chi Minh trail]], which passed through [[Kingdom of |]].{{sfn|Gillet|2011}}

The communists attacked South  targets during the 1968 [[Tết Offensive]]. The campaign failed militarily, but shocked the  establishment and turned US public opinion against the war.{{sfn|Dallek|2018}} During the offensive, communist troops [[Massacre at Huế|massacred over 3,000 civilians]] at [[Huế]].{{sfn|Turner|1975|p=251}}{{sfn|Frankum|2011|p=209}} Facing an increasing casualty count, [[Opposition to  involvement in the  War|rising domestic opposition]] to the war, and growing international condemnation, the US began [[Nixon Doctrine|withdrawing from ground combat roles]] in the early 1970s. This also entailed an unsuccessful effort to [[Vietnamisation|strengthen and stabilise South ]].{{sfn|Eggleston|2014|p=1}} Following the [[Paris Peace Accords]] of 27 January 1973, all  combat troops were withdrawn by 29 March 1973.{{sfn|History|2018}} In December 1974, North  [[Battle of Phước Long|captured]] the province of [[Phước Long province|Phước Long]] and started a [[1975 Spring Offensive|full-scale offensive]], culminating in the [[fall of Saigon]] on 30 April 1975.{{sfn|Tucker|2011|p=749}} South  was ruled by a [[Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Republic of South |provisional government]] for 14 months under North  control.{{sfn|Brigham|1998|p=86}}

=== Reunification and reforms ===
{{further|Re-education camp ()| boat people|Đổi Mới}}

On 2 July 1976, North and South  were merged to form the Socialist Republic of .{{sfn|''The New York Times''|1976}} The war had devastated  and killed 966,000 to 3.8&nbsp;million people.{{sfn|Hirschman|Preston|Manh Loi|1995}}{{sfn|Shenon|1995}}{{sfn|Obermeyer|Murray|Gakidou|2008}} A 1974 US Senate subcommittee estimated nearly 1.4&nbsp;million [[ War casualties| civilians]] were killed or wounded between 1965 and 1974—including 415,000 killed.{{sfn|Dohrenwend|Turse|Wall|Yager|2018|p=69}} In its aftermath, under [[Lê Duẩn]]'s administration, there were no mass executions of South  who had collaborated with the US or the defunct South  government, confounding Western fears,{{sfn|Elliott|2010|pp=499, 512–513}} but up to 300,000 South  were sent to [[Re-education camp ()|reeducation camps]], where many endured torture, starvation, and disease while being forced to perform hard labour.{{sfn|Sagan|Denny|1982}} The government embarked on a mass campaign of [[collectivisation]] of farms and factories.{{sfn|Spokesman-Review|1977|p=8}} Many fled the country following the conclusion of the war.{{Sfn|Moise|1988|p=12}} In 1978, in response to the [[Khmer Rouge]] government of  ordering massacres of  residents in the border villages in the districts of [[An Giang province|An Giang]] and [[Kiên Giang province|Kiên Giang]],{{sfn|Kissi|2006|p=144}} the  military [[– War|invaded ]] and removed them from power after occupying [[Phnom Penh]].{{sfn|Meggle|2004|p=166}} The intervention was a success, resulting in the establishment of a new, pro- socialist government, the [[People's Republic of Kampuchea]], which ruled until 1989.{{sfn|Hampson|1996|p=175}} However, this worsened relations with , which had supported the Khmer Rouge.  later launched a [[Sino- War|brief incursion into northern ]] in 1979, causing  to rely even more heavily on Soviet economic and military aid, while mistrust of the [[Government of | government]] escalated.{{sfn|Khoo|2011|p=131}}

At the [[6th National Congress of the Communist Party of |Sixth National Congress]] of the [[Communist Party of ]] (CPV) in December 1986, reformist politicians replaced the "old guard" government with new leadership.{{sfn|BBC News|1997}}{{sfn|Van Phuc|2014}} The reformers were led by 71-year-old [[Nguyễn Văn Linh]], who became the party's new general secretary.{{sfn|BBC News|1997}} He and the reformers implemented a series of market reforms known as {{lang|vi|[[Đổi Mới]]}} ("Renovation") that carefully managed the transition from a [[planned economy]] to a "[[socialist-oriented market economy]]".{{sfn|Murray|1997|pp=24–25}}{{sfn|Bich Loan|2007}} Although the authority of the state remained unchallenged under ''Đổi Mới'', the government encouraged [[private ownership]] of farms and factories, economic deregulation, and foreign investment, while maintaining control over strategic industries.{{sfn|Bich Loan|2007}}{{sfn|Howe|2016|p=20}} Subsequently, 's economy achieved strong growth in agricultural and industrial production, construction, exports, and foreign investment, although these reforms also resulted in a rise in income inequality and gender disparities.{{sfn|Goodkind|1995}}{{sfn|Gallup|2002}}{{sfn|Wagstaff|van Doorslaer|Watanabe|2003}}

In 2021, [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of ]], [[Nguyễn Phú Trọng]], was re-elected for his third term in office, meaning he was 's most powerful leader in decades. He died 19 July 2024, and was followed by [[Tô Lâm]] as General Secretary of the Communist Party.
==History==
{{main|History of the }}
[[Bantu peoples|Bantu-speaking peoples]], who founded tribes during the [[Bantu expansion]]s, mostly displaced and absorbed the earlier inhabitants of the region, the [[African Pygmies|Pygmy]] people, about 1500{{nbsp}}BC. The [[Bakongo]], a Bantu ethnic group that occupied parts of what later became , , and the , formed the basis for ethnic affinities and rivalries among those countries.{{cn|date=July 2025}}

By the 13th century, there were three main confederations of states in the western  Basin. In the east were the [[Seven Kingdoms of Kongo dia Nlaza]], considered to be the oldest and most powerful, which likely included [[Nsundi]], [[Mbata Kingdom|Mbata]], [[Mpangu]], and possibly [[Kundi kingdom|Kundi]] and [[Okanga]]. South of these was [[Mpemba]] which stretched from modern-day [[]] to the [[ River]]. It included various kingdoms such as [[Mpemba Kasi]] and [[Vunda]]. To its west across the  River was a confederation of three small states; [[Vungu]] (its leader), [[Kakongo]], and [[Ngoyo]].{{Rp|pages=24–25}} Some Bantu kingdoms—including those of the [[Kongo people|Kongo]], the [[Tio people|Tio]], and [[Kingdom of Loango|Loango]]—built trade links leading into the [[ Basin]]. The [[Tio Kingdom]] formed in the 14th century; the association of kingship with [[smithing]] is believed to have originated among the Tio before spreading to the kingdoms of Loango and [[Kingdom of Kongo|Kongo]].{{Reference page|pages=439-42}}

The [[Kingdom of |]] explorer [[Diogo Cão]] reached the mouth of the  in 1484. Commercial relationships grew between the inland Bantu kingdoms and European merchants who traded in commodities, manufactured goods, and people captured and enslaved in the [[hinterland]]s. After centuries as a central hub for transatlantic trade, direct European colonization of the  River delta began in the 19th century, subsequently eroding the power of the Bantu societies in the region.

[[File:Court of Loango.png|thumb|The court of [[N'Gangue M'voumbe Niambi]], from the book ''Description of Africa'' (1668)]]

The area north of the  River came under  sovereignty in 1880 as a result of [[Pierre de Brazza]]'s treaty with Tio King {{ill|Iloo I|fr|Illoy Ier}}.{{efn|De Brazza promised benefits of trade and an alliance, which was likely interpreted as military assistance. While some sources attest that Iloo was aware of the condition, [[Jan Vansina]] wrote that "it seems clear that he only wanted to cede land for the establishment of a [[Trading post|commercial station]]", and that his desire for an alliance may have been influenced by the hostility of [[Henry Morton Stanley's first trans-Africa expedition|Henry Stanley's expedition]] a few years earlier.{{Reference page|pages=409-12}}}} After the death of Iloo, his widow Queen [[Ngalifourou]] upheld the terms of the treaty and became an ally to the colonizers. This  Colony became known first as [[ ]], then as Middle  in 1903.

In 1908,  organized [[ Equatorial Africa]] (AEF), comprising the Middle , [[ |]], [[ |]], and [[Oubangui-Chari]] (which later became the [[]]). The  designated [[Brazzaville]] as the federal capital. Economic development during the first 50 years of colonial rule in  centered on natural resource extraction. Construction of the [[–Ocean Railway]] following [[World War I]] has been estimated to have cost at least 14,000 lives.

During the [[Nazi occupation of ]] during [[World War II]], Brazzaville functioned as the symbolic capital of [[Free ]] between 1940 and 1943. The [[Brazzaville Conference of 1944]] heralded a period of reform in  colonial policy.  "benefited" from the postwar expansion of colonial administrative and infrastructure spending as a result of its central geographic location within AEF and the federal capital at Brazzaville. It had a local legislature after the adoption of the 1946 constitution that established the [[ Fourth Republic|Fourth Republic]].

Following the revision of the [[Constitution of | constitution]] that established the [[ Fifth Republic|Fifth Republic]] in 1958, AEF dissolved into its constituent parts, each of which became an autonomous colony within the [[ Community]]. During these reforms, Middle  became known as the  in 1958 and published its first constitution in 1959. Antagonism between the [[Mbochi]]s (who favored [[Jacques Opangault]]) and the [[Lari people ()|Lari]]s and [[Kongo people|Kongo]]s (who favored [[Fulbert Youlou]], the first black mayor elected in  Equatorial Africa) resulted in a series of riots in Brazzaville in February 1959, which the [[ Army]] subdued.

Elections took place in April 1959. By the time the  became independent in August 1960, Opangault, the former opponent of Youlou, agreed to serve under him. Youlou, an avid anti-communist, became the first President of the . Since the political tension was so high in [[Pointe-Noire]], Youlou moved the capital to Brazzaville.{{cn|date=July 2025}}

[[File:Alphonse Massamba-Debat.png|thumb|left|upright|[[Alphonse Massamba-Débat]]'s 1-party rule (1963–1968) attempted to implement a [[political economy|political economic]] strategy of "[[scientific socialism]]".]]
The  became fully independent from  on 15 August 1960. Youlou ruled as the country's first president until labor elements and rival political parties instigated a [[Trois Glorieuses (1963)|three-day uprising]] that ousted him.
