The  military took over the country and installed a civilian provisional government headed by [[Alphonse Massamba-Débat]].

Under the 1963 constitution, Massamba-Débat was elected president for a five-year term. During [[Alphonse Massamba-Débat# under Massamba-Débat (1963–1968)|Massamba-Débat's term in office]], the regime adopted "[[scientific socialism]]" as the country's constitutional ideology. In 1964,  sent an official team with a single athlete at the [[1964 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]] for the first time in its history. In 1965,  established relations with the [[Soviet Union]], the [[|People's Republic of ]], [[]], and [[North ]]. Under his presidency, the  began to [[industrialize]]. Some large production units with large workforces were built: the textile factory of Kinsoundi, the palm groves of Etoumbi, the match factory of [[Bétou]], the shipyards of Yoro, etc. Health centers were created as well as school groups (colleges and elementary school). The country's school enrollment rate became the highest in Black Africa.

On the night of 14 to 15 February 1965, three public officials of the  were kidnapped: {{ill|Lazare Matsocota|fr}} (prosecutor of the Republic), {{ill|Joseph Pouabou|fr}} (President of the Supreme Court), and {{ill|Anselme Massouémé|fr}} (director of the  Information Agency). The bodies of two of these men were later found, mutilated, by the  River. Massamba-Débat's regime invited some hundred [[]]n army troops into the country to train his party's militia units. These troops helped his government survive a [[1966  coup d'état attempt|''coup d'état'' in 1966]] led by paratroopers loyal to future President [[Marien Ngouabi]]. Massamba-Débat's regime ended with a bloodless [[1968  coup d'état|''coup'' in September 1968]].

Marien Ngouabi, who had participated in the coup, assumed the presidency on 31 December 1968. One year later, Ngouabi proclaimed the  Africa's first "people's republic", the [[People's ]], and announced the decision of the National Revolutionary Movement to change its name to the [[ Party of Labour| Labour Party]] (PCT). He survived an [[1972  coup d'état attempt|attempted ''coup'' in 1972]] and was assassinated on 18 March{{nbsp}}1977. An 11-member Military Committee of the Party (CMP) was then named to head an interim government, with [[Joachim Yhombi-Opango]] serving as president. Two years later, Yhombi-Opango was forced from power, and [[Denis Sassou Nguesso]] became the new president.

Sassou Nguesso aligned the country with the [[Eastern Bloc]] and signed a 20-year friendship pact with the Soviet Union. Over the years, Sassou had to rely more on [[political repression]] and less on [[patronage]] to maintain his dictatorship. The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 resulted in the ending of Soviet aid to prop up the regime, and it abdicated power.

[[Pascal Lissouba]] who became 's first elected president (1992–1997) during the period of multi-party democracy attempted to implement economic reforms with IMF backing to liberalize the economy. In the years 1993 and 1994 the [[ Civil War (1993–1994)|first  Civil War in ]] occurred. In June 1996, IMF approved a three-year [[Special drawing rights|SDR]] 69.5m (US$100m) [[enhanced structural adjustment facility]] (ESAF) and was on the verge of announcing a renewed annual agreement when civil war broke out in  in 1997.

's democratic progress was derailed in 1997 when Lissouba and Sassou started to fight for power in the [[ Civil War (1997–1999)|civil war]]. As presidential elections scheduled for July 1997 approached, tensions between the Lissouba and Sassou camps mounted. On 5 June, President Lissouba's government forces surrounded Sassou's compound in Brazzaville, and Sassou ordered members of his private militia (known as "Cobras") to resist. Thus began a four-month conflict that destroyed or damaged some of Brazzaville and caused tens of thousands of civilian deaths. In October, the  government began an invasion of  to install Sassou in power and the Lissouba government fell. After that, Sassou declared himself president.
[[File:Pro-constitutional reform demonstration in Brazzaville - 2015-10 (21518932913).jpg|thumb|left|A pro-constitutional reform rally in Brazzaville during October 2015. The constitution's reforms were subsequently approved in a disputed election that saw demonstrations and violence.]]

In the [[ presidential election, 2002|elections in 2002]], Sassou won with almost 90% of the vote cast. His two main rivals, Lissouba and Bernard Kolelas, were prevented from competing. A remaining rival, [[André Milongo]] advised his supporters to boycott the elections and then withdrew from the race. A [[constitution]], agreed upon by [[ constitutional referendum, 2002|referendum in January 2002]], granted the president new powers, extended his term to seven years and introduced a new bicameral assembly. International observers took issue with the organization of the presidential election and the constitutional referendum, both of which were reminiscent in their organization of 's era of the 1-party state. Following the presidential elections, fighting restarted in the [[Pool Department|Pool region]] between government forces and rebels led by [[Pastor Ntumi]]; a peace treaty to end the conflict was signed in April 2003.

Sassou won the following [[ presidential election, 2009|presidential election in July 2009]]. According to the  Observatory of Human Rights, a non-governmental organization, the election was marked by "very low" turnout and "fraud and irregularities". In March 2015, Sassou announced that he wanted to run for yet another term in office and a [[ constitutional referendum, 2015|constitutional referendum]] in October resulted in a [[Constitution of the |changed constitution]] that allowed him to run during the [[ presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]]. He won the election believed by some to be fraudulent. After violent protests in the capital, Sassou attacked the Pool region where the [[Ninja (militia)|Ninja rebel]]s of the civil war used to be based, in what was believed to be a distraction. This led to a revival of the Ninja rebels who launched attacks against the army in April 2016, leading 80,000 people to flee their homes. A ceasefire deal was signed in December 2017.

In 2023, the [[Odzala National Park|Forest Massif of Odzala-Kokoua]] was listed as a natural [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]].
== History ==
{{main|History of }}

===Prehistory and Classical era===
{{Main|Pre-colonial }}
Cultural remains at [[Jerimalai]] on the eastern tip of  have been dated to 42,000 years ago. The first known inhabitants are those who arrived during the [[Australo-Melanesian]] migration through the region, likely bringing the precursors to today's [[Papuan languages]]. A later migration of [[Austroasiatic languages|Austroasiatic]]-speakers is suspected, although no such languages remain. The arrival of [[Austronesian peoples]] brought [[Austronesian languages|new languages]], and merged with existing cultures on the island. Timorese origin myths recount settlers sailing around the eastern end of the island before landing in the south. These people are sometimes noted as being from the [[Malay Peninsula]] or the [[Minangkabau people|Minangkabau]] highlands of [[Sumatra]]. [[Austronesian peoples|Austronesian]] migration to  may be associated with the development of agriculture on the island.

While information is limited about the political system of  during this period, the island had developed an interconnected series of polities governed by customary law. Small communities, centred around a particular sacred house, were part of wider ''sucos'' (or principalities), which were themselves part of larger kingdoms led by a ''liurai''. Authority within these kingdoms was held by [[Dyad (sociology)|two individuals]], with the worldly power of the ''liurai'' balanced by the spiritual power of a ''rai nain'', who was generally associated with the primary sacred house of the kingdom. These polities were numerous and saw shifting alliances and relations, but many were stable enough that they survived from initial European documentation in the 16th century until the end of  rule.{{rp|11–15}}

From perhaps the thirteenth century, the island exported [[sandalwood]],{{rp|267}} which was valued both for its use in crafting and as a source of perfume.  was included in Southeast Asian, , and  trading networks by the fourteenth century, exporting sandalwood, honey, and wax. The island was recorded by the [[Majapahit]] Empire as a source of tribute.{{rp|89}} It was sandalwood that attracted European explorers to the island in the early sixteenth century. Early European presence was limited to trade, with the first  settlement being on the nearby island of [[Solor]].{{rp|90}}

===  era (1769–1975) ===
{{Main| }}
[[File:Planta de Cailacao (1727), Arquivo Histórico Ultramarino.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Black, red and white hand-drawn illustration showing a battle between  forces and their allies against an army of rebelling kingdoms|The [[Battle of Cailaco]] in 1726, part of a rebellion]]
Early  presence on  was very limited; trade was directed through  settlements on nearby islands. Only in the 17th century did they establish a more direct presence on the island, a consequence of being driven out of other islands by the .{{rp|267}} After Solor was lost in 1613, the  moved to [[Flores]]. In 1646, the capital moved to [[Kupang]] on 's west, before Kupang too was lost to the  in 1652. The  then moved to [[Lifau]], in what is now 's [[Oecusse]] exclave.{{rp|90}} Effective European occupation in the east of the island only began in 1769, when the city of [[Dili]] was founded, although actual control remained highly limited. A definitive [[– border|border]] between the  and  parts of the island was established by the [[Permanent Court of Arbitration]] in 1914 and remains the international boundary between the successor states  and , respectively.

For the , East  remained little more than a neglected trading post, with minimal investment in infrastructure and education, until the late nineteenth century. Even when  established actual control over the interior of its colony, investment remained minimal.{{rp|269, 273}} Sandalwood continued to be the main export crop and coffee exports became significant in the mid-nineteenth century.

At the beginning of the twentieth century, a faltering domestic economy prompted the  to extract greater wealth from its colonies, which was met with  resistance. The colony was seen as an economic burden during the [[Great Depression]] and received little support or management from .{{rp|269}}

During World War II, Dili was occupied by the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] in 1941, and later by the [[Empire of |]] beginning in 1942. The mountainous interior of the colony became the scene of a [[guerrilla warfare|guerrilla campaign]], known as the [[Battle of  (1942–43)|Battle of ]]. Waged by  volunteers and Allied forces against the , the struggle killed between 40,000 and 70,000  civilians. The  eventually drove the last of the  and Allied forces out in early 1943.  control resumed, however, after  surrender at the end of World War II.

 began investment in the colony in the 1950s, funding education and promoting coffee exports, but the economy did not improve substantially and infrastructure improvements were limited.{{rp|269}} Yearly growth rates remained low, near 2%. Following the [[Carnation Revolution|1974  revolution]],  effectively abandoned its colony in , and civil war between  political parties broke out in 1975.

The [[Revolutionary Front for an Independent East ]] (Fretilin) resisted a [[Timorese Democratic Union]] (UDT) coup attempt in August 1975, and [[ declaration of independence|unilaterally declared independence]] on 28 November 1975. Fearing a communist state within the  Archipelago, the  military launched an [[ invasion of East |invasion of East ]] on 7 December 1975.  declared [[East  (province)|East  its 27th province]] on 17 July 1976. The [[United Nations Security Council]] opposed the invasion, and the territory's nominal status in the UN remained as "non-self-governing territory under  administration".

===  occupation (1975–1999) ===
{{main| occupation of East |East  (province)}}
[[File:East  Demo.jpg|thumb|alt=Protestors holding a sign saying " out of East  NOW"|A demonstration for [[ occupation of East |independence from ]] held in  during September 1999]]
[[Fretilin]] resisted the invasion, initially as an army, holding territory until November 1978, and then as a guerrilla resistance. The [[ occupation of East | occupation]] of  was marked by violence and brutality. A detailed statistical report prepared for the [[Commission for Reception, Truth and Reconciliation in East ]] cited a minimum of 102,800 conflict-related deaths in the period between 1974 and 1999, including approximately 18,600 killings and 84,200 [[excess death]]s from hunger and illness. The total number of conflict-related deaths during this period is difficult to determine due to a lack of data. One estimate based on , , and Catholic Church data suggests it may have been as high as 200,000. Repression and restrictions counteracted improvements in health and education infrastructure and services, meaning there was little overall improvement in living standards; economic growth mostly benefited immigrants from elsewhere in .{{rp|271}} A huge expansion of education was intended to increase  language use and internal security as much as it was for development.

The [[Santa Cruz massacre|1991 massacre]] of more than 200 demonstrators by the  military was a turning point for the independence cause, and brought increased international pressure on . Following the [[Fall of Suharto|resignation of  President Suharto]], the new President [[B. J. Habibie|BJ Habibie]], prompted by a letter from  [[Prime Minister John Howard]], decided to hold a referendum on independence. A UN-sponsored agreement between  and  allowed for a UN-supervised popular [[ independence referendum, 1999|referendum]] in August 1999. A clear vote for independence was met with [[1999  crisis|a punitive campaign of violence]] by  [[pro- militia|pro-integration militias]] supported by elements of the  military. In response, the  government allowed a multinational peacekeeping force, [[International Force East |INTERFET]], to restore order and aid  refugees and internally displaced persons. On 25 October 1999, the administration of East  was taken over by the UN through the [[United Nations Transitional Administration in East ]] (UNTAET). INTERFET deployment ended in February 2000 with the transfer of military command to the UN.

=== Contemporary era ===
{{See also|East  independence|United Nations Administered East }}
[[File:Präsidentschaftswalhkampf JRH 2007.JPG|thumb|left|upright=0.6|alt=José Ramos-Horta in traditional formal wear talking to reporters|[[José Ramos-Horta]], 1996 Nobel Peace Prize winner, fourth and seventh president of ]]
On 30 August 2001, the  voted in their first election organised by the UN to elect members of the Constituent Assembly. On 22 March 2002, the Constituent Assembly approved the Constitution. By May 2002, more than 205,000 refugees had returned. On 20 May 2002, the Constitution of the Democratic Republic of  came into force and  was [[East  independence|recognised as independent]] by the UN. The Constituent Assembly was renamed the National Parliament, and [[Xanana Gusmão]] was elected as the country's first president. On 27 September 2002 the country became a UN member state.

In 2006, [[2006  crisis|a crisis of unrest and factional fighting]] forced 155,000 people to flee their homes; the United Nations sent in security forces to restore order. The following year, Gusmão declined to run for another term. While there were minor incidents in the build-up to the [[ presidential election, 2007|mid-year presidential elections]], the process was peaceful overall and [[José Ramos-Horta]] was elected president. In June 2007, Gusmão ran in the [[ parliamentary election, 2007|parliamentary elections]] and became prime minister at the head of the [[National Congress for Timorese Reconstruction]] (CNRT) party. In February 2008, Ramos-Horta was critically injured in [[2008  assassination attempts|an attempted assassination]]; Prime Minister Gusmão also faced gunfire separately but escaped unharmed.  reinforcements were immediately sent to help keep order. In March 2011, the UN handed over operational control of the police force to the  authorities. The United Nations ended its peacekeeping mission on 31 December 2012.

[[Francisco Guterres]] of the centre-left Fretilin party became president in May 2017. The leader of Fretilin, [[Mari Alkatiri]], formed a coalition government after the July 2017 parliamentary election. This government soon fell, leading to a second general election in May 2018. In June 2018, former president and independence fighter, [[Taur Matan Ruak]], became the new prime minister. [[José Ramos-Horta]] again became president on 20 May 2022 after winning the April 2022 [[2022  presidential election|presidential election]] runoff against Francisco Guterres. Following ratification by the National Parliament, the [[Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons]] came into force for  on 22 September, making the use of nuclear weapons in the country illegal.{{Citation needed|date=October 2025}}
==History==
{{Main|History of }}

[[File:CPN ST B 01.jpg|thumb|A [[Maya stelae|Maya stela]], an emblematic symbol of the  Mayan civilization at Copan]]

===Pre-colonial period===
{{Further|Mesoamerican chronology}}
{{See also|Bajo Aguán}}
In the pre-Columbian era, modern  was split between two pan-cultural regions: [[Mesoamerica]] in the west and the [[Isthmo- area]] in the east. Each complex had a "core area" within  (the [[Sula Valley]] for Mesoamerica, and [[La Mosquitia ()|La Mosquitia]] for the Isthmo- area), and the intervening area was one of gradual transition. However, these concepts had no meaning in the Pre-Columbian era itself and represent extremely diverse areas. The [[Lenca|Lenca people]] of the interior highlands are also generally considered to be culturally Mesoamerican, though the extent of linkage with other areas varied over time (for example, expanding during the zenith of the [[Toltec Empire]]).

In the extreme west, [[Maya civilization]] flourished for hundreds of years. The dominant, best known, and best studied state within 's borders was in [[Copán]], which was located in a mainly non-Maya area, or on the frontier between Maya and non-Maya areas. Copán declined with other Lowland centres during the conflagrations of the [[Classic Maya collapse|Terminal Classic]] in the 9th century. The Maya of this civilization survive in western  as the [[Ch'orti' people|Ch'orti']], isolated from their Choltian linguistic peers to the west.

However, Copán represents only a fraction of  pre-Columbian history. Remnants of other civilizations are found throughout the country. Archaeologists have studied sites such as {{interlanguage link|Naco ()|lt=Naco|es|Naco ()}} and La Sierra in the Naco Valley, [[Los Naranjos, |Los Naranjos]] on [[Lake Yojoa]], [[Yarumela]] in the Comayagua Valley, [[La Ceiba]] and Salitron Viejo (both now under the [[El Cajón Dam ()|Cajón Dam]] [[reservoir]]), Selin Farm and Cuyamel in the Aguan valley, [[Cerro Palenque]], Travesia, Curruste, Ticamaya, Despoloncal, and [[Playa de los Muertos]] in the lower [[Ulúa River]] valley, and many others.

In 2012, LiDAR scanning revealed that several previously unknown high density settlements existed in La Mosquitia, corresponding to the legend of "[[La Ciudad Blanca]]". Excavation and study has since improved knowledge of the region's history. It is estimated that these settlements reached their zenith from 500 to 1000 AD.

===  conquest (1524–1539) ===
{{main| conquest of }}

[[File:Retrato de Hernán Cortés.jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|[[Hernán Cortés]], one of the conquerors of ]]
On his fourth and the final voyage to the [[New World]] in 1502, [[Christopher Columbus]] landed near the modern town of [[Trujillo, |Trujillo]], near Guaimoreto Lagoon, becoming the first European to visit the [[Bay Islands Department|Bay Islands]] on the coast of . On 30 July 1502, Columbus sent his brother [[Bartholomew Columbus|Bartholomew]] to explore the islands and Bartholomew encountered a Mayan trading vessel from Yucatán, carrying well-dressed Maya and a rich cargo. Bartholomew's men stole the cargo they wanted and kidnapped the ship's elderly captain to serve as an interpreter in the first recorded encounter between the  and the Maya.

In March 1524, [[Gil González Dávila]] became the first Spaniard to enter  as a [[conquistador]]. followed by [[Hernán Cortés]], who had brought forces down from . Much of the conquest took place in the following two decades, first by groups loyal to [[Cristóbal de Olid]], and then by those loyal to [[Francisco de Montejo]] but most particularly by those following Alvarado.{{who|date=December 2017}} In addition to  resources, the conquerors relied heavily on armed forces from {{snd}}[[Tlaxcalans]] and [[Aztec|Mexica]] armies of thousands who remained garrisoned in the region.

Resistance to conquest was led in particular by [[Lempira (Lenca ruler)|Lempira]]. Many regions in the north of  never fell to the , notably the [[Mosquito Coast|Miskito Kingdom]]. After the  conquest,  became part of 's vast empire in the New World within the [[Captaincy General of |Kingdom of ]]. Trujillo and [[Gracias a Dios Department|Gracias]] were the first city-capitals. The  ruled the region for approximately three centuries.

===  (1524–1821)===
[[File:San Manuel Colohete,Lempira 1.JPG|thumb|[[Church of San Manuel de Colohete]]]]
 was organized as a province of the [[Captaincy General of |Kingdom of ]] and the capital was fixed, first at Trujillo on the Atlantic coast, and later at [[Comayagua]], and finally at [[Tegucigalpa]] in the central part of the country.

[[Silver mining]] was a key factor in the  conquest and settlement of . Initially the mines were worked by local people through the [[encomienda]] system, but as disease and resistance made this option less available, slaves from other parts of Central America were brought in. When local slave trading stopped at the end of the sixteenth century, African slaves, mostly from [[]], were imported. After about 1650, very few slaves or other outside workers arrived in .

Although the  conquered the southern or Pacific portion of  fairly quickly, they were less successful on the northern, or Atlantic side. They managed to found a few towns along the coast, at [[Puerto Cortés|Puerto Caballos]] and Trujillo in particular, but failed to conquer the eastern portion of the region and many pockets of independent indigenous people as well. The [[Mosquito Coast|Miskito Kingdom]] in the northeast was particularly effective at resisting conquest. The Miskito Kingdom found support from northern European privateers, pirates and especially the  formerly  colony of [[]], which placed much of the area under its protection after 1740.

[[File:Exterior Fuerte de Omoa .jpg|thumb|The [[Battle of San Fernando de Omoa|Fortaleza de San Fernando de Omoa]] was built by the  to protect the coast of  from  pirates.]]

===Independence (1821)===
 gained independence from  in 1821 and [[Central America under  rule|was a part]] of the [[First  Empire]] until 1823, when it became part of the [[United Provinces of Central America]]. It has been an independent [[republic]] and has held regular elections since 1838. In the 1840s and 1850s  participated in several failed attempts at Central  unity, such as the Confederation of Central America (1842–1845), the covenant of  (1842), the Diet of Sonsonate (1846), the Diet of Nacaome (1847) and National Representation in Central America (1849–1852). Although  eventually adopted the name Republic of , the unionist ideal never waned, and  was one of the Central  countries that pushed the hardest for a policy of regional unity.

Policies favoring [[international trade]] and investment began in the 1870s.  Soon, foreign interests became involved, first in shipping from the north coast, especially tropical fruit and most notably bananas, and then in building railroads. [[Comayagua]] was the capital of  until 1880, when the capital moved to [[Tegucigalpa]]. In 1888, a projected railroad line from the Caribbean coast to Tegucigalpa ran out of money when it reached [[San Pedro Sula]]. As a result, San Pedro grew into the nation's primary industrial center and second-largest city.

Since independence, nearly 300 small internal rebellions and civil wars have occurred in the country, including some changes of régime.

===20th century and the role of  companies===
{{See also|Banana Wars}}
In the late nineteenth century,  granted land and substantial exemptions to several US-based fruit and infrastructure companies in return for developing the country's northern regions. Thousands of workers came to the north coast as a result to work in [[Banana production in |banana plantations]] and other businesses that grew up around the export industry. Banana-exporting companies, dominated until 1930 by the [[Cuyamel Fruit Company]], as well as the [[United Fruit Company]], and [[Standard Fruit Company]], built an [[enclave economy]] in northern , controlling [[infrastructure]] and creating self-sufficient, tax-exempt sectors that contributed relatively little to economic growth.  troops landed in  in 1903, 1907, 1911, 1912, 1919, 1924 and 1925.

In 1904, the writer [[O. Henry]] coined the term "[[banana republic]]" to describe , publishing a book called ''[[Cabbages and Kings (novel)|Cabbages and Kings]]'', about a fictional country, [[Anchuria]], inspired by his experiences in , where he had lived for six months. In ''The Admiral'', O. Henry refers to the nation as a "small maritime banana republic"; naturally, the fruit was the entire basis of its economy. According to a literary analyst writing for ''[[The Economist]]'', "his phrase neatly conjures up the image of a tropical, agrarian country. But its real meaning is sharper: it refers to the fruit companies from the  that came to exert extraordinary influence over the politics of  and its neighbors." In addition to drawing Central  workers north, the fruit companies encouraged immigration of workers from the [[-speaking Caribbean]], notably [[]] and [[]], which introduced an African-descended, -speaking and largely Protestant population into the country, although many of these workers left following changes to immigration law in 1939.
 joined the [[Allies of World War II|Allied Nations]] after [[attack on Pearl Harbor|Pearl Harbor]], on 8 December 1941, and signed the [[Declaration by United Nations]] on 1 January 1942, along with twenty-five other governments.

Constitutional crises in the 1940s led to reforms in the 1950s. One reform gave workers permission to organize, and a 1954 [[General strike of 1954 ()|general strike]] paralyzed the northern part of the country for more than two months, but led to reforms. In 1963 a [[1963  coup d'état|military coup]] unseated democratically elected President [[Ramón Villeda Morales]]. In 1960, the northern part of what was the [[Mosquito Coast]] was transferred from  to  by the [[International Court of Justice]].

===War and upheaval (1969–1999)===
In 1969,  and [[]] fought what became known as the [[Football War]]. Border tensions led to acrimony between the two countries after [[Oswaldo López Arellano]], the president of , blamed the deteriorating  economy on immigrants from . The relationship reached a low when  met  for a three-round football elimination match preliminary to the [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]].

Tensions escalated and on 14 July 1969, the  army invaded . The [[Organization of  States]] (OAS) negotiated a cease-fire which took effect on 20 July and brought about a withdrawal of  troops in early August. Contributing factors to the conflict were a boundary dispute and the presence of thousands of  living in  illegally. After the week-long war, as many as 130,000  immigrants were expelled.

[[Hurricane Fifi]] caused severe damage when it skimmed the northern coast of  on 18 and 19 September 1974. [[Juan Alberto Melgar Castro|Melgar Castro]] (1975–78) and Paz Garcia (1978–82) largely built the current physical infrastructure and telecommunications system of .

[[File:Mitch-Tegucigalpa Damage.JPG|thumb|Part of the massive damage caused by [[Hurricane Mitch]] in Tegucigalpa, 1998]]
In 1979, the country returned to civilian rule<!-- for the first time since 1963? -->. A [[constituent assembly]] was popularly elected in April 1980 to write a new constitution, and general elections were held in November 1981. The constitution was approved in 1982 and the [[Liberal Party of |PLH]] government of [[Roberto Suazo Córdova|Roberto Suazo]] won the election with a promise to carry out an ambitious program of economic and social development to tackle the recession in which  found itself. He launched ambitious social and economic development projects sponsored by  development aid.  became host to the largest [[Peace Corps]] mission in the world, and nongovernmental and international voluntary agencies proliferated. The Peace Corps withdrew its volunteers in 2012, citing safety concerns.

During the early 1980s, the  established a continuing military presence in  to support , the [[Contra (guerrillas)|Contra]] guerrillas fighting the [[]]n government, and also develop an airstrip and modern port in . Though spared the bloody civil wars wracking its neighbors, the [[ Army]] quietly waged campaigns against [[Marxist–Leninist]] militias such as the [[People's Liberation Movement-Chinchoneros|Cinchoneros]] Popular Liberation Movement, notorious for kidnappings and bombings, and against many non-militants as well. The operation included a campaign of extrajudicial killings by government units, most notably the CIA-trained [[Battalion 3-16 ()|Battalion 316]].  was found internationally liable for a series of [[enforced disappearance]]s during this time period, culminating in [[Velásquez-Rodríguez v. ]].

In 1998, [[Hurricane Mitch]] caused massive and widespread destruction.  President [[Carlos Roberto Flores]] said that fifty years of progress in the country had been reversed. Mitch destroyed about 70% of the country's crops and an estimated 70–80% of the transportation infrastructure, including nearly all bridges and secondary roads. Across  33,000 houses were destroyed, and an additional 50,000 damaged. Some 5,000 people killed, and 12,000 more injured. Total losses were estimated at US$3 billion.

===21st century===
[[File:Defense.gov News Photo 0308020-F-2828D-168.jpg|thumb|right|President [[Ricardo Maduro]] with U.S. Secretary of Defense [[Donald Rumsfeld]] in August 2003]]
In 2007, President of  [[Manuel Zelaya]] and President of the  [[George W. Bush]] began talks on US assistance to  to tackle the latter's growing drug cartels in Mosquito, Eastern  using US special forces. This marked the beginning of a new foothold for the US military's continued presence in Central America.

[[File:2009  political crisis 11.jpg|thumb|[[2009  coup d'état]]]]
Under Zelaya,  joined [[ALBA]] in 2008, but withdrew in 2010 after the [[2009  coup d'état]]. In 2009, a [[2009  political crisis|constitutional crisis]] resulted when power was transferred in a coup from the president to the head of Congress. The [[Organization of  States|OAS]] suspended  because it did not regard its government as legitimate.

Countries around the world, the OAS, and the [[United Nations]] formally and unanimously condemned the action as a [[coup d'état]], refusing to recognize the ''de facto'' government, even though the lawyers consulted by the [[Library of Congress]] submitted to the [[ Congress]] an opinion that declared the coup legal. The [[ Supreme Court]] also ruled that the proceedings had been legal. The government that followed the ''de facto government'' established a truth and reconciliation commission, ''Comisión de la Verdad y Reconciliación'', which after more than a year of research and debate concluded that the ousting had been a [[coup d'état]], and illegal in the commission's opinion.

On 28 November 2021, the former first lady [[Xiomara Castro]], leftist presidential candidate of opposition [[Liberty and Refoundation]] Party, won 53% of the votes in the [[2021  general election|presidential election]] to become the first female president of , bringing an end to the 12-year reign of the right-wing National Party. She was sworn in on 27 January 2022. Her husband, Manuel Zelaya, held the same office from 2006 until 2009.

In April 2022, former president of , [[Juan Orlando Hernández]], who served two terms between 2014 and January 2022, was extradited to the  to face charges of drug trafficking and money laundering. Hernandez denied the accusations.
==History==
{{main|History of }}

=== Precolumbian history ===
 is thought to have been first populated by peoples from South America during the Caribbean [[Ortoiroid people|Archaic Age]], although definitive evidence is lacking. The earliest potential human presence comes from [[Proxy (statistics)|proxy]] evidence of lake cores, beginning {{circa|3600 BC}}. Less ephemeral, permanent villages began {{circa|100–200}}. The population peaked between 750 and 1250, with major changes in population afterward, potentially the result of either the [[Island Caribs|"Carib Invasion"]] (although highly contested), regional droughts, or both.

===European arrival===
In 1498, Christopher Columbus was the first European to report sighting  during his third voyage, naming it 'La Concepción', but Amerigo Vespucci may have renamed it 'Mayo' in 1499. Although it was deemed the property of the King of , there are no records to suggest the  attempted to settle. However, various Europeans are known to have passed and both fought and traded with the indigenous peoples there. The first known settlement attempt was a failed venture by the  in 1609 who were massacred and driven away by the native "Carib" peoples.{{sfn|Steele|2003|pp=35–36}}

=== colony and slavery (1649–1763)===
{{Main| West Indies}}
In 1649, a  expedition of 203 men from [[Martinique]], led by [[Jacques Dyel du Parquet]], founded a permanent settlement on .{{sfn|Steele|2003|pp=35–36}} They signed a peace treaty with the Carib chief [[Chief Kairouane|Kairouane]], but within months conflict broke out between the two communities.{{sfn|Steele|2003|pp=39–48}} This lasted until 1654 when the island was completely subjugated by the .{{sfn|Steele|2003|pp=35–44}} Warfare continued during the 1600s between the  on  and the Caribs of present-day [[]] and [[St.  and the ]].

[[History of chocolate|Chocolate]] was brought to  in 1714 with the introduction of [[cocoa bean]]s.

The  named their [[ colonial empires|new colony]] La Grenade, and the economy was initially based on [[sugar cane]] and [[indigo]], worked by African slaves via the transatlantic slave trade.{{sfn|Steele|2003|p=59}} According to records, during the  colonial period (circa 1659–1762), the enslaved population on  rose from about 222 in 1669 to roughly 15,200 by 1763'''.''' The  established a capital known as Fort Royal (later St. George's). To shelter from hurricanes, the  navy would often take refuge in the capital's natural harbour, as no nearby  islands had a natural harbour to compare with that of Fort Royal. The  captured  in the [[Seven Years' War]] in 1762.

===  colony, slavery and emancipation ===
==== Early colonial period and slavery ====
{{Main| West Indies| Windward Islands|West Indies Federation}}
[[File:Port -Georges dans l'île de la Grenade en 1776.jpg|thumb|The island of  and port -Georges in 1776]]

 was formally ceded to [[Kingdom of Great Britain|Britain]] by the Treaty of Paris in 1763. The  [[ capture of  1779|re-captured the island]] during the [[ Revolutionary War]], after [[Comte d'Estaing]] won the bloody land and naval [[Battle of ]] in July 1779. However, the island was restored to Britain with the [[Peace of Paris (1783)|Treaty of Versailles]] in 1783. A decade later, dissatisfaction with  rule led to a [[Fédon's rebellion|pro- revolt]] in 1795–96 led by [[Julien Fédon]], which was successfully defeated by the .

As 's economy grew, more and more enslaved Africans transported to the island. In 1785,  had 23,926 enslaved Africans and 1,115 free people of colour, with around 996 European settlers. According to the Voyages Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade Database, by 1807 Britain had brought 114,000 slaves to '''.''' Britain eventually outlawed the slave trade within the  Empire in 1807, after transporting approximately 3.1 million Africans, between 1640 and 1807, with roughly 2.7 million surviving the Middle Passage and arriving in the Americas. Slavery was completely outlawed in 1833, leading to the emancipation of all enslaved Africans by 1838. To ease the subsequent labour shortage, migrants from  were brought to  in 1857.{{sfn|Steele|2003|pp=35–36}}

[[Nutmeg]] was introduced to  in 1843 when a merchant ship called in on its way to England from the East Indies.{{sfn|Steele|2003|pp=35–36}} The ship had a small quantity of nutmeg trees on board, which they left in . Nutmeg continues to be an important crop for the Grenadine economy.

==== Later colonial period after slavery ====
In 1877,  was made a [[Crown colony]]. [[Theophilus A. Marryshow]] founded the Representative Government Association (RGA) in 1918 to agitate for a new and participative constitutional dispensation for the  people. Due to Marryshow's lobbying, the Wood Commission of 1921–22 concluded that  was ready for constitutional reform in the form of a modified Crown colony government. This modification granted  the right to elect five of the 15 Legislative Council members on a restricted property franchise, enabling the wealthiest 4% of adult  to vote. Marryshow was named a [[1943 Birthday Honours#Commander of the Order of the  Empire (CBE)|Commander of the Order of the  Empire (CBE) in 1943]].

In 1950, [[Eric Gairy]] founded the [[ United Labour Party]] (GULP), initially as a trade union, which led to the 1951 [[general strike]] for better working conditions.{{sfn|Steele|2003|pp=35–36}} This sparked great unrest, and so many buildings were set ablaze that the disturbances became known as the "sky red" days. On 10 October 1951,  held its [[1951  general election|first general elections]] based on universal adult suffrage, with Gairy's party winning six of the eight seats contested.

From 1958 to 1962,  was part of the [[Federation of the West Indies]].{{sfn|Steele|2003|pp=35–36}} After the federation's collapse,  was granted full autonomy over its internal affairs as an Associated State on 3 March 1967. [[Herbert Blaize]] of the [[ National Party]] (GNP) was the first Premier of the Associated State of  from March to August 1967. Eric Gairy served as [[Premier of |Premier]] from August 1967 until February 1974.

=== Post-independence era ===
[[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-1982-0610-101, Berlin, Besuch Regierungsdelegation , Bootsfahrt.jpg|thumb|[[Maurice Bishop]] visiting East , 1982]]

Independence was granted on 7 February 1974 under the leadership of Eric Gairy, who became the first [[prime minister of ]].{{sfn|Steele|2003|pp=35–36}} This is annually commemorated as [[Independence Day ()|Independence Day]].  opted to remain within the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]], retaining Queen Elizabeth as [[Monarchy of |Monarch]], represented locally by a [[Governor-General of |governor-general]]. Civil conflict gradually broke out between Eric Gairy's government and some opposition parties, including the Marxist [[New JEWEL Movement]] (NJM). Gairy and the GULP won the [[1976  general election]], albeit with a reduced majority; however, the opposition deemed the results invalid due to fraud and the violent intimidation performed by the so-called '[[Mongoose Gang]]', a private militia loyal to Gairy.

On 13 March 1979, whilst Gairy was out of the country, the NJM launched a [[bloodless coup]] which removed Gairy, suspended the constitution, and established a [[People's Revolutionary Government]] (PRG), headed by [[Maurice Bishop]], who declared himself prime minister. His [[Marxism–Leninism|Marxist–Leninist]] government established close ties with [[]], [[]], and other [[communist bloc]] countries. All political parties except for the New Jewel Movement were banned and no elections were held during the four years of PRG rule.

=== Invasion by the  (1983) ===
{{main| invasion of }}
[[File:Eastern Caribbean Defense Force.jpg|thumb|Members of the Eastern Caribbean Defence Force during the 1983 [[invasion of ]].]]

==== Coup and execution of Maurice Bishop ====
Some years later,{{when|date=August 2021}} a dispute developed between Bishop and certain high-ranking members of the NJM. Though Bishop cooperated with  and the [[USSR]] on various trade and foreign policy issues, he sought to maintain a [[Non-Aligned Movement|non-aligned status]]. Hardline [[Marxist]] party members, including [[communist]] Deputy Prime Minister [[Bernard Coard]], deemed Bishop insufficiently revolutionary and demanded that he either step down or enter into a power-sharing arrangement.{{citation needed|date=July 2023}}

On 16 October 1983, Bernard Coard and his wife, Phyllis, backed by the  Army, led a coup against the government of Maurice Bishop and placed Bishop under [[house arrest]]. These actions led to street demonstrations in various parts of the island because Bishop had widespread support from the population. Because Bishop was a widely popular leader, he was freed by impassioned supporters who marched en masse to his guarded residence from a rally in the capital's central square. Bishop then led the crowd to the island's military headquarters to reassert his power.  soldiers were dispatched in armoured vehicles by the Coard faction to retake the fort. A confrontation between soldiers and civilians at the fort ended in gunfire and panic. Three soldiers and at least eight civilians died in the tumult that also injured 100 others, a school-sponsored study later found in 2000. When the initial shooting ended with Bishop's surrender, he and a group of seven of his closest supporters were taken prisoner and executed by firing squad. Besides Bishop, the group included three of his cabinet ministers, a trade union leader, and three service-industry workers.

After the execution of Bishop, the [[People's Revolutionary Army ()|People's Revolutionary Army]] (PRA) formed a military Marxist government with General [[Hudson Austin]] as chairman. The army declared a four-day total curfew, during which anyone leaving their home without approval would be shot on sight.

====  and allied response and reaction ====
[[File:M102 howitzers during Operation Urgent Fury.jpg|thumb|[[M102 howitzer]]s of [[320th Field Artillery Regiment]] firing during the 1983 [[invasion of ]].]]

US President [[Ronald Reagan]] stated that particularly worrying was the presence of  construction workers and military personnel building a {{convert|10000|ft|m|adj=on}} [[Point Salines International Airport|airstrip]] on . Bishop had stated the purpose of the airstrip was to allow commercial jets to land, but some US military analysts argued that the only reason for constructing such a long and reinforced runway was so that it could be used by heavy military transport planes. The contractors,  and European companies, and the [[European Economic Community|EEC]], which provided partial funding, all claimed the airstrip did not have military capabilities. Reagan asserted that , under the direction of the Soviet Union, would use  as a refuelling stop for  and Soviet airplanes loaded with weapons destined for Central  communist insurgents.

The Organization of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS), [[]], and  all appealed to the  for assistance. On 25 October 1983, combined forces from the  and the [[Regional Security System]] (RSS) based in  invaded  in an operation codenamed ''[[Invasion of |Operation Urgent Fury]]''. The US stated this was done at the behest of , [[]]{{citation needed|date=July 2019}} and Governor-General [[Paul Scoon]]. Scoon had requested the invasion through secret diplomatic channels, but it was not made public for his safety. Progress was rapid, and within four days the  had removed the military government of Hudson Austin.{{fact|date=July 2025}}

The invasion was criticised by the governments of Britain, [[]], and . The [[United Nations General Assembly]] condemned it as "a flagrant violation of international law" by a vote of 108 to 9, with 27 abstentions. The [[United Nations Security Council]] considered a similar resolution, which was supported by 11 countries. However, the  vetoed the motion.

==== Post-invasion arrests ====
After the invasion, the pre-revolutionary  constitution came into operation once again. Eighteen members of the PRG/PRA were arrested on charges related to the murder of Maurice Bishop and seven others. The 18 included the top political leadership of  at the time of the execution, along with the entire military chain of command directly responsible for the operation that led to the executions. Fourteen were [[Capital punishment|sentenced to death]], one was found not guilty, and three were sentenced to 45 years in prison. The death sentences were eventually commuted to terms of imprisonment. Those in prison have become known as the "[[ 17]]".

=== Since 1983 ===
When US troops withdrew from  in December 1983, Governor-General Scoon appointed an interim advisory council chaired by [[Nicholas Brathwaite]] to organise new elections. The first democratic elections since 1976 were [[1984  general election|held in December 1984]], and were won by the [[New National Party ()|New National Party]] under Herbert Blaize, who served as prime minister until his death in December 1989.

[[Ben Jones ()|Ben Jones]] briefly succeeded Blaize as prime minister and served until the [[1990  general election|March 1990 election]]. This election was won by the [[National Democratic Congress ()|National Democratic Congress]] under Nicholas Brathwaite, who served as prime minister until he resigned in February 1995. He was succeeded by [[George Brizan]] for a brief period until the [[1995  general election|June 1995 election]] which was won by the [[New National Party ()|New National Party]] under [[Keith Mitchell]], who went on to win the [[1999  general election|1999]] and [[2003  general election|2003 elections]], serving for a record 13 years until 2008. Mitchell re-established relations with  and also reformed the country's banking system, which had come under criticism over potential money laundering concerns.{{sfn|Steele|2003|pp=35–36}}

In 2000–02, much of the controversy of the late 1970s and early 1980s was once again brought into the public consciousness with the opening of the [[truth and reconciliation commission]]. The commission was chaired by a [[Holy Orders|Roman Catholic priest]], Father Mark Haynes, and was tasked with uncovering injustices arising from the PRA, Bishop's regime, and before. It held a number of hearings around the country. Brother Robert Fanovich, head of Presentation Brothers' College (PBC) in St. George's, tasked some of his senior students with conducting a research project into the era and specifically into the fact that Maurice Bishop's body was never discovered.
[[File: ivan.jpg|thumb|right|Aftermath of Hurricane Ivan in ]]

On 7 September 2004, after being hurricane-free for 49 years, the island was directly hit by [[Hurricane Ivan]]. Ivan struck as a [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 3 hurricane]], resulting in 39 deaths and damage or destruction to 90% of the island's homes.{{sfn|Steele|2003|pp=35–36}} On 14 July 2005, [[Hurricane Emily (2005)|Hurricane Emily]], a Category 1 hurricane at the time, struck the northern part of the island with {{convert|80|kn|km/h mph|adj=on}} winds, killing one person and causing an estimated US$110&nbsp;million (EC$297&nbsp;million) worth of damage.{{sfn|Steele|2003|pp=35–36}} Agriculture, and in particular the nutmeg industry, suffered serious losses, but that event caused changes in crop management and it is hoped that as new nutmeg trees mature, the industry will gradually rebuild.

Mitchell was defeated in the [[2008  general election|2008 election]] by the NDC under [[Tillman Thomas]]; however, he won the [[2013  general election]] by a landslide and the NNP returned to power, winning again by another landslide [[2018  general election|in 2018]]. In March 2020, [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in | confirmed its first case of COVID-19]] and, {{as of|2022|3|17|lc=on}}, 13,921 cases and 217 deaths had been recorded.

On 23 June 2022, the NDC won the [[2022  general election|general election]] under [[Dickon Mitchell]], who became prime minister the following day.

On 1 July 2024, [[Hurricane Beryl (2024)|Hurricane Beryl]] struck the island of Carriacou as a Category 4 hurricane, causing widespread damage across all of  and Carriacou. On Carriacou, there was no electricity and limited communication. Throughout the rest of the country, 95% of customers had no power and telecommunications were also damaged.
== History ==
{{Main|History of }}

{{For timeline|Timeline of  history}}

=== Prehistory ===
{{Main|Linear Pottery culture|Unetice culture|Urnfield culture|Celts}}

Ancient humans were present in  at least 600,000 years ago. The first non-modern human fossil (the [[Neanderthal]]) was discovered in the [[Neandertal (valley)|Neander Valley]]. Similarly dated evidence of modern humans has been found in the [[Caves and Ice Age Art in the Swabian Jura|Swabian Jura]], including 42,000-year-old [[Paleolithic flute|flutes]] which are the oldest musical instruments ever found, the 40,000-year-old [[Lion-man|Lion Man]], and the 41,000-year-old [[Venus of Hohle Fels]].

=== Germanic tribes, Roman frontier and the Frankish Empire ===
{{Main|Jastorf culture|Germanic peoples|Germania|Migration Period|Frankish Realm}}

[[File:Trier 012.JPG|thumb|[[Aula Palatina|Basilica of Constantine]] in [[Trier]] (''[[Augusta Treverorum]]''), built in the 4th century]]
The [[Germanic peoples]] are thought to have [[Ethnogenesis|emerged]] from the [[Jastorf culture]] during the [[Nordic Bronze Age]] or early [[Pre-Roman Iron Age|Iron Age]]. From southern [[Scandinavia]] and [[northern ]], they expanded south, east, and west, coming into contact with the [[Celts|Celtic]], [[ peoples|]], [[Balts|Baltic]], and [[Early Slavs|Slavic]] tribes. Southern  was inhabited by Celtic-speaking peoples, who belonged to the wider [[La Tène culture]]. They were later assimilated by the Germanic conquerors.

Under [[Augustus]], the [[Roman Empire]] began to invade lands inhabited by the Germanic tribes, creating a short-lived Roman province of [[Germania Antiqua|Germania]] between the Rhine and [[Elbe]] rivers. In 9 AD, three [[Roman legion]]s were [[Battle of the Teutoburg Forest|defeated]] by [[Arminius]] in the [[Battle of the Teutoburg Forest]]. The outcome of this battle dissuaded the Romans from their ambition of conquering [[Germania]] and is thus considered one of the most important events in [[European history]].{{sfn|Murdoch|2004|p=57}} By 100 AD, when [[Tacitus]] wrote ''[[Germania (book)|Germania]]'', Germanic tribes had settled along the Rhine and the Danube (the [[Limes Germanicus]]), occupying most of modern . However, [[Baden Württemberg|Baden-Württemberg]], southern [[Bavaria]], southern [[Hesse]] and the western [[Rhineland]] had [[Germanic Wars|been incorporated]] into [[Roman province]]s.{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|pp=9–13}}

Around 260, Germanic peoples broke into Roman-controlled lands. After the invasion of the [[Huns]] in 375, and with the decline of Rome from 395, Germanic tribes moved farther southwest: the Franks established the [[Frankish Kingdom]] and pushed east to subjugate [[Duchy of Saxony|Saxony]] and [[Duchy of Bavaria|Bavaria]]. Areas of modern eastern  were inhabited by [[West Slavs|Western Slavic]] tribes.{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|pp=9–13}}

{{Clear left}}

=== East Francia and the Holy Roman Empire ===
{{Main|East Francia|Holy Roman Empire}}

[[File:East Francia 843.svg|thumb|[[East Francia]] in 843]]
[[File:Lucas Cranach d.Ä. - Martin Luther, 1528 (Veste Coburg).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Martin Luther]], born in [[Eisleben]] in 1483, challenged the indulgences of the [[Catholic Church]], giving rise to the [[Reformation]] and [[Protestantism]].]]
[[Charlemagne]] founded the [[Carolingian Empire]] in 800; it was [[Treaty of Verdun|divided in 843]].{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|p= 11}} The eastern successor kingdom of [[East Francia]] stretched from the Rhine in the west to the Elbe river in the east and from the North Sea to the Alps.{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|p= 11}} Subsequently, the Holy Roman Empire emerged from it. The [[Ottonian]] rulers (919–1024) consolidated several major [[Stem duchy|duchies]]. In 996, [[Pope Gregory V|Gregory V]] became the first  Pope, appointed by his cousin [[Otto III]], whom he shortly after crowned Holy Roman Emperor. The Holy Roman Empire absorbed northern  and [[Burgundy (historical region)|Burgundy]] under the [[Salian]] emperors (1024–1125), although the emperors lost power through the [[Investiture Controversy]].

Under the [[House of Hohenstaufen|Hohenstaufen]] emperors (1138–1254),  princes encouraged  settlement to the south and east ({{lang|de|[[Ostsiedlung]]}}).{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|pp= 19–20}} Members of the [[Hanseatic League]], mostly north  towns, prospered in the expansion of trade.{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|pp= 13–24}} The population declined starting with the [[Great Famine of 1315–1317|Great Famine]] in 1315, followed by the [[Black Death]] of 1348–1350. The [[Golden Bull of 1356|Golden Bull]] issued in 1356 provided the constitutional structure of the Empire and codified the election of the emperor by seven [[prince-elector]]s.{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|p= 27}}

[[Johannes Gutenberg]] introduced moveable-type printing to Europe, laying the basis for the [[democratization of knowledge|democratisation of knowledge]]. In 1517, [[Martin Luther]] incited the Protestant Reformation and [[Luther Bible|his translation of the Bible]] began the standardisation of the language; the 1555 [[Peace of Augsburg]] tolerated the "Evangelical" faith ([[Lutheranism]]), but also decreed that the faith of the prince was to be the faith of his subjects ({{lang|la|[[cuius regio, eius religio]]}}). From the [[Cologne War]] through the [[Thirty Years' War]]s (1618–1648), religious conflict devastated  lands and significantly reduced the population.

The [[Peace of Westphalia]] ended religious warfare among the [[Imperial Estate]]s. The legal system initiated by a series of [[Imperial Reform]]s (approximately 1495–1555) provided for considerable local autonomy and a stronger [[Imperial Diet (Holy Roman Empire)|Imperial Diet]]. The [[House of Habsburg]] held the imperial crown from 1438 until the death of [[Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles VI]] in 1740. Following the [[War of the  Succession]] and the [[Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle (1748)|Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle]], Charles VI's daughter [[Maria Theresa]] ruled as [[Queen consort|empress consort]] when her husband, [[Francis I, Holy Roman Emperor|Francis I]], became emperor.

From 1740, [[ dualism|dualism]] between the  [[Habsburg monarchy]] and the [[Kingdom of Prussia]] dominated  history. In 1772, 1793, and 1795, Prussia and , along with the [[ Empire]], agreed to the [[Partitions of ]]. During the period of the [[ Revolutionary Wars]], the [[Napoleonic era]] and the subsequent [[Final Recess of the Reichsdeputation|final meeting of the Imperial Diet]], most of the [[Free Imperial Cities]] were annexed by dynastic territories; the ecclesiastical territories were secularised and annexed. In 1806 the {{lang|de|Imperium}} was dissolved; , , Prussia, and the Habsburgs () competed for hegemony in the  states during the [[Napoleonic Wars]].{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|p= 97}}

===  Confederation and Empire ===
{{Main| question| Confederation|Unification of | Empire| colonial empire}}

[[File: Confederation (1815).svg|thumb|The  Confederation in 1815]]
Following the fall of [[Napoleon]], the [[Congress of Vienna]] founded the  Confederation, a loose league of [[States of the  Confederation|39 sovereign states]]. The appointment of the [[emperor of ]] as the permanent president reflected the Congress's rejection of [[Prussia]]'s rising influence. Disagreement within [[Concert of Europe|restoration]] politics partly led to the rise of [[Liberalism in |liberal]] movements, followed by new measures of repression by  statesman [[Klemens von Metternich]]. The {{lang|de|[[Zollverein]]}}, a tariff union, furthered economic unity. In light of [[Revolutions of 1848|revolutionary movements in Europe]], intellectuals and commoners started the [[ revolutions of 1848–1849|revolutions of 1848 in the  states]], raising the  question. King [[Frederick William IV of Prussia]] was offered the title of emperor, but with a loss of power; he rejected the crown and the proposed constitution, a temporary setback for the movement.

[[File:Berlin Nationaldenkmal Kaiser Wilhelm mit Schloss 1900.jpg|thumb|right|[[Berlin Palace]], the main residence of the Kings of Prussia and  Emperors]]
King [[William I,  Emperor|William I]] appointed [[Otto von Bismarck]] as the [[Minister President of Prussia]] in 1862. Bismarck successfully concluded the [[Second Schleswig War|war with  in 1864]]; the subsequent decisive Prussian victory in the [[Austro-Prussian War]] of 1866 enabled him to create the [[North  Confederation]] which excluded [[ Empire|]]. After the defeat of  in the [[Franco-Prussian War]], the  princes proclaimed the founding of the  Empire in 1871. Prussia was the dominant constituent state of the new empire; the King of Prussia ruled as its [[ Emperor|Emperor]] ({{lang|de|Kaiser}}), and Berlin became its capital.

In the {{lang|de|[[Gründerzeit]]}} period following the unification of , Bismarck's foreign policy as [[chancellor of ]] secured 's position as a great nation by forging alliances and avoiding war. However, under [[Wilhelm II]],  took an [[New Imperialism|imperialistic]] course, leading to friction with neighbouring countries. [[Dual Alliance (1879)|A dual alliance]] was created with the [[multinational state|multinational realm]] of [[-]]; the [[Triple Alliance (1882)|Triple Alliance of 1882]] included . Britain,  and  also concluded alliances to protect against Habsburg interference with  interests in the Balkans or  interference against .{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|pp= 135, 149}} At the [[Berlin Conference]] in 1884,  claimed several [[List of former  colonies|colonies]] including [[ East Africa]], [[ South West Africa]], [[Togoland]], and [[Kamerun]]. Later,  further expanded its colonial empire to include holdings in the Pacific and [[]]. The colonial government in South West Africa (present-day [[]]), from 1904 to 1908, carried out the [[Herero and Nama genocide|annihilation of the local Herero and Nama peoples]] as punishment for an uprising; this was the 20th century's first [[genocide]].

[[Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of |The assassination]] of [[Archduke Franz Ferdinand of |'s crown prince]] on 28 June 1914 provided the pretext for - to attack  and trigger [[World War I]]. After four years of warfare, in which approximately two million  soldiers were killed, [[Armistice with |a general armistice]] ended the fighting. In the [[ Revolution of 1918–1919| Revolution]] (November 1918), Wilhelm II and the ruling princes [[abdication|abdicated]] their positions, and  was declared a [[federal republic]]. 's new leadership signed the [[Treaty of Versailles]] in 1919, accepting defeat by the [[Allies of World War I|Allies]].  perceived the treaty as humiliating, which was seen by historians as influential in the rise of [[Adolf Hitler]].  lost around 13% of its European territory and ceded all of its colonial possessions.

=== Weimar Republic and Nazi  ===
{{Main|Weimar Republic|Nazi }}

[[File:Hitler portrait crop.jpg|thumb|[[Adolf Hitler]], dictatorial ''[[Führer]]'' of Nazi  from 1933 until [[Death of Adolf Hitler|his suicide]] in 1945|upright]]

<!-- deleted, see Talk page [[File:Europe under Nazi domination.png|thumb|A map of [[-occupied Europe]] in 1942 during [[World War II]] with areas controlled by the  Reich shown in bold black]] -->
On 11 August 1919, President [[Friedrich Ebert]] signed the democratic [[Weimar Constitution]].{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|pp=156–160}} [[Bavarian Soviet Republic|Communists briefly seized power in Bavaria]] and a few larger cities, while conservative elements failed to overthrow the central government in the 1920 [[Kapp Putsch]]. The [[occupation of the Ruhr]] by  and  troops and a period of [[Hyperinflation in the Weimar Republic|hyperinflation]] followed. A [[Dawes Plan|plan to restructure 's war reparations]] and the creation of [[ Rentenmark|a new currency]] in 1924 helped stabilise the government and ushered in the [[Golden Twenties]], an era of artistic innovation and liberal cultural life.

The worldwide [[Great Depression]] hit  in 1929, and by 1932 the unemployment rate had risen to 24%. The [[Nazi Party]] led by Adolf Hitler became the largest party in the Reichstag after the [[July 1932  federal election|election of July 1932]], and [[President Hindenburg]] appointed Hitler chancellor on 30 January 1933.{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|pp=155–158, 172–177}} After the [[Reichstag fire]], [[Reichstag Fire Decree|a decree]] abrogated basic [[civil rights]], and the first [[Nazi concentration camps|Nazi concentration camp]] opened. On 23 March 1933, the [[Enabling Act of 1933|Enabling Act]] gave Hitler unrestricted legislative power, overriding the constitution, and marked the beginning of Nazi . His government established a centralised [[Totalitarianism|totalitarian state]], [[1933  referendum|withdrew from the League of Nations]], and dramatically increased the [[ re-armament|country's rearmament]]. A government-sponsored programme for economic renewal focused on public works, the most famous of which was the {{lang|de|[[Reichsautobahn|Autobahn]]}}.

In 1935, the regime withdrew from the Treaty of Versailles and introduced the [[Nuremberg Laws]] which targeted [[Jews]] and other [[Minority group|minorities]].  also reacquired control of the [[Territory of the Saar Basin|Saarland]] in 1935,{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|pp=188–189}} [[remilitarization of the Rhineland|remilitarised the Rhineland]] in 1936, [[Anschluss|annexed]]  in 1938, [[Sudetenland#Sudetenland as part of Nazi |annexed]] the Sudetenland in 1938 with the [[Munich Agreement]], and, in violation of the agreement, [[ occupation of |occupied ]] in March 1939. {{lang|de|[[Kristallnacht]]}} (Night of Broken Glass) saw the burning of synagogues, the destruction of Jewish businesses, and mass arrests of Jewish people.

In August 1939, [[Government of Nazi |Hitler's government]] negotiated the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact]] that divided Eastern Europe into  and [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] spheres of influence. On 1 September 1939,  [[invasion of |invaded ]], beginning [[European theatre of World War II|World War II in Europe]];{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|pp=190–195}} Britain and  declared war on  on 3 September. In the spring of 1940,  [[Operation Weserübung|conquered  and ]], [[ invasion of the |the ]], [[ invasion of  (1940)|]], [[ invasion of |]], and [[Battle of |]], forcing the  government to sign an [[armistice]]. The  repelled  air attacks in the [[Battle of Britain]] in the same year. In 1941,  troops [[Invasion of Yugoslavia|invaded Yugoslavia]], [[Battle of |]] and the [[Operation Barbarossa|Soviet Union]], and  declared war on the . By 1942,  and its allies controlled most of [[-occupied Europe|continental Europe]] and [[North Africa]], but following the Soviet victory at the [[Battle of Stalingrad]], the Allied [[North African Campaign|reconquest of North Africa]] and [[ Campaign (World War II)|invasion of ]] in 1943,  forces suffered repeated military defeats. In 1944, the Soviets [[Eastern Front (World War II)#Summer 1944|pushed into Eastern Europe]]; the Western allies [[Operation Overlord|landed in ]] and entered  despite a [[Battle of the Bulge|final  counteroffensive]]. Following [[Death of Adolf Hitler|Hitler's suicide]] during the [[Battle of Berlin]], [[ Instrument of Surrender| signed the surrender document]] on 8 May 1945, [[End of World War II in Europe|ending World War II in Europe]]{{sfn|Fulbrook |1991|pp=190–195}} and Nazi . Following the end of the war, surviving Nazi officials were tried for [[War crimes of the Wehrmacht|war crimes]] at the [[Nuremberg trials]].

In what later became known as [[the Holocaust]], the  government persecuted [[Holocaust victims|minorities]], including interning them in concentration and [[Extermination camp|death camps]] across Europe. The regime systematically murdered around 6 million [[Jews]], at least 130,000 [[Porajmos|Romani]], 275,000 [[Aktion T4|disabled]], thousands of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], thousands of [[Persecution of homosexuals in Nazi |homosexuals]], and hundreds of thousands of [[Nacht und Nebel|political and religious opponents]]. [[Generalplan Ost|Nazi policies in -occupied countries]] resulted in the deaths of an estimated 2.7&nbsp;million [[ people|Poles]], 1.3&nbsp;million [[]], 1&nbsp;million [[]] and 3.5&nbsp;million [[ mistreatment of Soviet prisoners of war|Soviet prisoners of war]]. [[ casualties in World War II| military casualties]] have been estimated at 5.3&nbsp;million, and around 900,000  civilians died. Around 12&nbsp;million [[Flight and expulsion of  (1944–1950)|ethnic  were expelled]] from across Eastern Europe, and  lost roughly [[Former eastern territories of |one-quarter]] of its pre-war territory.

=== East and West  ===
{{Main|History of  (1945–1990)|Allied-occupied |West |East }}

[[File:Thefalloftheberlinwall1989.JPG|thumb|The [[fall of the Berlin Wall]] in 1989 was one of the first developments in the end of the [[Cold War]], leading ultimately to the dissolution of the [[Soviet Union]].]]

After the surrender of Nazi , the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] ''[[de jure]]'' [[Berlin Declaration (1945)|abolished the  state]] and partitioned Berlin and 's remaining territory into four occupation zones. The western sectors, controlled by , the [[]], and the [[]], were merged on 23 May 1949 to form the Federal Republic of  (FRG) ({{langx|de|Bundesrepublik Deutschland}}); on 7 October 1949, the Soviet Zone became the  Democratic Republic (GDR) ({{lang|de|Deutsche Demokratische Republik}}; DDR). They were informally known as West  and East . East  selected [[East Berlin]] as its capital, while West  chose [[Bonn]] as a provisional capital to emphasise its stance that the two-state solution was temporary.

West  was established as a federal parliamentary republic with a [[social market economy]]. In 1948, West  became a major recipient of reconstruction aid under the  [[Marshall Plan]]. [[Konrad Adenauer]] was elected the first [[Federal Chancellor of the Federal Republic of |federal chancellor of ]] in 1949. The country enjoyed prolonged economic growth ({{lang|de|[[Wirtschaftswunder]]}}) beginning in the early 1950s. West  joined [[NATO]] in 1955 and was a founding member of the [[European Economic Community]]. On 1 January 1957, the [[Saar Protectorate|Saarland]] joined West .

East  was an [[Eastern Bloc]] state under political and military control by the [[Soviet Union]] via occupation forces and the [[Warsaw Pact]]. Although East  claimed to be a democracy, political power was exercised solely by leading members ({{lang|de|[[Politburo|Politbüro]]}}) of the communist-controlled [[Socialist Unity Party of ]], supported by the {{lang|de|[[Stasi]]|italic=no}}, an immense secret service. While [[Communist propaganda|East  propaganda]] was based on the benefits of the GDR's social programmes and the alleged threat of a West  invasion, many of its citizens looked to the West for freedom and prosperity. The [[Berlin Wall]], built in 1961, prevented East  citizens from escaping to West , becoming a symbol of the [[Cold War]].

Tensions between East and West  were reduced in the late 1960s by Chancellor [[Willy Brandt]]'s {{lang|de|[[Ostpolitik]]}}. In 1989,  decided to dismantle the [[Iron Curtain]] and [[Removal of 's border fence with |open its border with ]], causing the emigration of thousands of East  to West  via  and . This had devastating effects on the GDR, where [[Monday demonstrations in East |regular mass demonstrations]] received increasing support. In an effort to help retain East  as a state, the East  authorities eased border restrictions, but this actually led to an acceleration of the {{lang|de|Wende}} reform process, culminating in the ''[[Treaty on the Final Settlement with Respect to |Two Plus Four Treaty]]'' under which  regained full sovereignty. This permitted [[ reunification]] on 3 October 1990, with the accession of the [[New states of |five re-established states]] of the former GDR. The [[fall of the Berlin Wall]] in 1989 became a symbol of the [[fall of Communism]], the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]],  reunification and {{lang|de|[[Die Wende]]}} ("the turning point").

=== Reunified  and the European Union ===
{{Main| reunification|History of  since 1990}}

[[File:Berlin reichstag west panorama 2.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Berlin/Bonn Act]] made [[Berlin]] the [[capital of ]] again, with the [[Reichstag building|Reichstag]] becoming the seat of the [[ parliament]] in 1999.]]
United  was considered the enlarged continuation of [[West ]], so it retained its memberships in international organisations. Based on the [[Berlin/Bonn Act]] (1994), [[Berlin]] again became the [[capital of ]], while [[Bonn]] obtained the unique status of a {{lang|de|Bundesstadt}} (federal city), retaining some federal ministries. The relocation of the government was completed in 1999, and modernisation of the East  economy was scheduled to last until 2019.

Since reunification,  has taken a more active role in the [[European Union]], signing the [[Maastricht Treaty]] in 1992 and the [[Lisbon Treaty]] in 2007, and co-founding the [[eurozone]].  sent a peacekeeping force to secure stability in the [[1999 NATO bombing in Yugoslavia|Balkans]] and sent [[Bundeswehr| troops]] to [[]] as part of a NATO effort to provide [[War in  (2001–2021)|security in that country]] after the ousting of the [[Taliban]].

In the [[2005  federal election|2005 elections]], [[Angela Merkel]] became the first female chancellor. In 2009, the  government approved a €50&nbsp;billion stimulus plan. Among the major  political projects of the early 21st century are the advancement of [[European integration]], the [[Energy transition in |country's energy transition]] ({{lang|de|Energiewende}}) for a [[sustainable energy]] supply, the [[Debt brake ()|debt brake]] for balanced budgets, measures to increase the [[Ageing of Europe#|fertility rate]] ([[Natalistic politics|pronatalism]]), and [[high-tech]] strategies for the transition of the  economy, summarised as [[Industry 4.0]]. During the [[2015 European migrant crisis]], the country took in over a million refugees and migrants.
== History ==
{{Main|History of }}
[[File:Insulae Capitis viridis-1598.jpg|thumb|upright=1.15|''Insulae Capitis Viridis'' (1598), showing ]]
The archipelago was formed approximately 40–50 million years ago during the [[Eocene]] epoch. Before the arrival of Europeans, the  Islands were uninhabited. They were discovered by [[Republic of Genoa|Genoese]] and  navigators around 1456. According to  official records, the first discoveries were made by Genoa-born [[António de Noli]], who was afterwards appointed governor of  by  King [[Afonso V of |Afonso V]]. Other navigators mentioned as contributing to discoveries on the  archipelago are [[Diogo Dias]], Diogo Afonso, [[Republic of Venice|Venetian]] [[Alvise Cadamosto]] and [[Diogo Gomes]] (who had accompanied António de Noli on his voyage of discovery, and who claimed to have been the first to land on [[Santiago, |Santiago]] and the first to name that island).

In 1462,  settlers arrived at Santiago and founded a settlement they called Ribeira Grande. Today it is called [[Cidade Velha]] ("Old City"), to distinguish it from [[Ribeira Grande, |Ribeira Grande]]. The original Ribeira Grande was the first permanent European settlement in the [[tropics]].

In the 16th century, the archipelago prospered from the [[Atlantic slave trade]]. Pirates occasionally attacked the  settlements. [[Francis Drake]], an  [[privateer]], twice sacked Ribeira Grande in 1585 when it was a part of the [[Iberian Union]]. After a  attack in 1712, the town declined in importance relative to nearby [[Praia]], which became the capital in 1770.

The decline in the slave trade in the 19th century resulted in an economic crisis. 's early prosperity slowly vanished. However, the islands' position astride mid-Atlantic shipping lanes made  an ideal location for re-supplying ships. Because of its excellent harbour [[Mindelo]], located on the island of [[São Vicente, |São Vicente]], became an important commercial centre. Diplomat [[Edmund Roberts (diplomat)|Edmund Roberts]] visited  in 1832.  was the first stop of [[Charles Darwin]]'s voyage with {{HMS|Beagle}} in 1832.
[[File:Garthpool SLV AllanGreen.jpg|thumb|upright=1.15|The -built grain-ship ''[[Garthpool (barque)|Garthpool]]'', wrecked at [[Boa Vista, |Boa Vista]], in 1928]]
With few natural resources and inadequate sustainable investment from the , the citizens grew increasingly discontented with the colonial masters, who refused to provide the local authorities with more autonomy. In 1951,  changed 's status from a colony to an overseas province in an attempt to blunt growing nationalism.

In 1956, [[Amílcar Cabral]] and a group of fellow  and  organised (in [[ ]]) the clandestine [[African Party for the Independence of  and ]] (PAIGC). It demanded improvement in economic, social, and political conditions in  and   and formed the basis of the two nations' independence movement. Moving its headquarters to [[Conakry]], , in 1960, the PAIGC began an armed rebellion against  in 1961. Acts of sabotage eventually grew into a [[-Bissau War of Independence|war in  ]] that pitted 10,000 [[Eastern Bloc|Soviet Bloc]]-supported PAIGC soldiers against 35,000  and African troops.

By 1972, the PAIGC controlled much of   despite the presence of the  troops, but the organisation did not attempt to disrupt  control in .   declared independence in 1973 and was granted ''[[de jure]]'' independence in 1974. A budding independence movement—originally led by [[Amílcar Cabral]] who was assassinated in 1973—passed on to his half-brother [[Luís Cabral]] and culminated in independence for the archipelago in 1975.

=== Independence (1975) ===
Following the [[Carnation Revolution|April 1974 revolution in ]], the PAIGC became an active political movement in . In December 1974, the PAIGC and  signed an agreement providing for a transitional government composed of  and . On 30 June 1975,  elected a National Assembly which received the instruments of independence from  on 5 July 1975.

On 2 February 2024,  became the third African country to be free of [[malaria]].
== History ==
{{Main|History of }}

=== Pre-colonial ===
[[File:Templo de Kalasasaya, Tiwanaku.jpg|left|thumb|The [[Kalasasaya|Kalasasaya Temple]] of the [[Tiwanaku polity|Tiwanaku Polity]] (200 BC){{sfn|Kolata|1993|p=}}{{page needed|date=August 2025}}]]
The region now known as  had been occupied for over 2,500 years when the [[Aymara people|Aymara]] arrived; however, present-day Aymara associate themselves with the ancient civilization of the [[Tiwanaku Empire|Tiwanaku Polity]], which had its capital at [[Tiwanaku]], in Western . The capital city of Tiwanaku dates back as early as 1500 BC, when it was a small, agriculturally-based village.{{sfn|Fagan|2001|p=203}}

The [[Aymara people|Aymara]] community grew to urban proportions between AD 600 and AD 800, becoming an important regional power in the southern [[Andes]] from [[La Paz]]. According to early estimates,{{When|date=February 2014}} the city covered approximately {{convert|6.5|sqkm|abbr=off|sp=us}} at its peak, and had between 15,000 and 30,000 inhabitants.{{sfn|Kolata|1993|p=145}} However, in 1996, [[Satellite imagery|satellite imaging]] was used to map the extent of preserved ''suka kollus'' ([[Raised field|flooded raised fields]]) across the three primary valleys of [[Tiwanaku]], with the results suggesting a population-carrying capacity of anywhere between 285,000 and 1,482,000 people.{{sfn|Kolata|1996|p={{page needed|date=July 2013}}}}

Around AD 400, Tiwanaku went from being a locally-dominant force to a 'predatory' state, aggressively expanding its reach into the [[Yungas]] and bringing its culture and ways to new peoples in , , and . Nonetheless, Tiwanaku was not a violent or domineering culture; to expand its reach, the state exercised great political astuteness, created colonies, fostered local trade agreements (which made other cultures rather dependent), and instituted state cults.

As rainfall gradually decreased, the stores of food supplies decreased, and thus the elites lost power. Tiwanaku disappeared around AD 1000. The area remained uninhabited for centuries thereafter.{{sfn|Kolata|1993|p={{page needed|date=July 2013}}}}

Between 1438 and 1527, [[Incan Empire]] expanded from its capital at [[Cusco]], gaining control over much of what is now the  Andes, and extending its control into the fringes of the Amazon basin.

=== Colonial period ===
[[File:PMa BOL 108 Sucre.jpg|thumb|The [[Potosí|Villa Imperial de Potosí]], established in 1545, held great significance for the  colonial empire, as its abundant mineral wealth accounted for over half of the global silver production during the colonial period. ]]
The  conquest of the [[Inca empire]] began in 1524 and was mostly completed by 1533. The territory now called  was known as Charcas, and was under the authority of . Local government came from the [[Real Audiencia of Charcas|Audiencia de Charcas]] located in Chuquisaca (La Plata—modern [[Sucre]]). Founded in 1545 as a mining town, [[Potosí]] soon produced fabulous wealth, becoming the largest city in the [[New World]] with a population exceeding 150,000 people.

[[File:Church in Historic Center - Sucre - .jpg|thumb|[[Metropolitan Cathedral of Sucre]] in Sucre, a UNESCO World Heritage city]]
By the late 16th century,  silver was an important source of revenue for the [[ Empire]]. A steady stream of natives served as labor force under the brutal, slave conditions of the  version of the pre-Columbian draft system called the [[Mita (Inca)|mita]]. Charcas was transferred to the [[Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata]] in 1776 and the people from Buenos Aires, the capital of the Viceroyalty, coined the term "[[Upper ]]" ({{Langx|es|link=no|Alto }}) as a popular reference to the Royal Audiencia of Charcas. [[Túpac Katari]] led the indigenous rebellion that laid siege to [[La Paz]] in March 1781, during which 20,000 people died. As  royal authority weakened during the [[Napoleonic Wars]], sentiment against colonial rule grew.

=== Independence and subsequent wars ===
{{More citations needed section|date=May 2025}}{{Main|History of  (1809–1920)}}
