The [[ War of Independence|struggle for independence]] started in the city of [[Sucre]] on 25 May 1809 and the [[Chuquisaca Revolution]] (Chuquisaca was then the name of the city) is known as the first cry of Freedom in Latin America. That revolution was followed by the [[La Paz revolution]] on 16 July 1809. The La Paz revolution marked a complete split with the  government, while the Chuquisaca Revolution established a local independent junta in the name of the  King deposed by Napoleon Bonaparte. Both revolutions were short-lived and defeated by the  authorities in the Viceroyalty of the Rio de La Plata, but the following year the [[  wars of independence]] raged across the continent.

 was captured and recaptured many times during the war by the [[Royalist (  Revolution)|royalists]] and patriots. Buenos Aires sent three military campaigns, all of which were defeated, and eventually limited itself to protecting the national borders at Salta.  was finally freed of Royalist dominion by Marshal [[Antonio José de Sucre]], with a military campaign coming from the North in support of the campaign of [[Simón Bolívar]]. After 16 years of war the Republic was [[ Declaration of Independence|proclaimed]] on 6 August 1825.

[[File:Coat of arms of  (1825).svg|thumb|The first coat of arms of , formerly named the Republic of Bolívar in honor of [[Simón Bolívar]]]]

In 1836, , under the rule of [[Marshal]] [[Andrés de Santa Cruz]], invaded  to reinstall the deposed president, General [[Luis José de Orbegoso]].  and  formed the [[- Confederation]], with de Santa Cruz as the ''Supreme Protector''. Following tension between the Confederation and ,  declared war on 28 December 1836.  separately declared war on the Confederation on 9 May 1837. The - forces achieved several major victories during the [[War of the Confederation]]: the defeat of the  expedition and the defeat of the first  expedition on the fields of [[Paucarpata District|Paucarpata]] near the city of [[Arequipa]]. The  army and its  rebel allies surrendered unconditionally and signed the Paucarpata Treaty. The treaty stipulated that  would withdraw from -,  would return captured Confederate ships, economic relations would be normalized, and the Confederation would pay  debt to . However, the  government and public rejected the peace treaty.  organized a second attack on the Confederation and defeated it in the [[Battle of Yungay]]. After this defeat, Santa Cruz resigned and went to exile in  and then Paris, and the - Confederation was dissolved.
[[File:Fachada del Banco Nacional de , Sucre .jpg|left|thumb|Historic headquarters of [[Banco Nacional de ]] in Sucre]]
Following the renewed independence of ,  president General [[Agustín Gamarra]] invaded . On 18 November 1841, the battle de Ingavi took place, in which the  Army defeated the  troops of Gamarra (killed in the battle). After the victory,  invaded  on several fronts. The eviction of the  troops from the south of  would be achieved by the greater availability of material and human resources of ; the  Army did not have enough troops to maintain an occupation. In the district of Locumba – Tacna, a column of  soldiers and peasants defeated a  regiment in the so-called Battle of Los Altos de Chipe (Locumba). In the district of Sama and in Arica, the  colonel José María Lavayén organized a troop that managed to defeat the  forces of Colonel Rodríguez Magariños and threaten the port of Arica. In the battle of Tarapacá on 7 January 1842,  militias formed by the commander Juan Buendía defeated a detachment led by  colonel José María García, who died in the confrontation.  troops left Tacna, Arica and Tarapacá in February 1842, retreating towards Moquegua and Puno. The battles of Motoni and Orurillo forced the withdrawal of  forces occupying  territory and exposed  to the threat of counter-invasion. The Treaty of Puno was signed on 7 June 1842, ending the war. However, the climate of tension between Lima and La Paz would continue until 1847, when the signing of a Peace and Trade Treaty became effective.

A period of political and economic instability in the early-to-mid-19th century weakened . In addition, during the [[War of the Pacific]] (1879–83),  occupied vast territories rich in [[natural resources]] south west of , including the  [[coast]].  took control of today's [[Chuquicamata]] area, the adjoining rich ''salitre'' ([[Sodium nitrate|saltpeter]]) fields, and the port of [[Antofagasta]] among other  territories.

Since independence,  has lost over half of its territory to neighboring countries. Through diplomatic channels in 1909, it lost the basin of the Madre de Dios River and the territory of the Purus in the Amazon, yielding 250,000&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> to . It also lost the [[Acre (state)|state of Acre]], in the [[Acre War]], important because this region was known for its production of rubber. Peasants and the  army fought briefly but after a few victories, and facing the prospect of a total war against , it was forced to sign the [[Treaty of Petrópolis]] in 1903, in which  lost this rich territory. Popular myth has it that  president Mariano Melgarejo (1864–71) traded the land for what he called "a magnificent white horse" and Acre was subsequently flooded with , which ultimately led to confrontation and fear of war with .

In the late 19th century, an increase in the world price of silver brought  relative prosperity and political stability.

=== Early 20th century ===

{{Main|History of  (1920–1964)}}
[[File:Map  territorial loss-en.svg|thumb|left|'s territorial losses (1867–1938)]]
During the early 20th century, [[tin]] replaced silver as the country's most important source of wealth. A succession of governments controlled by the economic and social elite followed [[laissez-faire]] capitalist policies through the first 30 years of the 20th century.

Living conditions of the native people, who constitute most of the population, remained deplorable. With work opportunities limited to primitive conditions in the mines and in large estates having nearly feudal status, they had no access to education, economic opportunity, and [[Participation (decision making)|political participation]]. 's defeat by  in the [[Chaco War]] (1932–1935), where  lost a great part of the [[Gran Chaco]] region in dispute, marked a turning-point.

On 7 April 1943,  entered [[World War II]], joining part of the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]], which caused president [[Enrique Peñaranda]] to declare war on the [[Axis powers]] of [[Nazi |]], [[Fascist  (1922-1943)|]] and [[Empire of |]].

In 1945,  became a founding member of the United Nations.

The [[Revolutionary Nationalist Movement]] (MNR), the most historic political party, emerged as a broad-based party. Denied its victory in the 1951 presidential elections, the MNR led a successful revolution in 1952. Under President [[Víctor Paz Estenssoro]], the MNR, having strong popular pressure, introduced [[universal suffrage]] into his political platform and carried out a sweeping land-reform promoting rural education and nationalization of the country's largest tin mines.

=== Late 20th century ===

{{Main|History of  (1964–1982)}}
[[File:GralHugoBanzerSuarez.jpg|thumb|upright|In 1971, [[Hugo Banzer Suárez]], supported by the CIA, [[ involvement in regime change|forcibly ousted]] President Torres in a coup.]]
Twelve years of tumultuous rule left the MNR divided. In 1964, a military [[military dictatorship|junta]] overthrew President Paz Estenssoro at the outset of his third term. The 1969 death of President [[René Barrientos]], a former member of the junta who was elected president in 1966, led to a succession of weak governments. Alarmed by the rising Popular Assembly and the increase in the popularity of President [[Juan José Torres]], the military, the MNR, and others installed [[Hugo Banzer]] as president in 1971. He returned to the presidency in 1997 through 2001. Torres, who had fled , was kidnapped and assassinated in 1976 as part of [[Operation Condor]], the U.S.-supported campaign of political repression by South  right-wing dictators.

The ' [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA) financed and trained the  military dictatorship in the 1960s. The revolutionary leader [[Che Guevara]] was killed by a team of CIA officers and members of the  Army on 9 October 1967, in . [[Félix Rodríguez (soldier)|Félix Rodríguez]] was a CIA officer on the team with the  Army that captured and shot Guevara. Rodriguez said that after he received a  presidential execution order, he told "the soldier who pulled the trigger to aim carefully, to remain consistent with the  government's story that Che had been killed in action during a clash with the  army." Rodriguez said the US government had wanted Che in , and "I could have tried to falsify the command to the troops, and got Che to  as the US government said they had wanted", but that he had chosen to "let history run its course" as desired by .

Elections in 1978 were marked by fraud and those in 1979 were inconclusive. There were [[Coup d'état|coups d'état]], counter-coups, and caretaker governments. Following the 1980 election, General [[Luis García Meza]] carried out a coup d'état. The [[ Workers' Center]], which tried to resist the putsch, was violently repressed. More than a thousand people were killed in less than a year. Cousin of one of the most important narco-trafficker of the country, García Meza favored the production of cocaine. After a military rebellion forced out García Meza in 1981, three other military governments in fourteen months struggled with 's growing economic problems. Unrest forced the military to convoke the [[National Congress of |Congress]] elected in 1980, and allow it to choose a new president. In October 1982, [[Hernán Siles Zuazo]] again became president, twenty-two years after the end of his first term of office (1956–1960).

=== Democratic transition ===
{{main|History of  (1982–present)}}In 1993, [[Gonzalo Sánchez de Lozada]] was elected [[President of |president]] in alliance with the [[Revolutionary Liberation Movement Tupaq Katari|Tupac Katari Revolutionary Liberation Movement]], which inspired indigenous-sensitive and multicultural-aware policies. Sánchez de Lozada pursued an aggressive economic and social reform agenda. The most dramatic reform was privatization under the "capitalization" program, under which investors, typically foreign, acquired 50% ownership and management control of public enterprises in return for agreed upon capital investments. In 1993, Sanchez de Lozada introduced the ''Plan de Todos'', which led to the decentralization of government, introduction of [[intercultural bilingual education]], implementation of [[Agriculture|agrarian]] legislation, and [[privatization]] of state owned businesses. The plan explicitly stated that  citizens would own a minimum of 51% of enterprises; under the plan, most [[Government-owned corporation|state-owned enterprises]] (SOEs), though not mines, were sold. This privatization of SOEs led to a [[neoliberal]] structuring.<!--that acknowledged a diverse population within . – Acknowledged how so?-->

The reforms and economic restructuring were strongly opposed by certain segments of society, which instigated frequent and sometimes violent protests, particularly in La Paz and the Chapare [[coca]]-growing region, from 1994 through 1996. The indigenous population of the [[Andes|Andean]] region was not able to benefit from government reforms. During this time, the umbrella labor-organization of , the [[Central Obrera Boliviana]] (COB), became increasingly unable to effectively challenge government policy. A [[1995  state of siege|teachers' strike in 1995]] was defeated because the COB could not marshal the support of many of its members, including construction and factory workers.

====1997–2002 General Banzer presidency====
In the 1997 elections, General [[Hugo Banzer]], leader of the [[Nationalist Democratic Action]] party (ADN) and former dictator (1971–1978), won 22% of the vote, while the MNR candidate won 18%. At the outset of his government, President Banzer launched a policy of using special police-units to eradicate physically the illegal coca of the Chapare region. The [[Revolutionary Left Movement ()|Revolutionary Left Movement]] (MIR) of Jaime Paz Zamora remained a coalition-partner throughout the Banzer government, supporting this policy (called the Dignity Plan). The Banzer government continued the free-market and privatization-policies of its predecessor. The relatively robust economic growth of the mid-1990s continued until about the third year of its term in office. After that, regional, global and domestic factors contributed to a decline in economic growth. Financial crises in  and , lower world prices for export commodities, and reduced employment in the coca sector depressed the  economy. The public also perceived a significant amount of public sector corruption. These factors contributed to increasing social protests during the second half of Banzer's term.

Between January 1999 and April 2000, large-scale [[2000 Cochabamba protests|protests]] erupted in [[Cochabamba]], 's third largest city at the time, in response to the [[Water privatization|privatization of water]] resources by foreign companies and a subsequent doubling of water prices. On 6 August 2001, Banzer resigned from office after being diagnosed with cancer. He died less than a year later. Vice President [[Jorge Quiroga|Jorge Fernando Quiroga Ramírez]] completed the final year of his term.

==== 2002–2005 Sánchez de Lozada / Mesa presidency ====

In the June 2002 national elections, former President [[Gonzalo Sánchez de Lozada]] (MNR) placed first with 22.5% of the vote, followed by coca-advocate and native peasant-leader [[Evo Morales]] ([[Movement for Socialism ()|Movement Toward Socialism]], MAS) with 20.9%. A July agreement between the MNR and the fourth-place MIR, which had again been led in the election by former President Jaime Paz Zamora, virtually ensured the election of Sánchez de Lozada in the congressional run-off, and on 6 August he was sworn in for the second time. The MNR platform featured three overarching objectives: economic reactivation (and job creation), anti-corruption, and social inclusion.

In 2003, the [[ gas conflict]] broke out. On 12 October 2003, the government imposed martial law in El Alto after 16 people were shot by the police and several dozen wounded in violent clashes. Faced with the option of resigning or more bloodshed, Sánchez de Lozada offered his resignation in a letter to an emergency session of Congress. After his resignation was accepted and his vice president, [[Carlos Mesa]], invested, he left on a commercially scheduled flight for the .

The country's internal situation became unfavorable for such political action on the international stage. After a resurgence of gas protests in 2005, Carlos Mesa attempted to resign in January 2005, but his offer was refused by Congress. On 22 March 2005, after weeks of new street protests from organizations accusing Mesa of bowing to U.S. corporate interests, Mesa again offered his resignation to Congress, which was accepted on 10 June. The chief justice of the Supreme Court, [[Eduardo Rodríguez (politician)|Eduardo Rodríguez]], was sworn as interim president to succeed the outgoing Carlos Mesa.

====2005–2019 Morales presidency====
{{POV section|date=September 2020|talk=Talk:/Archive 2#NPOV}}
[[File:Presidentes_del_Perú_y_Bolivia_inauguran_Encuentro_Presidencial_y_III_Gabinete_Binacional_Perú-Bolivia_(36962597345)_(cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Former President, [[Evo Morales]]]]
[[Evo Morales]] won the [[ presidential election, 2005|2005 presidential election]] with 53.7% of the votes. On 1 May 2006, Morales announced his intent to [[ gas conflict|re-nationalize  hydrocarbon assets]] following protests which demanded this action. Fulfilling a campaign promise, on 6 August 2006, Morales opened the [[ Constituent Assembly]] to begin writing a new constitution aimed at giving more power to the indigenous majority.

2009 marked the creation of a new constitution and the renaming of the country to the Plurinational State of . The previous constitution did not allow a consecutive reelection of a president, but the new constitution allowed for just one reelection, starting the dispute if Evo Morales was enabled to run for a second term arguing he was elected under the last constitution. This also triggered a new general election in which Evo Morales was re-elected with 61.36% of the vote. His party, [[Movement for Socialism ()|Movement for Socialism]], also won a two-thirds majority in both houses of the [[National Congress of |National Congress]]. By 2013, after being reelected under the new constitution, Evo Morales and his party attempted a third term as President of . The opposition argued that a third term would be unconstitutional, but the  Constitutional Court ruled that Morales' first term under the previous constitution did not count towards his term limit. This allowed Evo Morales to run for a third term in 2014, and he was re-elected with 64.22% of the vote. During his third term, Evo Morales began to plan for a fourth, and the [[2016  constitutional referendum]] asked voters to override the constitution and allow Evo Morales to run for an additional term in office. Morales narrowly lost the referendum; however, in 2017 his party then petitioned the  Constitutional Court to override the constitution on the basis that the [[ Convention on Human Rights]] made term limits a human rights violation. The [[Inter- Court of Human Rights]] determined that term limits are not a human rights violation in 2018; however, once again the  Constitutional Court ruled that Morales has permission to run for a fourth term in the 2019 elections, and this permission was not retracted. "[T]he country's highest court overruled the constitution, scrapping term limits altogether for every office. Morales can now run for a fourth term in 2019 – and for every election thereafter."

The revenues generated by the partial [[nationalization]] of hydrocarbons made it possible to finance several social measures: the Renta Dignidad (or old age minimum) for people over 60 years old; the Juana Azurduy voucher (named after the revolutionary Juana Azurduy de Padilla, 1780–1862), which ensures the complete coverage of medical expenses for pregnant women and their children in order to fight infant mortality; the Juancito Pinto voucher (named after a child hero of the Pacific War, 1879–1884), an aid paid until the end of secondary school to parents whose children are in school in order to combat school dropout, and the Single Health System, which since 2018 has offered all  free medical care.

The reforms adopted made the  economic system the most successful and stable in the region. Between 2006 and 2019, GDP grew from $9 billion to over $40 billion, real wages increased, GDP per capita tripled, foreign exchange reserves rose, inflation was essentially eliminated, and extreme poverty fell from 38% to 15%, a 23-point drop.

==== Interim government 2019–2020 ====
{{See also|2019  general election|2019  political crisis}}

During the 2019 elections, the [[2019  general election|''Transmisión de Resultados Electorales Preliminares'' (TREP)]] (a quick count process used in Latin America as a transparency measure in electoral processes) was interrupted; at the time, Morales had a lead of 46.86 percent to Mesa's 36.72, after 95.63 percent of tally sheets were counted. Two days after the interruption, the official count showed Morales fractionally clearing the 10-point margin he needed to avoid a runoff election, with the final official tally counted as 47.08 percent to Mesa's 36.51 percent, starting a wave of protests and tension in the country.

Amidst allegations of fraud perpetrated by the Morales government, widespread [[2019  protests|protests]] were organized to dispute the election. On 10 November, the [[Organization of  States]] (OAS) released a preliminary report concluding several irregularities in the election, though these findings were heavily disputed. ''The New York Times'' reported on 7 June 2020 that the OAS analysis immediately after the 20 October election was flawed yet fuelled "a chain of events that changed the South  nation's history".

[[File:Mapa Electoral de  2020 .svg|thumb|[[2020  general election]], results by department]]
[[File:Canciller Andrés Allamand participa del saludo protocolar al Presidente de , Luis Arce, y al Vicepresidente, David Choquehuanca 02.jpg|thumb|Inauguration of [[Luis Arce]] and [[David Choquehuanca]] on 8 November 2020]]
After weeks of protests, Morales resigned on national television shortly after the Commander-in-Chief of the armed forces General [[Williams Kaliman]] had urged that he do so to restore "peace and stability". Opposition Senator [[Jeanine Áñez]] declared herself interim president, claiming constitutional succession after the president, vice president and both head of the legislature chambers. She was confirmed as interim president by the constitutional court who declared her succession to be constitutional and automatic. International politicians, scholars and journalists are divided between describing the event as a coup or a spontaneous social uprising against an unconstitutional fourth term. Protests to reinstate Morales as president continued becoming highly violent: burning public buses and private houses, destroying public infrastructure and harming pedestrians. The protests were met with more violence by security forces against Morales supporters after Áñez exempted police and military from criminal responsibility in operations for "the restoration of order and public stability".

In April 2020, the interim government took out a loan of more than $327&nbsp;million from the [[International Monetary Fund]] to meet the country's needs during the [[COVID-19 pandemic]]. New elections were scheduled for 3 May 2020. In response to the [[COVID-19 pandemic|coronavirus pandemic]], the  electoral body, the TSE, made an announcement postponing the election. MAS reluctantly agreed with the first delay only. A date for the new election was delayed twice more, in the face of massive protests and violence. The final proposed date for the elections was 18 October 2020. Observers from the OAS, UNIORE, and the UN all reported that they found no fraudulent actions in the 2020 elections.

The [[2020  general election|general election]] had a record voter turnout of 88.4% and ended in a landslide win for MAS which took 55.1% of the votes compared to 28.8% for centrist former president Carlos Mesa. Both Mesa and Áñez conceded defeat.

==== Government of Luis Arce: 2020–2025 ====
On 8 November 2020, [[Luis Arce]] was sworn in as President of  alongside his Vice President [[David Choquehuanca]]. In February 2021, the Arce government returned an amount of around $351&nbsp;million to the IMF. This comprised a loan of $327&nbsp;million taken out by the interim government in April 2020 and interest of around $24&nbsp;million. The government said it returned the loan to protect 's economic sovereignty and because the conditions attached to the loan were unacceptable.

===== Coup d'état attempt of Juan José Zúñiga: 2024 =====
{{main|2024  coup d'état attempt}}

On 26 June 2024, a military coup attempt led by [[Juan José Zúñiga]] ended after lasting only 5 hours. In the evening of 26 June,  police arrested Zúñiga.

=== Election 2025 and Rodrigo Paz administration (2025-present) ===
Main article: [[2025  general election]]

In October 2025, [[Rodrigo Paz Pereira|Rodrigo Paz]] of the centre-right [[Christian Democratic Party ()|Christian Democratic Party]] (PDC) won the run-off race of the [[2025  general election|election]] against right-wing former president [[Jorge  Quiroga]], meaning the end of governance by the Movement for Socialism (MAS) party and a clear political shift to the right. 
On 8 November 2025, Rodrigo Paz was sworn in as ’s new president during 's worst economic crisis in 40 years.
==History==
{{Main|History of }}
{{For timeline|Timeline of  history}}

===Prehistory===
{{further|Prehistory of the Levant}}
The [[Ubeidiya prehistoric site]] in northern  shows the [[Early expansions of hominins out of Africa|presence of archaic humans]] around 1.5 million years ago. The second-oldest evidence of [[anatomically modern human]]s [[Recent African origin of modern humans|outside Africa]] is a 200,000-year-old fossil from [[Misliya Cave]] on Mount Carmel. The [[Natufian culture]] ({{circa}} 10,000 BCE) may be linked to the [[Proto-Afroasiatic language]] and is notable for adopting [[sedentism]] before the [[Origins of agriculture in West Asia|advent of agriculture]] and the [[Neolithic Revolution]].

===Bronze and Iron Ages===
{{Main|History of ancient  and Judah}}
[[File:Ruins atop Tel Megiddo with circular altar-like shrine and a series of temples on top of the other dating from the early bronze-age through the iron-age periods, Tel Meggido,  (19888642855).jpg|thumb|[[Tel Megiddo]], the ruins of a Canaanite and later Israelite city]]
Early references to "[[Canaan]]" and "Canaanites" appear in ancient [[Ancient Near East|Near Eastern]] and [[Ancient |]] texts ({{Circa}} 2000 BCE); these populations were structured as politically independent [[city-state]]s. During the [[Late Bronze Age]] (1550–1200 BCE), large parts of Canaan formed [[vassal state]]s of the [[New Kingdom of ]]. As a result of the [[Late Bronze Age collapse]], Canaan fell into chaos, and  control over the region collapsed. Ancestors of the [[Israelites]] are thought to have included [[ancient Semitic-speaking peoples]] native to this area.{{rp|78–79}} Modern archaeological accounts suggest that the Israelites and their culture branched out of the Canaanite peoples through the development of a distinct [[Monolatry|monolatristic]]—and later [[Monotheism|monotheistic]]—religion centered on [[Yahweh]]. They spoke an archaic form of [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], known as [[Biblical Hebrew]]. Around the same time, the [[Philistines]] settled on the southern [[ coastal plain|coastal plain]].{{sfn|Killebrew|2005|p=230}}{{sfn|Shahin|2005|p=6}}

Most modern scholars agree that the [[The Exodus|Exodus]] narrative in the [[Torah]] and [[Old Testament]] did not take place as depicted; however, some elements of these traditions do have [[Historicity of the Bible|historical roots]]. There is debate about the earliest existence of the [[History of ancient  and Judah|Kingdoms of  and Judah]] and their extent and power. While it is unclear if there was a [[Kingdom of  (united monarchy)| of ]], historians and archaeologists agree that the northern [[Kingdom of  (Samaria)|Kingdom of ]] existed by {{Abbr|ca.|circa}} 900 BCE{{rp|169–195}} and the [[Kingdom of Judah]] by {{Abbr|ca.|circa}} 850 BCE. The Kingdom of  was the more prosperous of the two and soon developed into a regional power, with a capital at [[Samaria (ancient city)|Samaria]]; during the [[Omrides|Omride dynasty]], it controlled [[Samaria]], [[Galilee]], the upper [[ Valley]], the [[Sharon plain|plain of Sharon]] and large parts of [[ (region)|]].

The Kingdom of  was conquered around 720 BCE by the [[Neo-Assyrian Empire]]. The Kingdom of Judah, under [[Davidic line|Davidic]] rule with its capital in [[Jerusalem]], later became a [[client state]] of first the Neo-Assyrian Empire and then the [[Neo-Babylonian Empire]]. It is estimated that [[Demographic history of  (region)|the region's population]] was around 400,000 in the [[Iron Age II]]. In 587/6 BCE, following a [[Judah's revolts against Babylon|revolt in Judah]], King [[Nebuchadnezzar II]] [[Siege of Jerusalem (587 BC)|besieged and destroyed Jerusalem]] and [[Solomon's Temple]], dissolved the kingdom and [[Babylonian captivity|exiled much of the Judean elite to Babylon]].

=== Classical antiquity ===
{{Main|Second Temple period}}
After [[Fall of Babylon|capturing Babylon]] in 539 BCE, [[Cyrus the Great]], founder of the [[Achaemenid Empire]], issued [[Edict of Cyrus|a proclamation]] allowing the exiled Judean population to return. The construction of the [[Second Temple]] was completed {{Circa|520 BCE}}. The Achaemenids ruled the region as the province of [[Yehud Medinata]]. In 332 BCE, [[Alexander the Great]] conquered the region as part of his [[Wars of Alexander the Great|campaign against the Achaemenid Empire]]. After his death, the area was controlled by the [[Ptolemaic Kingdom|Ptolemaic]] and [[Seleucid Empire|Seleucid]] empires as a part of [[Coele-]]. Under the Hellenistic kingdoms, ongoing [[Hellenization]] generated cultural tensions among the Jewish population that culminated under [[Antiochus IV Epiphanes|Antiochus IV]], whose decrees outlawed Jewish practices and triggered the [[Maccabean Revolt]] in 167 BCE. The revolt weakened Seleucid control over Judea; by 142/141 BCE the [[Hasmonean dynasty|Hasmoneans]] had secured autonomy and soon established an [[Hasmonean Judea|independent Jewish kingdom]] that, in the late 2nd–early 1st century BCE, expanded into neighboring territories.

[[File:-2013-Aerial 21-Masada.jpg|thumb|upright|View of the [[Masada]] fortress overlooking the [[Dead Sea]], which is the location of a [[Siege of Masada|1st-century Roman siege]]]]
The [[Roman Republic]] invaded the region in 63 BCE, first [[Third Mithridatic War|taking control of ]], and then intervening in the [[Hasmonean civil war]]. [[Roman–Parthian Wars|The struggle]] between pro-Roman and pro-[[Parthian Empire|Parthian]] factions in Judea led to the installation of [[Herod the Great]] as a [[Herodian dynasty|dynastic vassal]] of [[Ancient Rome|Rome]]. In 6 CE, the area was annexed as the [[Judaea (Roman province)|Roman province of Judaea]]; tensions with Roman rule led to a series of [[Jewish–Roman wars]], resulting in widespread destruction. The [[First Jewish–Roman War]] (66–73 CE) resulted in the [[Siege of Jerusalem (70 CE)|destruction of Jerusalem and the Second Temple]] and a sizable portion of the population being killed or displaced.

A second uprising known as the [[Bar Kokhba revolt]] (132–136 CE) initially allowed the Jews to form an independent state, but the Romans brutally crushed the rebellion, devastating and depopulating Judea's countryside. Jerusalem was rebuilt as a [[Colonia (Roman)|Roman colony]] ([[Aelia Capitolina]]), and the province of Judea was renamed [[ Palaestina]]. Jews were expelled from the districts surrounding Jerusalem. Nevertheless, there was a continuous small Jewish presence, and Galilee became its religious center.

=== Late antiquity and the medieval period ===
{{further|Byzantine |Bilad al-Sham|Kingdom of Jerusalem}}
[[File:Ruins of the Ancient Synagogue at Bar'am.jpg|thumb|3rd-century [[Kfar Bar'am synagogue]] in the Galilee]]
During the [[Byzantine |Byzantine period]], [[Early Christianity]] displaced [[Religion in ancient Rome|Roman paganism]] in the 4th century CE, with [[Constantine the Great|Constantine]] embracing and promoting the Christian religion and [[Theodosius I]] making it [[Christianity as the Roman state religion|the state religion]]. A series of laws were passed that discriminated against Jews and Judaism, and Jews were persecuted by both the church and the authorities. Many Jews had emigrated to flourishing [[Jewish diaspora|diaspora]] communities, while locally there was both Christian immigration and local conversion. By the middle of the 5th century, there was a Christian majority. Towards the end of the 5th century, [[Samaritan revolts]] erupted, continuing until the late 6th century and resulting in a large decrease in the Samaritan population. After the [[Sasanian conquest of Jerusalem]] and the short-lived [[Jewish revolt against Heraclius]] in 614 CE, the Byzantine Empire [[Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628|reconsolidated control of the area]] in 628.

In 634–641 CE, the [[Rashidun Caliphate]] [[Muslim conquest of the Levant|conquered the Levant]]. Caliph [[Umar ibn al-Khattab]] ({{Reign|634|644}}) lifted the Christian ban on Jews entering [[Jerusalem]] and permitted them to worship there. Over the next six centuries, control of the region transferred between the [[Umayyad Caliphate|Umayyad]], [[Abbasid Caliphate|Abbasid]], and [[Fatimid Caliphate|Fatimid]] caliphates, and subsequently the [[Seljuk dynasty|Seljuk]] and [[Ayyubid dynasty|Ayyubid]] dynasties. The population drastically decreased during the following several centuries, dropping from an estimated 1 million during Roman and Byzantine periods to about 300,000 by the early [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman period]], and there was steady [[Arabization|Arabisation]] and [[Islamization|Islamisation]]. The end of the 11th century brought the [[Crusades]], [[Pope|papally]]-sanctioned incursions of Christian crusaders intent on wresting Jerusalem and the [[Holy Land]] from Muslim control and establishing [[crusader states]]. The Ayyubids pushed back the crusaders before Muslim rule was fully restored by the [[Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)|Mamluk sultans of ]] in 1291.

=== Modern period and the emergence of Zionism ===
{{main|Jerusalem Sanjak|Mutasarrifate of Jerusalem}}
{{further|Old Yishuv|Zionism}}
[[File:Jews at Western Wall by Felix Bonfils, 1870s.jpg|thumb|Jews at the [[Western Wall]] in the 1870s]]
In 1516, the Ottoman Empire conquered the region and ruled it as part of [[Ottoman ]]. Two violent incidents took place against Jews, the [[1517 Safed attacks]] and the [[1517 Hebron attacks]], after the  Ottomans ousted the [[Mamluk]]s during the [[Ottoman–Mamluk War (1516–1517)|Ottoman–Mamluk War]]. Under the Ottoman Empire, the Levant was fairly cosmopolitan, with religious freedoms for [[People of the Book|Christians, Muslims, and Jews]]. In 1561 the [[Suleiman the Magnificent|Ottoman sultan]] invited [[Sephardic Jews]] escaping the [[ Inquisition]] to settle in and rebuild the city of [[Tiberias]].

Under the Ottoman Empire's [[Millet (Ottoman Empire)|millet system]], Christians and Jews were considered ''[[dhimmi]]'' ("protected") under [[Ottoman law]] in exchange for loyalty to the state and payment of the ''[[jizya]]'' tax. Non-Muslim Ottoman subjects faced geographic and lifestyle restrictions, though these were not always enforced. The millet system organised non-Muslims into autonomous communities on the basis of religion.

[[File:THEODOR HERZL AT THE FIRST ZIONIST CONGRESS IN BASEL ON 25.8.1897. תאודור הרצל בקונגרס הציוני הראשון - 1897.8.25.jpg|thumb|The [[First Zionist Congress]] (1897) in [[Basel]], ]]
The [[Return to Zion|concept of an eventual return to Zion]] remained a symbol within religious Jewish belief which emphasised that their return should be determined by [[Divine providence in Judaism|Divine Providence]] rather than human action.{{sfn|Avineri|2017}} The Jewish population of  from the Ottoman rule to the beginning of the Zionist movement, known as the [[Old Yishuv]], comprised a minority and fluctuated in size. During the 16th century, Jewish communities struck roots in the [[Four Holy Cities]]—Jerusalem, Tiberias, [[Hebron]], and [[Safed]]—and in 1697, Rabbi Yehuda Hachasid led 1,500 Jews to Jerusalem. A 1660 [[Druze power struggle (1658–1667)# and Galilee campaign|Druze revolt]] against the Ottomans destroyed [[1660 destruction of Safed|Safed]] and [[1660 destruction of Tiberias|Tiberias]]. In the second half of the 18th century, Eastern European Jews who were [[Misnagdim|opponents]] of [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidism]], known as the [[Perushim]], settled in .

In the late 18th century, local Arab Sheikh [[Zahir al-Umar]] created a de facto independent emirate in the Galilee. Ottoman attempts to subdue the sheikh failed. After Zahir's death the Ottomans regained control of the area. In 1799, governor [[Jazzar Pasha]] repelled an [[Siege of Acre (1799)|assault on Acre]] by [[Napoleon]]'s troops, prompting the  to abandon the  campaign. In 1834, a [[Peasants' revolt in |revolt by  Arab peasants]] against  conscription and taxation policies under [[Muhammad Ali of |Muhammad Ali]] was suppressed; Muhammad Ali's army retreated and Ottoman rule was restored with  support in 1840. The [[Tanzimat]] reforms were implemented across the Ottoman Empire.

The first wave of modern Jewish migration to [[Southern |Ottoman-ruled ]], known as the [[First Aliyah]], began in 1881, as Jews fled [[pogrom]]s in Eastern Europe. The 1882 [[May Laws]] increased economic discrimination against Jews, and restricted where they could live. In response, political [[Zionism]] took form, a movement that sought to establish a [[Jewish state]] in , thus offering a solution to the [[Jewish question]] of the European states.{{sfn|Herzl|1946|p=11}}{{better source needed|date=September 2024}} Antisemitism, pogroms and official policies in tsarist  led to the emigration of three million Jews in the years between 1882 and 1914, only 1% of whom went to . Those who went to  were driven primarily by ideas of self-determination and Jewish identity, rather than as a response to pogroms or economic insecurity.{{sfn|Avineri|2017}}

The [[Second Aliyah]] (1904–1914) began after the [[Kishinev pogrom]]; some 40,000 Jews settled in , although nearly half left eventually. Both the first and second waves of migrants were mainly [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jews]]. The Second Aliyah included [[Labor Zionism|Zionist socialist]] groups who established the ''[[kibbutz]]'' movement based on the idea of establishing a separate Jewish economy based exclusively on Jewish labour.{{sfn|Romano|2003|p=30}} Those of the Second Aliyah who became leaders of the [[Yishuv]] in the coming decades believed that the Jewish settler economy should not depend on Arab labour. This would be a dominant source of antagonism with the Arab population, with the new Yishuv's nationalist ideology overpowering its socialist one. Though the immigrants of the Second Aliyah largely sought to create communal Jewish agricultural settlements, [[Tel Aviv]] was established as the first planned Jewish town in 1909. Jewish armed militias emerged during this period, the first being [[Bar-Giora (organization)|Bar-Giora]] in 1907. Two years later, the larger [[Hashomer]] organisation was founded as its replacement.

===  Mandate for  ===
{{main|Mandatory }}
{{further|Yishuv|Intercommunal conflict in Mandatory |1948  war}}
{{see also|Jewish land purchase in }}

[[Chaim Weizmann]]'s efforts to garner  support for the Zionist movement eventually secured the [[Balfour Declaration]] of 1917, stating Britain's support for the creation of a Jewish "[[Homeland for the Jewish people|national home]]" in . Weizmann's interpretation of the declaration was that negotiations on the future of the country were to happen directly between Britain and the Jews, excluding Arabs. [[Islamic–Jewish relations|Jewish-Arab relations]] in  deteriorated dramatically in the following years.

In 1918, the [[Jewish Legion]], primarily Zionist volunteers, assisted in the  [[Sinai and  campaign|conquest of ]]. In 1920, the territory was divided between Britain and  under the [[League of Nations mandate|mandate system]], and the -administered area (including modern ) was named [[Mandatory ]]. Arab opposition to  rule and Jewish immigration led to the [[1920 Nebi Musa riots|1920  riots]] and the formation of a Jewish militia known as the [[Haganah]] as an outgrowth of Hashomer, from which the [[Irgun]] and [[Lehi (group)|Lehi]] paramilitaries later split. In 1922, the [[League of Nations]] granted Britain the [[Mandate for ]] under terms which included the Balfour Declaration with its promise to the Jews and with similar provisions regarding the Arab . The [[Demographic history of  (region)|population of the area]] was predominantly Arab and Muslim, with Jews accounting for about 11% and Arab Christians about 9.5% of the population.
[[File:"Jews and Arabs in Grim Struggle for Holy Land" article (1938).jpg|thumb|"Jews and Arabs in Grim Struggle for Holy Land", article from 1938]]

The [[Third Aliyah|Third]] (1919–1923) and [[Fourth Aliyah]]s (1924–1929) brought an additional 100,000 Jews to . The [[Adolf Hitler's rise to power|rise of Nazism]] and the increasing persecution of Jews in 1930s Europe led to the [[Fifth Aliyah]], with an influx of a quarter of a million Jews. This was a major cause of the [[1936–1939 Arab revolt in |Arab revolt of 1936–39]], which was suppressed by  security forces and Zionist militias. Several hundred  security personnel and Jews were killed; 5,032 Arabs were killed, 14,760 wounded, and 12,622 detained. An estimated ten percent of the adult male [[ people| Arab]] population was killed, wounded, imprisoned, or exiled.

The  introduced restrictions on Jewish immigration to  with the [[White Paper of 1939]]. With countries around the world turning away Jewish refugees fleeing [[the Holocaust]], a clandestine movement known as [[Aliyah Bet]] was organised to bring Jews to . By the end of [[World War II]], 31% of the population of  was Jewish. The UK found itself facing a [[Jewish insurgency in Mandatory |Jewish insurgency]] over immigration restrictions and continued conflict with the Arab community over limit levels. The Haganah joined Irgun and Lehi in an armed struggle against  rule.{{sfn|Fraser|2004|p=27}} The Haganah attempted to bring tens of thousands of Jewish refugees and [[Holocaust survivors]] to  by ship. Most of the ships were intercepted by the [[Royal Navy]] and the refugees placed in detention camps in [[Atlit detainee camp|Atlit]] and [[ internment camps|]].

On 22 July 1946, Irgun [[King David Hotel bombing|bombed the  administrative headquarters]] for , killing 91. The attack was a response to [[Operation Agatha]] (a series of raids, including one on the [[Jewish Agency for |Jewish Agency]], by the ) and was the deadliest directed at the  during the Mandate era. The Jewish insurgency continued throughout 1946 and 1947 despite concerted efforts by the  military and [[ Police Force]] to suppress it.

 efforts to mediate with Jewish and Arab representatives were not successful as the Jews were unwilling to accept any solution that did not involve a Jewish state and suggested a partition of  into Jewish and Arab states, while the Arabs were adamant that a Jewish state in any part of  was unacceptable and that the only solution was a unified  under Arab rule. In February 1947, the  referred the  issue to the newly formed [[United Nations]]. On 15 May 1947, the [[General Assembly of the United Nations|UN General Assembly]] resolved that a [[United Nations Special Committee on |Special Committee]] be created "to prepare ... a report on the question of ". The Report of the Committee [[United Nations Partition Plan for |proposed a plan]] to replace the  Mandate with "an independent Arab State, an independent Jewish State, and the City of Jerusalem [...] the last to be under an International Trusteeship System".

Meanwhile, the Jewish insurgency continued and peaked in July 1947, with a series of widespread guerrilla raids culminating in [[the Sergeants affair]], in which the Irgun took two  sergeants hostage as attempted leverage against the planned execution of three Irgun operatives. After the executions were carried out, the Irgun killed the two  soldiers, hanged their bodies from trees, and left a booby trap at the scene which injured a  soldier. The incident caused widespread outrage in the UK. In September 1947, the  cabinet decided to evacuate  as the Mandate was no longer tenable.

[[File:UN  Partition Versions 1947.jpg|thumb|upright|[[United Nations Partition Plan for |UN Map]], " plan of partition with economic union"]]

On 29 November 1947, the General Assembly adopted [[United Nations Partition Plan for |Resolution 181 (II)]]. The plan attached to the resolution was essentially that proposed in the report of 3 September. The Jewish Agency, the recognised representative of the Jewish community, accepted the plan, which assigned 55–56% of Mandatory  to the Jews. At the time, the Jews were about a third of the population and owned around 6–7% of the land. Arabs constituted the majority and owned about 20% of the land, with the remainder held by the Mandate authorities or foreign landowners.

The [[Arab League]] and [[Arab Higher Committee]] of  rejected the partition plan on the basis that the partition plan privileged European interests over those of the , and indicated that they would reject any other plan of partition.{{sfn|Bregman|2002|pp=40–41}} On 1 December 1947, the Arab Higher Committee proclaimed a three-day strike, and [[1947 Jerusalem riots|riots broke out in Jerusalem]]. The situation spiralled into [[1947–1948 civil war in Mandatory |a civil war]]. Colonial Secretary [[Arthur Creech Jones]] announced that the  Mandate would end on 15 May 1948, at which point the  would evacuate. As Arab militias and gangs attacked Jewish areas, they were faced mainly by the Haganah as well as the smaller Irgun and Lehi. In April 1948, the Haganah moved onto the offensive.{{sfn|Morris|2008|p=77–78}}

=== State of  ===
{{main|History of  (1948–present)}}

==== Independence and early years ====
{{further| Declaration of Independence}}
[[File:Declaration of State of  1948.jpg|thumb|right|[[David Ben-Gurion]] declaring the [[ Declaration of Independence|establishment of ]] on 14 May 1948]]

On 14 May 1948, the day before the expiration of the  Mandate, [[David Ben-Gurion]], the head of the Jewish Agency, [[ Declaration of Independence|declared "the establishment of a Jewish state in Eretz-"]]. The following day, the armies of four Arab countries—, , , and —entered what had been Mandatory , launching the [[1948 Arab– War]];{{sfn|Ben-Sasson|1985|p=1058}} contingents from [[Mutawakkilite Kingdom of |]], [[]], [[]], and [[]] joined the war.{{sfn|Morris|2008|p=205}} The purpose of the invasion was to prevent the establishment of the Jewish state. The Arab League stated the invasion was to restore order and prevent further bloodshed.

[[File:Raising the Ink Flag at Umm Rashrash (Eilat) (3x4).jpg|thumb|right|Raising of the [[Ink Flag]] on 10 March 1949, marking the end of the [[1948 Arab– War|1948 war]]]]

After a year of fighting, a [[1949 Armistice Agreements|ceasefire was declared]] and temporary borders, known as the [[Green Line ()|Green Line]], were established. [[ annexation of the West Bank| annexed]] what became known as the [[West Bank]], including [[East Jerusalem]], and [[Occupation of the Gaza Strip by the United Arab Republic| occupied]] the [[Gaza Strip]]. Over 700,000  [[1948  expulsion and flight|fled or were expelled]] by [[Zionist political violence|Zionist militias]] and the [[ Defense Forces| military]]—what would become known in Arabic as the {{lang|ar-Latn|[[Nakba]]}} ('catastrophe'). The events also led to the destruction of most of 's Arab [[Culture of |culture]], [[ identity|identity]], and [[ nationalism|national aspirations]]. Some 156,000 Arabs remained and became [[Arab citizens of ]].

By [[United Nations General Assembly Resolution 273]],  was admitted as a member of the UN on 11 May 1949. In the early years of the state, the [[Labor Zionism|Labour Zionist]] movement led by Prime Minister Ben-Gurion dominated [[Politics of | politics]].{{sfn|Lustick|1988|pp=37–39}} Immigration to  during the late 1940s and early 1950s was aided by the  Immigration Department and the non-government sponsored [[Mossad LeAliyah Bet]] ({{Abbr|lit.|literally|class=small}} "Institute for [[Aliyah Bet|Immigration B]]"). The latter engaged in clandestine operations in countries, particularly in the Middle East and Eastern Europe, where the lives of Jews were in danger and exit was difficult. Mossad LeAliyah Bet was disbanded in 1953. The immigration was in accordance with the [[One Million Plan]]. Some immigrants held Zionist beliefs or came for the promise of a better life, while others moved to escape persecution or were expelled from their homes.

An [[Aliyah#Early statehood (1948–1960)|influx of Holocaust survivors]] and [[Jewish exodus from the Muslim world|Jews from Arab and Muslim countries]] to  during the first three years increased the number of Jews from 700,000 to 1,400,000. By 1958, the population had risen to two million. Between 1948 and 1970, approximately 1,150,000 Jewish refugees relocated to . Some immigrants arrived as refugees and were housed in temporary camps known as ''[[ma'abarot]]''; by 1952, over 200,000 people were living in these tent cities. [[Ashkenazi Jews|Jews of European background]] were often treated more favourably than Jews from [[Mizrahi Jews|Middle Eastern]] and [[Sephardi Jews|North African]] countries—housing units reserved for the latter were often re-designated for the former, so Jews newly arrived from Arab lands generally ended up staying longer in transit camps.{{sfn|Segev|2007|pp=155–157}} During this period, food, clothes and furniture were rationed in what became known as the [[Austerity in |austerity period]]. The need to solve the crisis led Ben-Gurion to sign a [[Reparations Agreement between  and the Federal Republic of |reparations agreement with West ]] that triggered mass protests by Jews angered at the idea that  could accept monetary compensation for the Holocaust.{{sfn|Shindler|2002|pp=49–50}}

==== Arab– conflict ====
{{Main|Arab– conflict}}

There were [[1949–1956  expulsions|further expulsions of ]] after the establishment of . During the 1950s,  was [[List of attacks against  civilians before 1967|frequently attacked]] by [[ fedayeen]], nearly always against civilians, mainly from the -occupied Gaza Strip,{{sfn|Gilbert|2005|p=58}} leading to several  [[reprisal operations]]. In 1956, the UK and  aimed at regaining control of the [[Suez Canal]], which  had nationalised. The continued blockade of the Suez Canal and [[Straits of Tiran]] to  shipping, together with increasing fedayeen attacks against 's southern population and recent Arab threatening statements, prompted  to attack .  joined [[Protocol of Sèvres|a secret alliance]] with the UK and  and overran the [[Sinai Peninsula]] in the [[Suez Crisis]] but was pressured to withdraw by the UN in return for guarantees of  shipping rights. The war resulted in significant reduction of  border infiltration.

[[File:1961-04-13 Tale Of Century - Eichmann Tried For War Crimes.ogv|thumb|U.S. newsreel on the trial of [[Adolf Eichmann]]]]
In the early 1960s,  captured Nazi war criminal [[Adolf Eichmann]] in  and brought him to  [[Eichmann trial|for trial]].{{sfn|Bascomb|2009|p=219–229}} Eichmann remains the only person executed in  by conviction in an  civilian court. In 1963,  was engaged in a diplomatic standoff with the  in relation to the  [[Nuclear weapons and |nuclear programme]].

Since 1964 Arab countries, concerned over  plans to divert waters of the [[ River]] into the [[ coastal plain|coastal plain]], had been trying to divert the headwaters to deprive  of water resources, [[War over Water ( River)|provoking tensions]] between  on the one hand, and  and  on the other. [[Arab nationalist]]s led by  President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] refused to recognise  and called for its destruction. By 1966 -Arab relations had deteriorated to the point of battles taking place between  and Arab forces.{{sfn|Segev|2007|p=178}}

In May 1967,  massed its army near the border with , expelled [[United Nations Emergency Force|UN peacekeepers stationed in the Sinai Peninsula]] since 1957, and blocked 's access to the Red Sea. Other Arab states mobilised their forces.{{sfn|Segev|2007|p=289}}  reiterated that these actions were a ''[[casus belli]]'' and launched a pre-emptive strike ([[Operation Focus]]) against  in June. ,  and  attacked .

[[File:Six Day War Territories.svg|thumb|Territory held by : {{legend|#ffffd0|before the [[Six-Day War]]}} {{legend|#f7d3aa|after the war}} The [[Sinai Peninsula]] was returned to  in 1982.]]

In the ensuing [[Six-Day War]],  captured and occupied the West Bank from , the Gaza Strip and Sinai Peninsula from , and the Golan Heights from .  forces [[Naksa|expelled ~300,000 ]] from the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. Jerusalem's boundaries were enlarged, incorporating [[East Jerusalem]]. The 1949 Green Line became the administrative boundary between  and the [[-occupied territories|occupied territories]].{{sfn|Shlay|Rosen|2010|pp=362–363}}

Following the 1967 war and the "[[Khartoum Resolution|Three Nos]]" resolution of the Arab League,  faced attacks from the  in the Sinai Peninsula during the 1967–1970 [[War of Attrition]], and from  groups targeting  in the occupied territories, globally, and in . Most important among the  and Arab groups was the [[ Liberation Organization| Liberation Organisation]] (PLO), established in 1964, which initially committed itself to "armed struggle as the only way to liberate the homeland". In the late 1960s and early 1970s, [[ political violence| groups launched attacks]] against  and Jewish targets around the world, including [[Munich massacre|a massacre of  athletes]] at the [[1972 Summer Olympics]] in Munich. The  government responded with an [[Mossad assassinations following the Munich massacre|assassination campaign]] against the organisers of the massacre, [[1972  air raid in  and |a bombing]] and a [[1973  raid in |raid on the PLO headquarters in ]].

On 6 October 1973, the  and  armies launched [[Operation Badr (1973)|a surprise attack]] against  forces in the Sinai Peninsula and Golan Heights, opening the [[Yom Kippur War]]. The war ended on 25 October with  repelling  and  forces but suffering great losses. An [[Agranat Commission|internal inquiry]] exonerated [[Fifteenth government of |the government]] of responsibility for failures before and during the war, but public anger forced Prime Minister [[Golda Meir]] to resign.{{better source needed|date=February 2023}} In July 1976, an airliner was hijacked in flight from  to  by  guerrillas;  commandos [[Operation Entebbe|rescued 102 of 106  hostages]].

==== Peace process ====
{{main|– peace process}}
The [[1977  legislative election|1977 Knesset elections]] marked a major turning point in  political history as [[Menachem Begin]]'s [[Likud]] party took control from the [[ Labor Party|Labour Party]]. Later that year,  President [[Anwar El Sadat]] made a trip to  and spoke before the [[Knesset]] in what was the first recognition of  by an Arab head of state.{{sfn|Bregman|2002|pp=171–174}} Sadat and Begin signed the [[Camp David Accords]] (1978) and the [[– peace treaty]] (1979).{{sfn|Bregman|2002|pp=186–187}} In return,  withdrew from the Sinai Peninsula and agreed to enter negotiations over autonomy for  in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.{{sfn|Bregman|2002|pp=186–187}}

On 11 March 1978, a PLO guerilla raid from  led to the [[Coastal Road massacre]].  responded by launching an [[1978 South  conflict|invasion of southern ]] to destroy PLO bases. Begin's government meanwhile provided incentives for [[ settlement| to settle]] in the [[ occupation of the West Bank|occupied West Bank]], increasing friction with the  there.

The 1980 [[Jerusalem Law]] was believed by some to reaffirm 's 1967 annexation of Jerusalem by government decree and [[UN Security Council Resolution 478|reignited international controversy]] over the [[Status of Jerusalem|status of the city]]. No  legislation has defined the territory of , and no act specifically included East Jerusalem therein. In 1981  [[Golan Heights Law|effectively annexed]] the Golan Heights. The international community largely rejected these moves, with the UN Security Council declaring both the Jerusalem Law and the Golan Heights Law null and void. Several waves of [[Beta | Jews]] [[Aliyah from |immigrated to ]] since the 1980s, while between 1990 and 1994, [[1990s post-Soviet aliyah|immigration from the post-Soviet states]] increased 's population by twelve percent.

On 7 June 1981, during the [[– War]], the [[Operation Opera| air force destroyed]] 's sole nuclear reactor, then under construction, in order to impede the  nuclear weapons programme. Following a series of PLO attacks in 1982,  [[1982  War|invaded ]] to destroy the PLO bases.{{sfn|Bregman|2002|p=199}} In the first six days,  destroyed the military forces of the PLO in  and decisively defeated the . An  government inquiry (the [[Kahan Commission]]) held Begin and several  generals indirectly responsible for the [[Sabra and Shatila massacre]] and held [[Ministry of Defense ()|defence minister]] [[Ariel Sharon]] as bearing "personal responsibility". Sharon was forced to resign.

In 1985,  responded to a  [[Larnaca yacht killings|terrorist attack in ]] by [[Operation Wooden Leg|bombing the PLO headquarters]] in .  withdrew from most of  in 1986 but continued to [[ occupation of Southern |occupy a borderland buffer zone]] in southern  until 2000, from where  forces [[South  conflict (1985–2000)|engaged in conflict]] with [[Hezbollah]]. The [[First Intifada]], a  uprising against  rule, broke out in 1987, with waves of uncoordinated demonstrations and violence in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. Over the following six years, the intifada became more organised and included economic and cultural measures aimed at disrupting the  occupation. Over 1,000 people were killed. During the 1991 [[Gulf War]], the PLO supported [[Saddam Hussein]] and  missile [[ rocket attacks on |attacks against ]]. Despite public outrage,  heeded  calls to refrain from hitting back.{{sfn |Mowlana |Gerbner |Schiller |1992 |p=111}}

[[File:Flickr - Government Press Office (GPO) - Foreign Min. Peres and King Hussein.jpg|thumb|[[Shimon Peres]] (left) with [[Yitzhak Rabin]] (center) and King [[Hussein of ]] (right), prior to signing the [[– peace treaty]] in 1994]]
In 1992, [[Yitzhak Rabin]] became prime minister following [[1992  legislative election|an election]] in which his party called for compromise with 's neighbours.{{sfn|Bregman|2002|p=236}} The following year, [[Shimon Peres]] on behalf of  and [[Yasser Arafat]] for the PLO signed the [[Oslo Accords]], which gave the [[ Authority| National Authority]] (PNA) the right to govern [[West Bank areas in the Oslo II Accord|parts of the West Bank]] and the Gaza Strip. The PLO also [[– Liberation Organization letters of recognition|recognised 's right to exist]] and pledged an end to terrorism.{{sfn|Tessler|2009|p=729}} In 1994, the [[– peace treaty]] was signed, making  the second Arab country to normalise relations with . Arab public support for the Accords was damaged by the continuation of  settlements and [[ checkpoint|checkpoints]], and the deterioration of economic conditions.  public support for the Accords waned after [[List of  suicide attacks| suicide attacks]]. In November 1995, Rabin [[assassination of Yitzhak Rabin|was assassinated]] by [[Yigal Amir]], a far-right Jew who opposed the Accords.

During [[Benjamin Netanyahu]]'s premiership at the end of the 1990s,  [[Protocol Concerning the Redeployment in Hebron|agreed to withdraw]] from [[Hebron]],{{sfn|Bregman|2002|p=257}} though this was never ratified or implemented, and he signed the [[Wye River Memorandum]]. The agreement dealt with further redeployments in the West Bank and security issues. The memorandum was criticised by major international human rights organisations for its "encouragement" of human rights abuses.
[[Ehud Barak]], [[1999  general election|elected]] prime minister in 1999, withdrew forces from southern  and conducted negotiations with PNA Chairman Yasser Arafat and U.S. President [[Bill Clinton]] at the [[2000 Camp David Summit]]. Barak offered a plan for the establishment of a [[ state]], including the entirety of the Gaza Strip and over 90% of the West Bank with Jerusalem as a shared capital.{{sfn|Gelvin|2005|p=240}} Each side blamed the other for the failure of the talks.

In late 2000, after a controversial visit by Sharon to the [[Temple Mount]], the [[Second Intifada]] began. The popular uprising faced disproportionate repression from the  state. [[ suicide attacks| suicide bombings]] eventually developed into a recurrent feature of the intifada. Some commentators contend that the intifada was pre-planned by Arafat after the collapse of peace talks. Sharon became prime minister in a [[2001  prime ministerial election|2001 election]]; he carried out his plan to [[ disengagement from the Gaza Strip|unilaterally withdraw]] from the Gaza Strip and spearheaded the construction of the [[West Bank barrier]], ending the intifada. Between 2000 and 2008, 1,063 , 5,517  and 64 foreign citizens were killed.

In July 2006, a Hezbollah artillery assault on 's northern border communities and a [[2006 Hezbollah cross-border raid|cross-border abduction]] of two  soldiers precipitated the month-long [[2006  War|Second  War]], including an  invasion of . The war wound down in August 2006 after the passage of [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1701]];  forces mostly withdrew from  by October 2006 but continued to occupy the  portion of [[Ghajar]] village. In 2007 the  Air Force [[Operation Outside the Box|destroyed a nuclear reactor]] in .

==== Gaza– conflict ====
{{Main|Gaza– conflict}}

In 2008, [[2008 –Hamas ceasefire|a ceasefire]] between [[Hamas]] and  collapsed, resulting in the three-week [[Gaza War (2008–2009)|Gaza War]]. In what  described as a response to [[List of  rocket attacks on  in 2012|over a hundred  rocket attacks]] on southern  cities,  began [[2012 Gaza War|an operation in the Gaza Strip]] in 2012, lasting eight days.  started another [[2014 Gaza War|operation in Gaza]] following an escalation of rocket attacks by Hamas in July 2014. In May 2021, another [[2021 – crisis|round of fighting]] took place in Gaza and , lasting eleven days. By the 2010s, [[Arab– alliance|increasing regional cooperation]] between  and [[Arab League]] countries have been established, culminating in the signing of the [[Abraham Accords]]. The  security situation shifted from the traditional [[Arab– conflict]] towards the [[– proxy conflict]] and [[– conflict during the  civil war|direct confrontation with  during the  civil war]].

[[File:Fires in  and the Gaza strip - 7 October 2023 (53245908850).jpg|thumb|Satellite view of fires in the [[Gaza envelope]] on 7 October 2023]]
On 7 October 2023,  militant groups from Gaza, led by Hamas, launched [[7 October Hamas-led attack on |a series of coordinated attacks]] on , leading to the start of the [[Gaza war]]. On that day, approximately 1,300 , predominantly civilians, were killed in communities near the Gaza Strip border and [[Re'im music festival massacre|during a music festival]]. [[Gaza war hostage crisis|Over 200 hostages]] were kidnapped and taken to the Gaza Strip. Studies modeling trauma exposure and assessing mental health outcomes estimated that approximately 5.3% of  may develop PTSD, with national data showing that probable PTSD nearly doubled from 16.2% to 29.8% and rates of anxiety and depression also rising sharply.

After clearing militants from its territory,  launched [[ bombing of the Gaza Strip|one of the most destructive bombing campaigns in modern history]] and [[ invasion of the Gaza Strip|invaded Gaza]] on 27 October with the stated objectives of destroying Hamas and freeing hostages. The fifth war of the [[Gaza– conflict]] since 2008, it has been the deadliest for  in the entire [[– conflict]] and the most significant military engagement in the region since the [[Yom Kippur War]] in 1973. A [[Special Committee to Investigate  Practices Affecting the Human Rights of the  People|United Nations Special Committee]], [['s genocide case against |multiple governments]], and various experts and human rights organisations have concluded that  is committing [[Gaza genocide|genocide against the  people]] due to the harm and loss of life inflicted on civilians during the [[Gaza war|Gaza War]].

In April 2024,  initiated a wave of airstrikes on , after  strikes targeted , marking the [[2024 – conflict]] the first time in which the two countries have ever directly exchanged fire. In October 2024,  [[2024  invasion of |invaded ]] and exchanged missile barrages with  three weeks later, in response of  strikes earlier in that month. After nearly a year of the [[–Hezbollah conflict (2023–present)|–Hezbollah conflict]] from October 2023 due to Hezbollah shooting rockets at  to support Hamas in Gaza,  [[2024 Hezbollah headquarters strike|assassinated]] Hezbollah secretary general [[Hassan Nasrallah]] in September 2024. A November 2024 [[2024 – ceasefire agreement|ceasefire agreement]] instructed  to withdraw from , which  mostly did by February 2025, but against the agreement  forces stayed in five military outposts on highlands in Southern . In June 2025,  launched a renewed series of airstrikes on , targeting 's air defense systems, missile launchers, their military leadership, and their [[Nuclear program of |nuclear program]], which escalated into a [[– war|full-scale war]].
== History ==
{{main|History of }}
{{See also|Timeline of  history}}

=== Prehistory and antiquity ===
{{multiple image
| align             = right
| width1            = 140
| image1            = Mohenjo-daro Priesterkönig.jpeg
| caption1          = ''[[Priest-king (sculpture)|Priest-King]]'' from [[Mohenjo-daro]] ({{circa|2500 BCE}}){{sfn|Parker|2017}}
| width2            = 140
| image2            = Cremation Urn with Lid LACMA AC1994.234.8a-b.jpg
| caption2          = Cremation urn, [[Gandhara grave culture]], Swat Valley, {{circa|1200 BCE}}{{sfn|Burrison|2017}}
}}
Some of the earliest ancient human civilisations in [[South Asia]] originated from areas encompassing present-day .{{sfn|Allchin|Petraglia|2007}} The earliest known stone tools in the region, dating to the [[Lower Palaeolithic]] (~2 million years ago), were discovered in the [[Soan Valley]] of [[northern ]].{{sfn|Rendell|Dennell|1985}} The [[Indus River|Indus region]], which covers most of the present-day , was the site of several successive ancient cultures including the [[Neolithic]] (7000–4300 [[BCE]]) site of [[Mehrgarh]],{{R|Coningham-Young-2015|Fisher-2018|Dyson-2018}} and the 5,000-year history of urban life in South Asia to the various sites of the [[Indus Valley Civilisation]], including [[Mohenjo-daro]] and [[Harappa]].{{R|Allchin-1982}}{{sfn|Dales|Kenoyer|Alcock|1986}}

Following the decline of the Indus Valley civilisation, semi-nomadic [[Indo-Aryan peoples|Indo-European Aryans]] migrated into the [[ subcontinent]] around 2000 BCE, perhaps by way of the [[Khyber Pass]]. They fused with the indigenous Harappan culture of the Indus Valley, and elements of the pre-Aryan spiritual traditions were assimilated into the developing Vedic tradition.{{sfn|Consiglio|2015}} This cultural milieu shaped the [[Gandhara civilization]], which flourished at the crossroads of , Central Asia, and the Middle East, connecting [[Silk Road|trade routes]] and absorbing cultural influences from diverse civilizations.{{sfn|Behrendt|2007}} By the early Vedic period, parts of the Indus region in present-day  were populated by numerous tribes that were beginning to coalesce into chieftain-led clans and early kingdoms.{{sfn|Flood|2022}} During this period, the [[Vedas]], the oldest [[scriptures]] of [[Hinduism]], were composed.{{sfn|Oberlies|2023}}{{efn|name="Rigveda"}}

=== Classical period ===
[[File:Gandhara Buddha (tnm).jpeg|thumb|''[[Standing Buddha]]'' from [[Gandhara]] (1st–2nd century CE){{sfn|Stonard|2017}}|upright=0.8]]
The western regions of  [[Achaemenid conquest of the Indus Valley|became part]] of [[Achaemenid Empire]] around 517&nbsp;BCE.{{sfn|Dandamaev|2023}} In 326&nbsp;BCE, [[Alexander the Great]] conquered the region by defeating various local rulers, most notably, the King [[Porus]], at [[Battle of Hydaspes|Jhelum]].{{sfn|Sadasivan|2011}} Among the major powers that ruled the region were the [[Mauryas]] (322–185 BCE), during which [[Ashoka the Great]] extended the empire.{{sfn|Khan|2022|page=114}}{{sfn|Cooke|2017}} The [[Indo- Kingdom]] founded by [[Demetrius I of Bactria|Demetrius of Bactria]] (180–165&nbsp;BCE) included [[Gandhara]] and [[Punjab]] and reached its greatest extent under [[Menander I|Menander]] (165–150&nbsp;BCE), prospering the [[Greco-Buddhism|Greco-Buddhist]] culture in the region.{{sfn|Pollitt|1986}}{{sfn|Quintanilla|2007}}{{sfn|Kubica|2023}} [[Taxila]] had one of the earliest universities and centres of higher education in the world, which was established during the late Vedic period in the 6th century BCE.{{sfn|Westmoreland|2019}} The ancient university was documented by the invading forces of Alexander the Great and was also recorded by  pilgrims in the 4th or 5th century CE.{{refn|name="Needham-1994"}}{{refn|name="Kulke-Rothermund-2016"}}{{sfn|Mookerji|1989}} At its zenith, the [[Rai dynasty]] (489–632&nbsp;CE) ruled [[Sindh]] and the surrounding territories.{{sfn|Banerjee|2022}}

=== Medieval period ===
The Arab conqueror [[Muhammad ibn Qasim]] conquered Sindh and some regions of Punjab in 711&nbsp;CE.{{sfn|Mufti|2013}} The  government's official chronology claims this as the time when the foundation of  was laid.{{sfn|Hoodbhoy|2023}} The early medieval period (642–1219&nbsp;CE) witnessed the spread of Islam in the region.{{sfn|Cavendish|2006|page=318}} Before the arrival of Islam beginning in the 8th century, the region of  was home to a diverse plethora of faiths, including [[Hinduism]], [[Buddhism]], [[Jainism]] and [[Zoroastrianism]].{{R|Stubbs-Thomson-2016}}{{sfn|Malik|2006|page=47}} During this period, [[Sufi]] [[Dawah|missionaries]] played a pivotal role in converting a majority of the regional population to Islam.{{sfn|Lapidus|2014}} Upon the defeat of the [[Turk Shahis|Turk]] and [[Hindu Shahi]] dynasties which governed the [[Kabul Valley]], [[Gandhara]], and western Punjab in the 7th to 11th centuries CE, [[Muslim conquest in the  subcontinent|several successive Muslim empires]] ruled over the region, including the [[Ghaznavids|Ghaznavid Empire]] (975–1187&nbsp;CE), the [[Ghorid]] Kingdom, and the [[Delhi Sultanate]] (1206–1526&nbsp;CE).{{sfn|Samad|2011}} The [[Lodi dynasty]], the last of the Delhi Sultanate, was replaced by the Mughal Empire (1526–1857&nbsp;CE).{{sfn|Faroqhi|2019}}

[[File:View_of_Makli_by_Usman_Ghani_(cropped).jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|[[Makli Necropolis]], a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]] rose to prominence as a major funerary site during the [[Samma dynasty]]{{sfn|Junejo|2020}}]]

The Mughals introduced Persian literature and high culture, establishing the roots of [[Indo-Persian culture]] in the region.{{sfn|Canfield|2002}} In the region of modern-day , key cities during the Mughal period were [[Multan]], [[Lahore]], [[Peshawar]] and [[Thatta]],{{sfn|Chandra|2005}} which were chosen as the site of impressive [[Mughal architecture|Mughal buildings]].{{sfn|Malik|2006|page=79}} In the early 16th century, the region remained under the [[Mughal Empire]].{{sfn|Metcalf|Metcalf|2006}} In the 18th century, the slow disintegration of the Mughal Empire was hastened by the emergence of the rival powers like the [[Maratha Empire]] and later the [[Sikh Empire]], as well as invasions by [[Nader Shah]] from  in 1739 and the [[Durrani Empire]] of  in 1759.{{sfn|Haleem|2013}}{{sfn|MacDonald|2017}} The growing political power of the  in Bengal had not yet reached the territories of modern .{{sfn|Simpson|2007}}

=== Colonial rule ===
{{main| | Raj|Aligarh Movement|Two-nation theory}}
{{multiple image
| align             = right
| width1            = 146
